user: <sent>By focusing on the needed, the government can also reinforce the quality of support to them. the number of people needed to help matters, for the distribution of the limited budget is dependent on the number of people.</sent>
chatgpt_after:
Based on what you learned in class today, a cause-effect essay requires more than just stating the effects of an issue. It also requires an explanation of the underlying causes. 

So let's start by identifying the cause-effect relationships in your essay. Firstly, what is the issue that you are writing about? Can you provide me with more context?
prev_essay:
In the famous Korean movie "parasite", there are some people who do not worry about economic problem, but there are some people who have trouble living their lives due to their poor situation. Is it reasonable for the wealthy people to be helped by the government with the people who live in an underground floor? I think it is not desirable. The government should focus on helping only those most in need.
The first reason why the government needs to help the poor only is it is a way to save
a budget of the government. A leader of the country has to control its budget carefully, for
it is not infinite, but has maximum limitation. If all of its citizens get economic merits by some policies, there will be some situations where the government cannot use the budget to the parts which are needed really. By focusing on the needed, the government can also reinforce the quality of support to them. the number of people needed to help matters, for the distribution of the limited budget is dependent on the number of people. The smaller the number is, the greater the quality of support becomes.
The second reason is that there can be a positive effect about solving the economic inequality by helping only those most in need. The government gets its income mainly by the tax, which is from the wealthy. If it needs tax to help the poor, the wealthy need to pay more tax naturally, which makes their wealth reduced. In this way, the poor can enhance their economic level by the support made from the wealthy's tax.
In conclusion, the government should focus on helping only those most in need. The first reason is saving the budget, and the second reason is solving the problem about the economic inequality. Although there may be some problems about it, it is the best way to help the poor.

In the famous Korean movie "parasite", there are some people who do not worry about economic problem, but there are some people who have trouble living their lives due to their poor situation. The first reason why the government needs to help the poor only is it is a way to save
a budget of the government. The budget of a country is limited to some extent depending on its economic level. In addition to that, the contemporary society has to try to save its budget for the future generation, which will have lots of difficulty on their lives. As a result, a leader of the country has to control its budget carefully. If all of its citizens get economic merits by some policies, there will be some situations where the government cannot use the budget to the parts which are needed really. By focusing on the needed, the government can also reinforce the quality of support to them. It will help the government to save the budget for the future. Also, the quality of support will be upgraded because the distribution of the limited budget is dependent on the number of people. The cases of private insurance focusing on only small number of people guarantee that the quality of support is related to the number of people who are supported.
The second reason is that there can be a positive effect about solving the economic inequality by helping only those most in need. The government gets its income mainly by the tax, which is from the wealthy. If it needs tax to help the poor, the wealthy need to pay more tax naturally, which makes their wealth reduced. In this way, the poor can enhance their economic level by the support made from the wealthy's tax.
In conclusion, the government should focus on helping only those most in need. The first reason is saving the budget, and the second reason is solving the problem about the economic inequality. Although there may be some problems about it, it is the best way to help the poor.

user: This week I learned about the argumentative essays. In the academic argumentative essays, the third person point of view and outside sources are needed.
chatgpt_after:
Great! Let's start by reviewing your essay to see if it meets the requirements for an academic argumentative essay. 

First, let's check the point of view. Is your essay written in the third person point of view? If not, you will need to revise it to ensure that you are not using first or second person pronouns (I, me, my, we, us, our, you, your). 

Next, let's look at your use of outside sources. Have you included any sources to support your argument? If not, you will need to find credible sources to back up your claims. Make sure to properly cite your sources using the appropriate citation style (APA, MLA, etc.). 

Once you have addressed these two areas, we can move on to the structure of your essay. Does your essay have a clear introduction, body, and conclusion? Is your thesis statement clear and concise? If not, you may need to revise your essay to ensure that it follows a logical structure and that your thesis statement is strong and supported by evidence. 

Finally, let's review your use of language and grammar. Are there any areas where you could improve your word choice or sentence structure? Are there any grammatical errors that need to be corrected? Make sure to proofread your essay carefully to catch any mistakes. 

Remember, the goal of an academic argumentative essay is to present a clear and well-supported argument. By following these steps, you can ensure that your essay meets the requirements for this type of writing.

essay:
The government makes laws and protects its citizens from various problems, such as disasters, poverty, and crime. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by government. Each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than helping all of its citizens? I want to say 'no' to this question for several reasons;
    First, if we help only people in need then discrimination and hatred between group who gets benefit and who does not will be deeper. Government rules the country with a money from their citizen. Every law and system is possible when there is a money to make and operate it. If people in need only gets benefit from them, then people who don't get benefit will loose their motivation to pay tax. They will discriminate the people who get benefit.
    The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
    For these reason the government should not help only those most in need. Discrimination between two group will grow, and people will not work hard to earn money. All citizens have a right to be helped by their government, and helping everyone equally is a healthy approach for our society.

user:
I rewrited my essay. 

<essay>The government makes laws and protects its citizens from various problems, such as disasters, poverty, and crime. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by government. Each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than helping all of its citizens? I want to say 'no' to this question for several reasons;
    First, if we help only people in need then discrimination and hatred between group who gets benefit and who does not will be deeper. Government rules the country with a money from their citizen. Every law and system is possible when there is a money to make and operate it. If people in need only gets benefit from them, then people who don't get benefit will loose their motivation to pay tax. They will discriminate the people who get benefit.
    The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
    Third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and subject to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
    For these reason the government should not help only those most in need. Discrimination between two group will grow, and people will not work hard to earn money. Additionally, in reality it is hard to  implement a system of aid that targets only those most in need. In this procedure moral issues can occur.  All citizens have a right to be helped by their government, and helping everyone equally is a healthy approach for our society.</essay>

In this essay is there any grammatically wrong part?
chatgpt_after:
Yes, there are a few grammatical errors in the essay. Let's work on revising them step by step.

First, let's look at this sentence: <sent>"Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than helping all of its citizens?"</sent> There's a small error in subject-verb agreement. It should be, <sent>"should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens?" </sent>

Next, in the sentence, <sent>"While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, doing so can be discriminatory and demotivating."</sent> Replace the word 'doing' with 'it' to make it more clear.

The sentence, <sent>"If people in need only gets benefit from them, then people who don't get benefit will loose their motivation to pay tax"</sent> has a couple of issues. First, 'gets' should be 'get' to match the subject. Secondly, 'loose' is a spelling error - it should be spelled 'lose'. The sentence can be revised as <sent>"If people in need only get benefit from the government, then those who don't receive benefits will lose their motivation to pay taxes."</sent>

The sentence, <sent>"Third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and subject to abuse"</sent> can be revised as <sent>"A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse."</sent>

Finally, in the sentence <sent>"For these reason the government should not help only those most in need,"</sent> 'reason' should be pluralized to match the sentence. It should be revised to: <sent>"For these reasons, the government should not help only those most in need."</sent>

Let's review the revised version of the entire paragraph: 

<essay>The government makes laws and protects its citizens from various problems, such as disasters, poverty, and crime. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by the government. Each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? I want to say 'no' to this question for several reasons. While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens in need.

Firstly, if we help only people in need, discrimination and animosity between groups who receive benefits and who do not will deepen. The government governs the country with money from its citizens. Every rule and system is possible only when there is money to make and operate it. If only those in need receive benefits, those who do not may lose their motivation to pay taxes and may discriminate against those who benefit.

The second reason is that people may lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They may believe they do not need to work as they can rely on the government for money. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They are faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.

A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation to receive assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. There are also moral issues where people with greater resources may still qualify for government support due to errors in determining who qualifies for aid.

For these reasons, the government should not help only those most in need. Discrimination between two groups will grow, and people will not work hard to earn money. In addition, in reality, it is hard to implement a system of aid that targets only those most in need. All citizens have the right to be helped by their government, and helping everyone equally is a healthy approach for our society.</essay>

prev_essay:
The government makes laws and protects its citizens from various problems, such as disasters, poverty, and crime. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by government. Each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? I want to say 'no' to this question for several reasons;. While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens in need.
    First, if we help only people in need then discrimination and hatred between group who gets benefit and who does not will be deeper. Government rules the country with a money from their citizen. Every law and system is possible when there is a money to make and operate it. If people in need only get benefit from them, then people who don't get benefit will lose their motivation to pay tax. They will discriminate the people who get benefit.
    The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
    For these reasons the government should not help only those most in need. Discrimination between two group will grow, and people will not work hard to earn money. Additionally, in reality it is hard to  implement a system of aid that targets only those most in need. In this procedure moral issues can occur.  All citizens have a right to be helped by their government, and helping everyone equally is a healthy approach for our society.

The government makes laws and protects its citizens from various problems, such as disasters, poverty, and crime. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by government. Each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? I want to say 'no' to this question for several reasons;. While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens in need.
    First, if we help only people in need then discrimination and hatred between group who gets benefit and who does not will be deeper. Government rules the country with a money from their citizen. Every law and system is possible when there is a money to make and operate it. If people in need only get benefit from them, then people who don't get benefit will lose their motivation to pay tax. They will discriminate the people who get benefit.
    The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
    Another reason of why providing assistance to all citizens can be beneficial is in the case of education funding. When governments choose to provide financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need, they may inadvertently signal to students that their work will not be rewarded except in cases of dire fiscal straits. In such a system, students may feel more effective pursuing an education that does not require them to take out costly student loans, even if it means abandoning their preferred path of study. On the other hand, by promoting assistance to all citizens based on merit and academic achievement, governments can ensure that talented students have an equal opportunity to achieve their goals, and the workforce remains competitive. However, some may argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars. They may argue that only students who demonstrate financial need or who contribute to the public good or a particular industry should be eligible for government funding. However, while this argument may seem logical, it fails to account for the fact that many talented students who do not meet the stringent eligibility criteria may still struggle with the costs of tuition and other expenses that pose a barrier to their educational goals. Additionally, by promoting higher educational achievement and merit, governments can create a better-educated workforce overall, leading to higher economic returns and a more productive and innovative society. The cost to the taxpayer can be balanced against the benefits brought about by a more educated citizenry.
    For these reasons the government should not help only those most in need. Discrimination between two group will grow, and people will not work hard to earn money. Additionally, in reality it is hard to  implement a system of aid that targets only those most in need. In this procedure moral issues can occur.  All citizens have a right to be helped by their government, and helping everyone equally is a healthy approach for our society.

<essay>    The relationship between the government and its citizens is a complex interplay of power, responsibility, and accountability. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by government. Additionally, each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? This essay argues that the government should provide aid to all citizens, regardless of their financial status or demonstrated need, for several reasons; While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. Also, it creates a system that is prone to errors and fraud. Providing support to all citizens can promote social cohesion and responsibility. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens in need.

    First, limiting assistance to only those in need can create deeper discrimination and antagonism between groups. The government runs the country with tax money collected from its citizens. If only those in need receive benefits, it can create resentment among those who do not receive aid. Discrimination and stigmatization can arise, leading those who do not receive assistance to harbor ill will towards those who do. For example, when healthcare systems focus only on providing care to those who demonstrate financial need, it can create division and hatred. On the other hand, when assistance is provided to all citizens, accountability is shared and it fosters a sense of communal responsibility. Citizens are more invested in each other's well-being, leading to a more cohesive society.
 
   The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
Some people might say that providing assistance only to those in need has potential for greater efficiency, as resources are concentrated where they are most needed. Additionally, the amount of funding needed for assistance programs may be lower, as it is targeted towards those in dire circumstances. However, Those who are ineligible for assistance due to their financial standing may feel that they are being left out of important government programs. They will lose their reason to pay taxes and their motivation to work hard, and consequently, government will lose efficiency gained by helping only those in need.

   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
   
    Another reason is that providing financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need can create unintended consequences, such as discouraging students from pursuing their preferred paths of study based on cost. In contrast, a system that promotes providing assistance to all citizens based on merit and academic achievement ensures talented students have an equal opportunity to achieve their goals, thereby keeping the workforce competitive. Some argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars and that only those who demonstrate financial need or contribute to the public good should receive government funding. However, this argument fails to consider that limiting funding exclusively in this way may exclude many talented students from access to higher education, contributing to a less productive and innovative society overall. The cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry.
    
    In conclusion, the government must offer aid to all citizens to ensure a just and cohesive society. Providing assistance only to those most in need can intensify discrimination and breed resentment, ultimately eroding social solidarity. Additionally, such a system may disincentivize work by fostering resentment among those who do not qualify for aid. While some may argue that focusing aid only on those most in need can be more efficient, it can also exclude those who, despite not demonstrating obvious financial hardship, still require support. The process of determining who qualifies for aid can be complex and prone to errors, potentially leaving out deserving citizens. A system that promotes aid to all citizens is more inclusive and promotes social responsibility, while encouraging productivity and innovation. Therefore, it is imperative that the government consider equity and community investment when designing aid programs, rather than concentrating support on an exclusive group of people.</essay>

<essay>The relationship between government and citizens is a complex interplay of power, responsibility, and accountability. Citizens have the right to receive help and protection from the government, but circumstances vary, and each citizen may require assistance. Therefore, the question arises: Should the government help only those most in need, or should it provide aid to all citizens? This essay argues that the government should provide aid to all citizens, regardless of their financial situation or demonstrated needs, for several reasons. Firstly, limiting assistance only to those in need can lead to discrimination and division among groups. Secondly, it can demotivate people from working and thus hinder economic growth. Thirdly, it creates a system that is prone to errors and fraud. Finally, providing support to all citizens can promote social cohesion and a sense of responsibility.

The first reason is that limiting assistance to those in need can create deeper discrimination and antagonism between groups. The government runs the country with tax money collected from its citizens. If only those in need receive benefits, it can create resentment among those who do not receive aid. Discrimination and stigmatization can arise, leading those who do not receive assistance to harbor ill will towards those who do. For instance, when healthcare systems concentrate care only on those who demonstrate financial need, it can create division and hatred. On the other hand, when assistance is offered to all citizens, accountability is shared, and it fosters a sense of communal responsibility. Citizens are more invested in each other's well-being, leading to a more cohesive society.

The second reason is that offering assistance only to those in need can demotivate people from working. Those who do not qualify for government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They pay for others' income without receiving any benefits themselves, which may decrease their motivation to work. While some argue that providing aid exclusively to those most in need can lead to greater efficiency, as resources are concentrated where they are most needed, limiting assistance to some citizens due to financial standing may lead them to question the fairness of the system. It may cause them to lose their reason to pay taxes and their motivation to work hard, resulting in a less efficient system overall.

The third issue of implementing a system that targets only those most in need of assistance is that it can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some may intentionally misrepresent their situation to receive aid, while others might be unjustly excluded from assistance due to administrative errors. Additionally, those with greater resources might not require government support, yet may still benefit from it in various ways due to errors in determining qualifications for government aid.

Another reason is that providing financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need can create unintended consequences, such as discouraging students from pursuing their preferred courses of study based on cost. In contrast, a system promoting assistance for all citizens, based on merit and academic achievement, ensures that talented students have equal opportunities to achieve their goals, which keeps the workforce competitive. While some argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars and that only those who demonstrate financial need or contribute to the public good should receive government funding, such limitation may exclude many talented students from accessing higher education, contributing to a less productive and innovative society overall. Therefore, the cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry.

In conclusion, aid should be provided to all citizens to ensure a just and cohesive society. Providing assistance only to those most in need can intensify discrimination and breed resentment, ultimately eroding social solidarity. Additionally, such a system may disincentivize work by fostering resentment among those who do not qualify for aid. While some may argue that focusing aid exclusively on those most in need may lead to greater efficiency, such a system can exclude those who may still require financial support. The process of determining who qualifies for aid can be complex and prone to errors, potentially leaving out deserving citizens. Offering aid to all citizens promotes social responsibility, while encouraging productivity and innovation. To build equity and community investment, the government must design aid programs that promote both inclusivity and efficiency by supporting all its citizens.</essay>

essay:
The relationship between the government and its citizens is a complex interplay of power, responsibility, and accountability. Citizens have their rights to be helped and protected by government. Additionally, each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? This essay argues that the government should provide aid to all citizens, regardless of their financial status or demonstrated need, for several reasons; While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. Also, it creates a system that is prone to errors and fraud. Providing support to all citizens can promote social cohesion and responsibility. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens in need.

    First, limiting assistance to only those in need can create deeper discrimination and antagonism between groups. The government runs the country with tax money collected from its citizens. If only those in need receive benefits, it can create resentment among those who do not receive aid. Discrimination and stigmatization can arise, leading those who do not receive assistance to harbor ill will towards those who do. For example, when healthcare systems focus only on providing care to those who demonstrate financial need, it can create division and hatred. On the other hand, when assistance is provided to all citizens, accountability is shared and it fosters a sense of communal responsibility. Citizens are more invested in each other's well-being, leading to a more cohesive society.
 
   The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
Some people might say that providing assistance only to those in need has potential for greater efficiency, as resources are concentrated where they are most needed. Additionally, the amount of funding needed for assistance programs may be lower, as it is targeted towards those in dire circumstances. However, Those who are ineligible for assistance due to their financial standing may feel that they are being left out of important government programs. They will lose their reason to pay taxes and their motivation to work hard, and consequently, government will lose efficiency gained by helping only those in need.

   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
   
    Another reason is that providing financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need can create unintended consequences, such as discouraging students from pursuing their preferred paths of study based on cost. In contrast, a system that promotes providing assistance to all citizens based on merit and academic achievement ensures talented students have an equal opportunity to achieve their goals, thereby keeping the workforce competitive. Some argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars and that only those who demonstrate financial need or contribute to the public good should receive government funding. However, this argument fails to consider that limiting funding exclusively in this way may exclude many talented students from access to higher education, contributing to a less productive and innovative society overall. The cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry.
    
    In conclusion, the government must offer aid to all citizens to ensure a just and cohesive society. Providing assistance only to those most in need can intensify discrimination and breed resentment, ultimately eroding social solidarity. Additionally, such a system may disincentivize work by fostering resentment among those who do not qualify for aid. While some may argue that focusing aid only on those most in need can be more efficient, it can also exclude those who, despite not demonstrating obvious financial hardship, still require support. The process of determining who qualifies for aid can be complex and prone to errors, potentially leaving out deserving citizens. A system that promotes aid to all citizens is more inclusive and promotes social responsibility, while encouraging productivity and innovation. Therefore, it is imperative that the government consider equity and community investment when designing aid programs, rather than concentrating support on an exclusive group of people.

I made similar changes throughout the essay to shift the focus away from the individual writer and towards the topic being discussed in a more objective, third-person perspective.

Additionally, each citizen has different situations and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? This essay argues that the government should provide aid to all citizens, regardless of their financial status or demonstrated need, for several reasons; While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. Also, it creates a system that is prone to errors and fraud. Providing support to all citizens can promote social cohesion and responsibility. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens in need.

     First, limiting assistance to those in need can create deeper discrimination and antagonism between groups. The government runs the country with tax money collected from its citizens. If only those in need receive benefits, it can create resentment among those who do not receive aid. Discrimination and stigmatization can arise, leading those who do not receive assistance to harbor ill will towards those who do. For instance, when healthcare systems concentrate care only on those who demonstrate financial need, it can create division and hatred. On the other hand, when assistance is offered to all citizens, accountability is shared, and it fosters a sense of communal responsibility. Citizens are more invested in each other's well-being, leading to a more cohesive society.
 
   The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They just have to get money from government and live with it. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. They're faced with paying for the income of others without receiving any benefits themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases.
Some people might say that providing assistance only to those in need has potential for greater efficiency, as resources are concentrated where they are most needed. Additionally, the amount of funding needed for assistance programs may be lower, as it is targeted towards those in dire circumstances. However, Those who are ineligible for assistance due to their financial standing may feel that they are being left out of important government programs. They will lose their reason to pay taxes and their motivation to work hard, and consequently, government will lose efficiency gained by helping only those in need.

   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
   
    Another reason is that providing financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need can create unintended consequences, such as discouraging students from pursuing their preferred paths of study based on cost. In contrast, a system that promotes providing assistance to all citizens based on merit and academic achievement ensures talented students have an equal opportunity to achieve their goals, thereby keeping the workforce competitive. Some argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars and that only those who demonstrate financial need or contribute to the public good should receive government funding. However, this argument fails to consider that limiting funding exclusively in this way may exclude many talented students from access to higher education, contributing to a less productive and innovative society overall. The cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry.
    
    In conclusion, the government must offer aid to all citizens to ensure a just and cohesive society. Providing assistance only to those most in need can intensify discrimination and breed resentment, ultimately eroding social solidarity. Additionally, such a system may disincentivize work by fostering resentment among those who do not qualify for aid. While some may argue that focusing aid only on those most in need can be more efficient, it can also exclude those who, despite not demonstrating obvious financial hardship, still require support. The process of determining who qualifies for aid can be complex and prone to errors, potentially leaving out deserving citizens. A system that promotes aid to all citizens is more inclusive and promotes social responsibility, while encouraging productivity and innovation. Therefore, it is imperative that the government consider equity and community investment when designing aid programs, rather than concentrating support on an exclusive group of people.

is there any way to make essay formal?
chatgpt_after:
Certainly! Here are some suggestions for making the essay more formal:

1. Use more formal language: Avoid using contractions (such as "don't" or "can't"), and instead use the full form of the word ("do not" or "cannot"). Additionally, avoid using colloquialisms or slang.

2. Use more complex sentence structures: Try to use more complex sentence structures, such as compound or complex sentences. This will help to demonstrate a more advanced understanding of English grammar.

3. Use more precise vocabulary: Try to use more precise vocabulary wherever possible. For example, instead of saying "help," use a more specific word, such as "assistance" or "support."

4. Avoid using personal pronouns: Try to avoid using personal pronouns, such as "I" or "you," and instead use more formal language, such as "one" or "individuals."

5. Use proper formatting: Make sure to use proper formatting throughout the essay. This includes using a formal font such as Times New Roman, double-spacing the text, and including a header with your name and page number.

By incorporating these suggestions, you can make the essay more formal and professional in tone.

   The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They could become reliant on government aid and lose motivation to work. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. Those who do not receive aid may feel as though they are contributing to support others without receiving any support themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases. Some people might say that providing assistance only to those in need has potential for greater efficiency, as resources are concentrated where they are most needed. Additionally, the amount of funding needed for assistance programs may be lower, as it is targeted towards those in dire circumstances. However, Those who are ineligible for assistance due to their financial standing may feel that they are being left out of important government programs. They will lose their reason to pay taxes and their motivation to work hard, and consequently, government will lose efficiency gained by helping only those in need.

   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their situation in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
   
    Another reason is that providing financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need can create unintended consequences, such as discouraging students from pursuing their preferred paths of study based on cost. In contrast, a system that promotes providing assistance to all citizens based on merit and academic achievement ensures talented students have an equal opportunity to achieve their goals, thereby keeping the workforce competitive. Some argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars and that only those who demonstrate financial need or contribute to the public good should receive government funding. However, this argument fails to consider that limiting funding exclusively in this way may exclude many talented students from access to higher education, contributing to a less productive and innovative society overall. The cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry.
    
    In conclusion, the government must offer aid to all citizens to ensure a just and cohesive society. Providing assistance only to those most in need can intensify discrimination and breed resentment, ultimately eroding social solidarity. Additionally, such a system may disincentivize work by fostering resentment among those who do not qualify for aid. While some may argue that focusing aid only on those most in need can be more efficient, it can also exclude those who, despite not demonstrating obvious financial hardship, still require support. The process of determining who qualifies for aid can be complex and prone to errors, potentially leaving out deserving citizens. A system that promotes aid to all citizens is more inclusive and promotes social responsibility, while encouraging productivity and innovation. Therefore, it is imperative that the government consider equity and community investment when designing aid programs, rather than concentrating support on an exclusive group of people.

First, there is a sentence that could be made clearer by using an adjective clause. In the sentence <sent>"Those who do not receive aid may feel as though they are contributing to support others without receiving any support themselves,"</sent> you could use the relative pronoun "who" to form an adjective clause and make the sentence more concise: <sent>"Those who do not receive aid may feel as though they are contributing to support others who are receiving aid, without receiving any support themselves."</sent>

Overall, great job on the essay!

essay:
The relationship between the government and its citizens is a complex interplay of power, responsibility, and accountability. The government is responsible for providing its citizens with assistance and protection as a fundamental right. Additionally, each citizen has different circumstances and needs that may require assistance from the government. Therefore, the question arises: should the government help only those most in need rather than help all of its citizens? This essay argues that the government should provide aid to all citizens, regardless of their financial status or demonstrated need, for several reasons; While it may seem logical to provide aid only to those most in need, it can be discriminatory and demotivating. Also, it creates a system that is prone to errors and fraud. Providing support to all citizens can promote social cohesion and responsibility. A more equitable approach is to provide aid to all citizens, regardless of financial status or demonstrated need.

     First, By restricting aid to those who demonstrate financial need, the government runs the risk of perpetuating division and animosity among different social and economic groups.The government runs the country with tax money collected from its citizens. If only those in need receive benefits, it can create resentment among those who do not receive aid. Discrimination and stigmatization can arise, leading those who do not receive assistance to harbor ill will towards those who do. For instance, when healthcare systems concentrate care only on those who demonstrate financial need, it can create division and hatred. On the other hand, when assistance is offered to all citizens, accountability is shared, and it fosters a sense of communal responsibility. Citizens are more invested in each other's well-being, leading to a more cohesive society.
 
   The second reason is that people will lose their motivation to work if the government provides assistance to only those in need. They could become reliant on government aid and lose motivation to work. In such a system, those who do not benefit from government aid may feel disenfranchised and resentful towards those who do. Those who do not receive aid may feel as though they are contributing to support others without receiving aid, without receiving any support themselves. As a result, their motivation to work decreases. Some people might say that providing assistance only to those in need has potential for greater efficiency, as resources are focused where they are most needed. Additionally, the amount of funding needed for assistance programs may be lower, as it is targeted towards those in dire circumstances. However, Those who are ineligible for assistance due to their financial standing may feel that they are being left out of important government programs. They will lose their reason to pay taxes and their motivation to work hard, and consequently, government will lose efficiency gained by helping only those in need.

   A third problem of implementing a system of aid that targets only those most in need is that the process of determining who qualifies for aid can be highly subjective and prone to abuse. Determining who qualifies for government aid and who does not can be complex and time-consuming. Some people might intentionally misrepresent their circumstance in order to get assistance, while others might be unjustly excluded from aid due to administrative errors. Then there can be a moral issues. People with greater resources might not need government support, they may still benefit from it in various ways due to the error on determining who qualifies for government assistance.
   
    Another reason is that providing financial aid only to those who demonstrate financial need can create unintended consequences, such as discouraging students from pursuing their preferred paths of study based on cost. In contrast, a system that promotes providing assistance to all citizens based on merit and academic achievement guarantees talented students have an equal opportunity to achieve their goals, thereby keeping the workforce competitive. Some argue that providing financial assistance to all students based on merit is a wasteful use of taxpayer dollars and that only those who demonstrate financial need or contribute to the public good should receive government funding. However, this argument fails to consider that limiting funding exclusively in this way may exclude many talented students from access to higher education, contributing to a less productive and innovative society overall. The cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry.
    
    In conclusion, the government must offer aid to all citizens to secure a just and cohesive society. Providing assistance only to those most in need can escalate discrimination and breed resentment, ultimately eroding social solidarity. Additionally, such a system may disincentivize work by fostering resentment among those who do not qualify for aid. While some may argue that focusing aid only on those most in need can be more efficient, it can also exclude those who, despite not demonstrating obvious financial hardship, still require support. The process of determining who qualifies for aid can be complex and prone to errors, potentially leaving out deserving citizens. A system that promotes aid to all citizens is more comprehensive and promotes social responsibility, while encouraging productivity and innovation. Therefore, it is imperative that the government consider equity and community investment when designing aid programs, rather than concentrating support on an exclusive group of people.

Sure! I'll provide some suggestions on how you can make your use of adjective and adverb clauses more formal:

- Instead of using "those" repeatedly to refer to a group of people, consider using more precise language. For example, you could use "individuals" or "recipients" instead.

- Use a range of sentence structures to show your mastery of the English language. Try varying the length and complexity of your sentences, and use more sophisticated connectives such as "moreover" or "nevertheless" to link your ideas.

- Use more formal language where appropriate. For example, instead of saying "citizens have different circumstances and needs," you could say "citizens possess diverse circumstances and requirements."

- Use adjective clauses to provide additional information about a noun. For instance, instead of saying "when healthcare systems concentrate care only on those who demonstrate financial need," you could say "when healthcare systems focus care only on those individuals who exhibit dire financial need."

- Similarly, use adverb clauses to provide additional information about how, when, or why an action is taking place. For example, instead of saying "The cost to the taxpayer must be weighed against the benefits of investing in a more educated citizenry," you could say "As a result, the cost to the taxpayer must be carefully balanced against the important benefits of promoting a more educated citizenry."

Remember that formal language doesn't mean using big words or complicated sentence structures just for the sake of it. Rather, it's about being clear, precise, and appropriate to your subject matter and audience.

user: Today I learned about parallelism in a sentence, can you make an example on that
chatgpt_after:
Sure, here's an example of a sentence without using parallelism: 

"I like to run, swimming, and cycling." 

Notice how the sentence doesn't flow and doesn't make sense. To fix this mistake, we need to apply parallelism; we need to make the elements of the sentence grammatically and structurally similar. Here's a revised version of the sentence using parallelism: 

"I like to run, swim, and cycle."

Notice how the revised sentence is smoother and makes more sense by applying parallelism.
essay:
Governament help is a hot topic nowadays. Opinions from people are contrasting and parties find hard time to come out with a democratic solution. I believe governament should help citizens following their income. Those in need should be helped the most because it allows them to explore new opportunities and lower the poverty rate of the country.

To begin with, people of lower classes tend to have poorer education. University these days has become extremely expensive and not all families can provide funds for their children to continue with their studies. We can extimate an average of 500$ spent in a semester only in books and class utilities. This represents a big portion of a wage for people with financial difficulties. That is why governament should help them achieve a better education with scholarships and funds. People with high socioeconomic background have more opportunities to continue with their education, even if the annual payment for a school is high. If people in need recive the proper help, they can have multiple job options with high wage, which will favor not only his current family but also its future children.

Moreover, governaments are trying to fight against high rate of poverty in their country. To achieve this, those in needs need to be help by the governament, not only with funds but with new jobs, better housing and incentives. This will benefit the image of the country, next to helping lower classes. Some countries, such as South Korea, are facing a rapid growth which leads to an increase in the gap between poor people and rich families. In cities like Seoul we tend to see extremely fancy district and right around the corner old houses which look almost like falling apart. Most of them are filled with the old generation, which was left behind during the economic expansion. It does not look an appealing situation also for tourists, who might feel uncomfortable with sleeping in such area. Governament has to preserve the image of the country while helping those in need. 

In conclusion, governament should focus their help to those most in need because it will open them to new opportunities and create a better image of the country.

To achieve this, those in need need to be helped by the government, not only with funds but also with new jobs, better housing, and incentives. This will benefit the image of the country along with helping the lower classes. Some countries, such as South Korea, are facing rapid growth, which leads to an increase in the gap between poor people and rich families: the income gap between the wealthiest 10% and least wealthy 10% in South Korea is substantial, with a difference of 21 times(Hankyoreh, 2021). In cities like Seoul, we tend to see extremely fancy districts and right around the corner old houses which look almost like they are falling apart. Most of them are filled with the old generation, which was left behind during the economic expansion. The situation may not be attractive to tourists, who might feel uncomfortable with sleeping in such areas. The government has to preserve the image of the country while helping those in need.

In conclusion, by investing in those most in need, governments not only improve the lives of individuals and communities, but also pave the way for a brighter and more prosperous future. After all, a government that helps the less fortunate is a government that understands the true meaning of 'two-for-one' specials!


Reference:
Kim, J. (2021, February 22). Income gap exceeds 21 times average. The Hankyoreh. https://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_business/1071567.htm

chatgpt_after:
Yes, we can definitely use noun clauses in academic essays. They can help provide clarity and variety to your writing.

As for an example of a bad noun clause, see the following sentence:

"I don't know why she left."

In this sentence, "why she left" is a noun clause that serves as the direct object of the verb phrase "I don't know." While it's not necessarily a "bad" noun clause, it is a basic example of one and could be improved upon with more detail and complexity.

Now let's take a look at your essay. Can you please provide your essay for revision with the focus on using substantive noun clauses?

In conclusion, by investing in those most in need, governments not only improve the lives of individuals and communities, but also pave the way for a brighter and more prosperous future. Therefore, a government that assists the underprivileged can aid in fostering a fair and inclusive society, driving towards a more prosperous future.

Kim, J. (2021, February 22). Income gap exceeds 21 times average. The Hankyoreh. https://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_business/1071567.htm

user: when I use numbers in an essay, should I write them out?
chatgpt_after: When writing an essay, it is usually best to write out numbers in full up to ten, and then use digits for numbers larger than ten. For example, you would write "three" instead of "3" for a number less than 10, but "15" instead of "fifteen" for a number greater than 10. However, some style guides may have specific requirements for when to write out numbers, so it's important to consult the guidelines provided by your instructor or the publication you are writing for. Additionally, if there are a mix of numbers and written-out words in a sentence or paragraph, it's important to maintain consistency and choose one format to stick with throughout.

chatgpt_after: Yes, I understand. It sounds like you learned a lot about how to write a results section for a CHI paper. Can you tell me more about what you learned about proper punctuation? How can you use punctuation effectively in the results section?
prev_essay: The neural network, taking a 1D tensor representing the characteristics of a single audio file as input, produces a sequence of synchronized time-action pairs ready to be converted into the chosen beatmap format. This end-to-end approach was preferred over the separation of the problem into multiple subtasks, namely action placement and action selection, which is commonly used in the beatmap generation domain. Since transformers have obtained incredible results in many sequence-to-sequence tasks in terms of quality and parallelization potential, and are able to handle long sequences of data better than LSTM-based networks, a standard encoder-decoder transformer implementation was chosen as a generation model.
essay:
The 40 participants were divided into three categories based on their self-reported level of expertise: beginner (n=15), intermediate (n=15), and expert (n=10). The subsequent placement test confirmed the results for 37 people, while three were moved from the beginner to the intermediate category.
Participants then responded to a questionnaire to assess if the generated beatmaps had the same quality as the human-made ones. The questionnaire asked participants to rate the difficulty level, enjoyment, and overall quality of each beatmap on a scale from 1 to 5.
The results were overall satisfactory and showed that the opinions of the participants varied depending on their level of expertise (table 3). Beginner and intermediate participants found the generated beatmaps to be slightly less enjoyable and of slightly lower quality than the human-made ones. Moreover, there was no significant difference in the difficulty level between the two types of beatmaps. In the expert category, the average scores for the human-made beatmaps were significantly higher than for the generated ones; the small sample size and the inclusion of advanced players in this category might have been determining factors.
When asked about the best and worst aspects of each chart, 70% of the participants described the generated beatmaps as unpredictable and unique, but mentioned that they lacked the flow and coherence of human-made charts. 40% of the expert players thought that the patterns of generated beatmaps did not always match the rhythm of the song and felt too repetitive at times.

<essay>The main objective of this study was to generate high-quality beatmaps using a deep learning language model and evaluate its performance. 
We collected a set of guidelines to evaluate beatmap quality and generalized the algorithm‚Äôs application field from one game to a set of games that share common features. Additionally, we expanded the Fraxtil-ITG dataset with valuable training data for music annotation purposes. 

This study contributes to developing advanced beatmap generation algorithms, which can benefit both beatmap makers and players by speeding up the creation process and enhancing the overall user experience. With a faster generation process, game updates can be released more quickly, giving players more varied and interesting content and allowing beatmappers to focus on the creative aspects of the task.</essay>

thanks that sounds great. what about this part?

<para>The results of the study indicated that the proposed algorithm was effective in generating beatmaps that accurately reflected the timing and rhythm patterns of the input music tracks. Specifically, the model achieved an overall step placement F1-score of 0.83 and a step selection accuracy of 73% with an end-to-end approach. Moreover, the Over P-Space score of the generated charts increased by 15% compared to the baseline algorithms.
Since there are several valid ways to interpret the same song, resulting in multiple possible beatmaps, evaluating the output correctly can be challenging. The achieved scores indicate that the algorithm can produce charts comparable to those created manually.

The user test results showed that the generated beatmaps were similar in terms of difficulty level and enjoyment to the human-made ones, but the expert players rated the latter as significantly better in terms of overall quality. The feedback received highlights the importance of considering the level of expertise of the intended users when evaluating quality. Beginner and intermediate players may be less critical than experienced players with higher standards. Since some participants described the generated beatmaps as unpredictable and unique but lacking flow and coherence, there may be room for improvement in the generation of more consistent and intuitive patterns that follow the structure and melody of the song. This could be achieved through incorporating low-level audio features into the model.</para>

prev_essay:
Despite the promising results, there are some limitations to consider. Firstly, while the percentage of unique patterns in the generated beatmaps greatly increased, it was still significantly lower than that of human-made beatmaps, especially for higher difficulty levels. Secondly, while the proposed algorithm outperformed the DDC baseline in every aspect, it was slightly worse than the GN baseline for the beginner charts.

Future research may investigate ways to improve consistency across all difficulty levels and incorporate the spatial placement of actions for specific game interfaces. It could also examine the variations in beatmaps created by different authors for the same song and develop a metric to quantify them to refine the evaluation guidelines. Obtaining feedback from experienced beatmap creators may be necessary.
The algorithm could have practical applications, especially for amateur video game developers who don't have the resources or expertise to create precise and engaging beatmaps from scratch. It could also be used for motor and cognitive skill recovery rhythm-based games in healthcare and rehabilitation settings.

user: Please list the specific suggestions to improve the writing of the passage. Show them as a numbered list of edits
chatgpt_after:
Sure, here is a list of specific suggestions to improve the writing of the passage:

1. Clarify the objective of the experiment in the opening sentence, for example: "The objective of this experiment was to assess the impact of the Skip-Reduce technique on the training of deep neural network (DNN) models."
2. Specify the names of the DNN models being tested, rather than just using their acronyms, for example: "the ResNet50, VGG16, BERT, and YOLO models."
3. Use consistent tense throughout the passage, for example: "The Adaptive Skip-Reduce technique varies for each DNN model."
4. Use clear and concise sentence structure, for example: "Figures \ref{fig:resnet50_skip}, \ref{fig:vgg16_skip}, \ref{fig:bert_skip}, and \ref{fig:yolo_skip} show the test accuracy (F1/mAP score) plots for all evaluated DNN models with Skip-Reduce."
5. Add a brief explanation of what the convergence results in Tables \ref{tab:acc_skip_4} and \ref{tab:acc_skip_8} mean, for example: "These tables show the achieved convergence results for the DNN models trained on the 4GPU and 8GPU systems, respectively."
6. Consider breaking up the passage into smaller paragraphs for better readability and flow.
prev_essay:
To evaluate Skip-Reduce, we train DNN models on two systems: 4GPU system and 8GPU system, as described in the Section 5.1. For 4GPU system, we evaluate four pruning options: Skipping 1 Reduce-Scatter (RS) step, Skipping 2 RS steps, Skipping 1 RS and 1 All-Gather (AG) steps, and Adaptive Skip-Reduce. For 8GPU system, the options are similar, except the number of skipped steps is scaled twofold, i.e.: 2RS steps, 4RS steps, 2RS and 2AG steps. 

The Adaptive Skip-Reduce varied for each DNN model. For ResNet50 and VGG16, he schedule consisted of 75 epochs with Skipping 2 RS, followed by 75 epochs with Skipping 1 RS, and finally the last 50 epochs with no pruning. For YOLO, it is [250, 250, 100] in the same order. On 8GPU system, the schedules are identical or similar, except the pruning options are scaled appropriately (e.g., Skipping 2RS becomes Skipping 4RS and etc.).

Figures \ref{fig:resnet50_skip}, \ref{fig:vgg16_skip}, \ref{fig:bert_skip}, \ref{fig:yolo_skip} show the test accuracy (F1/mAP score) plots for all evaluated DNNs with Skip-Reduce. Table \ref{tab:acc_skip_4} shows achieved convergence results for training on 4GPU system, while Table \ref{tab:acc_skip_8} shows convergence results for training on 8GPU system.

For 8GPU system, the options are similar, except the number of skipped steps is scaled twofold, i.e.: 2RS steps, 4RS steps, 2RS and 2AG steps. 

The Adaptive Skip-Reduce varied for each DNN model. For ResNet50 and VGG16, he schedule consisted of 75 epochs with Skipping 2 RS, followed by 75 epochs with Skipping 1 RS, and finally the last 50 epochs with no pruning. For YOLO, it is [250, 250, 100] in the same order. On 8GPU system, the schedules are identical or similar, except the pruning options are scaled appropriately (e.g., Skipping 2RS becomes Skipping 4RS and etc.).

Figures \ref{fig:resnet50_skip}, \ref{fig:vgg16_skip}, \ref{fig:bert_skip}, \ref{fig:yolo_skip} show the test accuracy (F1/mAP score) plots for all evaluated DNNs with Skip-Reduce. Table \ref{tab:acc_skip_4} shows achieved convergence results for training on 4GPU system, while Table \ref{tab:acc_skip_8} shows convergence results for training on 8GPU system.

user:
I want you to make the following text look better. If it is ok, then there is no need to change something. No need to paraphrase every word: 


Conclusion

<essay>This work proposed an alternative method for random gradient pruning called Skip-Reduce. We achieved notable performance benefits without loss in accuracy, most notably 11.25% speed-up in ResNet50 training and 25.75% speed-up in VGG16 training. 

Skip-Reduce performs random pruning by skipping devices, thereby saving time on All-Reduce operations. Unlike previous work, Skip-Reduce does not suffer from scalability issues on Ring AllReduce and does not require expensive gradient sorting operations. It allows costless random pruning at any percentage, overcoming the need to send the indices along with the retained gradients. 

With more devices in the ring, Skip-Reduce enables fine-grained choices of skipping steps and pruning percentages. Moreover, using Adaptive Skip-Reduce allows the design of more sophisticated pruning strategies, providing a trade-off between accuracy and performance.

Due to the lack of available computing resources, the evaluations in this work were done on relatively small systems (4-GPU and 8-GPU), however the performance benefit is expected to be greater in large-scale systems, consisting of hundreds of devices. Despite these limitations, this work has presented notable improvement on a 8-GPU system and has shown theoretical analysis of large-scale systems. Generalizing Skip-Reduce to other algorithms and hierarchical systems will be a focus for future research.

This work introduced a practical approach for random pruning with guaranteed performance benefits and without scalability issues on Ring All-Reduce.</essay>

Conclusion

This work proposed an alternative method for random gradient pruning called Skip-Reduce. We achieved notable performance benefits without loss in accuracy, most notably 11.25% speed-up in ResNet50 training and 25.75% speed-up in VGG16 training. 

Skip-Reduce performs random pruning by skipping devices, thereby saving time on All-Reduce operations. Unlike previous work, Skip-Reduce does not suffer from scalability issues on Ring AllReduce and does not require expensive gradient sorting operations. It allows costless random pruning at any percentage, overcoming the need to send the indices along with the retained gradients. 

With more devices in the ring, Skip-Reduce enables fine-grained choices of skipping steps and pruning percentages. Moreover, using Adaptive Skip-Reduce allows the design of more sophisticated pruning strategies, providing a trade-off between accuracy and performance.

Due to the lack of available computing resources, the evaluations in this work were done on relatively small systems (4-GPU and 8-GPU), however the performance benefit is expected to be greater in large-scale systems, consisting of hundreds of devices. Despite these limitations, this work has presented notable improvement on a 8-GPU system and has shown theoretical analysis of large-scale systems. Generalizing Skip-Reduce to other algorithms and hierarchical systems will be a focus for future research.

This work introduced a practical approach for random pruning with guaranteed performance benefits and without scalability issues on Ring All-Reduce.

This work introduced a practical approach for random pruning with guaranteed performance benefits and without scalability issues on Ring All-Reduce.

How does the following abstract look? Could you give a list of suggestions to change?
<para>Public cloud providers seek to meet stringent performance
requirements and low hardware cost. A key driver of performance and cost is main memory. Memory pooling
promises to improve DRAM utilization and thereby reduce costs. However, pooling is challenging under cloud
performance requirements. This paper proposes Pond,
the first memory pooling system that both meets cloud
performance goals and significantly reduces DRAM cost.
Pond builds on the Compute Express Link (CXL) standard
for load/store access to pool memory and two key insights.
First, our analysis of cloud production traces shows that
pooling across 8-16 sockets is enough to achieve most
of the benefits. This enables a small-pool design with
low access latency. Second, it is possible to create machine learning models that can accurately predict how
much local and pool memory to allocate to a virtual machine (VM) to resemble same-NUMA-node memory performance. Our evaluation with 158 workloads shows
that Pond reduces DRAM costs by 7% with performance
within 1-5% of same-NUMA-node VM allocations.</para>
chatgpt_after:
Yes, I understand. Based on the abstract provided, there are several suggestions that could be made to enhance its effectiveness:

1. The first sentence could be rephrased to be more specific. Who are the public cloud providers attempting to meet these stringent performance requirements and low hardware cost?

2. Use specific data or examples to support how main memory affects performance and cost. 

3. Further explanation is needed on how memory pooling has been difficult to achieve under cloud performance requirements.

4. The second sentence of the abstract needs to be rewritten. You already mentioned the cost reduction due to memory pooling in the previous sentence. 

5. Use more specific language to explain how Pond operates with CXL. 

6. More details would be helpful in understanding the significance of "small-pool design" and how the predictions for memory allocation were made.

7. It would be beneficial to mention what type of workloads were tested in the Pond evaluation.

Overall, the abstract can be further improved by using specific wording, data, and examples to help the reader understand the research being presented.
prev_essay: There has been a huge line of work proposing various defense mechanisms against Rowhammer. Some studies proposed increasing the refresh rate of all rows, which effectively reduces the typical refresh window of 64 ms to a smaller time frame [cite]. Another approach is to identify aggressor rows by tracking recent row activations. We categorize works in this domain into three types: 1) targeted row refresh, 2) throttling, and 3) aggressor row swap. The targeted row refresh focuses on refreshing the identified victim rows out of schedule. The throttling limits the number of issued activations to the level that guarantees protection, and the aggressor row swap alters the physical location of the aggressor row, such that previous victim rows are no longer in danger.

<para>A considerable amount of effort has been directed towards developing various mechanisms to defend against the Rowhammer. Some studies proposed increasing the refresh rate of all rows, which effectively reduces the typical refresh window of 64 ms to a smaller time frame [cite]. Alternatively, some researchers have suggested identifying aggressor rows by tracking recent row activations. These efforts can be grouped into three categories: targeted row refresh, throttling, and aggressor row swap. The targeted row refresh focuses on scheduling refresh operations for identified victim rows outside of the regular schedule. The throttling approach limits the number of issued row activations to a predetermined level that ensures protection [cite]. Finally, the aggressor row swap approach involves changing the physical location of the aggressor row [cite]. By doing so, previously victimized rows are no longer in danger. </para>
