essay:
The samples for conductivity analysis were prepared in three different configurations. InOx layers were formed on SiO2 or Al2O3 buffer layers, as shown in Figure 1. Thermal oxidized Si wafers were used as substrates to ensure insulation between the InOx layer and Si wafer during conductivity measurements. As a reference sample, a 20 nm-thick InOx film was deposited on the substrate by plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition (PEALD) at 200 ¬∞C with 100 W plasma power. It involved gaseous oxygen and [3-(Dimethylamino)propryl](dimethyl)indium (DADI) precursor. Conductivity measurement electrodes were formed with 150 nm-thick molybdenum (Mo) by sputtering using shadow masks. (Figure 1(a)). The second sample was fabricated by sequential formation of SiO2 buffer layer and InOx. The SiO2 films were 500 nm-thick, and deposited via plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) in an ambient gas mixture of SiH4/N2O at 300 ¬∞C. To recreate the fabrication process of TFTs, CF4 dry etch and photoresist (PR) strip were done on the SiO2 films. InOx layers and Mo electrode were formed using the same method as the reference sample (Figure 1.(b)). Fabrication of the third sample was same with the second sample, except for the formation of buffer layers. Instead of SiO2 films, 50 nm-thick Al2O3 films were deposited using thermal ALD at 150 ¬∞C with trimethylaluminum (TMA) and H2O precursor (Figure 1(c)). For surface depth profile analysis, the Mo electrode formation steps were excluded from the sample preparation. Vacuum thermal annealing was done before the electrode formation at temperatures at 100/200/300/400 ¬∞C, respectively.
	Four probe conductivity measurements were done on the samples with Mo electrode. Time-of flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) and elastic recoil detection (ERD) were used to measure the hydrogen concentration and depth profiles of elements in the films. Thermal desorption spectroscopy (TDS) was used to measure the amount of hydrogen desorbed from the surface as temperature increases.

user:
Consider this sentence: <sent>As noted in our discussion, prolonged exposure to morphine also produces apoptosis in cell culture.</sent>
The discussion can be considered a method. Why cannot 'by' be used instead of 'in'?
chatgpt_after: You make a good point. In this sentence, we talk about something noted in a discussion, so 'in' is the appropriate preposition to use. In this case, 'by' would not be appropriate because we are not talking about a person or an agent that performed an action. Additionally, we cannot consider the discussion to be a method in this context because the discussion is a forum where people exchange ideas and information, not a specific method used to conduct research. Therefore, 'in' is the correct preposition to use in this sentence.

user:
Figure 2(a)-(d) compares the hydrogen content ([H]) depth profiles obtained by ToF-SIMS in InOx film deposited on top of thermally oxidized Si wafer, SiO2 buffer layer, and Al2O3 buffer layer. The samples were analyzed in as-deposited state, and after 280 ¬∞C vacuum annealing for 2 hours. The InOx film on thermal oxide was used as a reference, and was not annealed. Both samples irrespective of annealing showed higher [H]  in the buffer layer region, and it was higher in Al2O3 than SiO2.
In the as-deposited state, the [H] of InOx film was the highest on Al2O3 buffer, which can be attributed to the highest [H] in the Al2O3. The [H] of InOx film was the lowest in the sample with SiO2 buffer, which had the second highest [H]. The hydrogen might be absorbed into the SiO2 layer during deposition.
After annealing, [H] in InOx films decreased. The decrease is most prominent in the sample with Al2O3 buffer, and it became lower than the sample with SiO2. The decrease in both samples can be explained by out-diffusion of hydrogen from the films into the vacuum, and the hydrogen in InOx on Al2O3 buffer might be more unstable than those on SiO2 buffer, causing the drastic decrease in [H] after annealing.
The depth profiles also showed humps at the interface. Since the shapes and locations of the humps differ by the buffer layer composition, the origin is likely be related to the interface properties. Detailed cause of these humps should be investigated further.
To investigate the change in [H] during annealing, the samples with SiO2 and Al2O3 buffer layers were annealed in vacuum at temperatures 100-400 ¬∞C for 2 hours. Figure 3(a)-(d) shows the [H] depth profile in SiO2 and Al2O3 buffer layers and the InOx film in the as-deposited state and after annealing. As shown in Figure 3(b), the InOx layer on SiO2 buffer had decreasing [H] as the annealing temperature increased. Since it also showed decreasing trend in the SiO2 buffer layer, it is most likely that the rate of hydrogen out-diffusion into the vacuum was higher than the diffusion from SiO2 to InOx.
	On the other hand, [H] in InOx film on Al2O3 layer did not show a clear trend. As in Figure 3(d), [H] of as-deposited InOx film was the highest, and while the content was similar in annealing temperatures between 100-300 ¬∞C, the 400 ¬∞C annealed sample showed increasing [H] as the depth decreased. Interestingly, the [H] in the Al2O3 buffer region was the highest in 300 ¬∞C annealed sample, even higher than that of as-deposited. The reproducibility of the results needs to be confirmed, and the reasons behind the lack of a clear trend should be examined in detail.
chatgpt_after:
Your draft looks good. Just a couple of small suggestions for revision:

1. In the first sentence, you can add the word "of" after "content" to make it clearer. So it would read: "Figure 2(a)-(d) compares the hydrogen content (of [H]) depth profiles..."

2. In the last sentence, you could clarify by saying "the reasons behind the lack of a clear trend in the [H] of the InOx film on the Al2O3 buffer layer". So the whole sentence would read: "The reproducibility of the results needs to be confirmed, and the reasons behind the lack of a clear trend in the [H] of the InOx film on the Al2O3 buffer layer should be examined in detail."

Does that work for you, or do you have any other questions or concerns?

user: Can you check the grammar and article use of the draft?
chatgpt_after:
Sure, I'd be happy to help you with that. Here are some suggestions for improving the grammar and article use in your draft:

- In the first sentence, it would be more accurate to say "Hydrogen (H) in oxide semiconductors plays an important role." since you are referring to a general class of materials, not a specific oxide semiconductor.
- In the second sentence, it would be clearer to say "Here, we investigated the diffusion of H in an InOx film from buffer layers after vacuum annealing at various temperatures." This makes it clear that you are referring to a specific InOx film, not oxide semiconductors in general.
- In the third sentence, it would be better to say "The InOx film was deposited using PEALD on top of a thermally oxidized Si wafer, PECVD SiO2, and ALD Al2O3." This makes it clear that you are referring to specific deposition methods for each layer.
- In the fourth sentence, it would be more accurate to say "Electrodes were fabricated on the InOx film for conductivity measurements." since you are referring to a specific InOx film, not oxide semiconductors in general.
- In the fifth sentence, it would be clearer to say "SIMS analysis revealed that vacuum annealing caused the out-diffusion of H from both the buffer layers and the InOx film." This makes it clear that you are referring to specific layers in your sample.
- In the sixth sentence, it would be better to say "For InOx films with SiO2 buffer layers, out-diffusion from both the InOx film and the buffer layer was more severe at higher annealing temperatures." This makes it clear that you are referring to specific layers in your sample.
- In the seventh sentence, it would be more accurate to say "However, the out-diffusion trend was not clear in samples with Al2O3 buffer layers." since you are referring to specific samples, not oxide semiconductors in general.
- In the eighth sentence, it would be clearer to say "There was no clear correlation between the conductivity of the InOx films and the H concentration." This makes it clear that you are referring to specific samples in your study.
- In the last sentence, it would be better to say "Further studies should be conducted to investigate the chemical state of H inside InOx films." This makes it clear that you are referring to future research.

prev_essay: Hydrogen (H) in oxide semiconductor plays an important role. It can act as a shallow donor, or a passivator of dangling bonds. Here, the diffusion of H in InOx film from buffer layers after vacuum annealing were investigated for various temperatures. The InOx film was deposited using PEALD on top of thermal oxidized Si wafer, PECVD SiO2, and ALD Al2O3. Electrodes were fabricated on InOx for conductivity measurements. SIMS analysis revealed that vacuum annealing caused the out-diffusion of H in both buffer layers and InOx. For InOx films with SiO2 buffer layers, out-diffusion from both the InOx film and buffer layer was more severe at higher annealing temperatures. However, the out-diffusion trend was not clear in samples with Al2O3 buffer layers. There was no clear correlation for conductivity of InOx films and H concentration. Further study should be conducted to investigate the chemical state of H inside InOx films.
essay: Hydrogen (H) in oxide semiconductor plays an important role. It can act as a shallow donor, or a passivator of dangling bonds. Here, the diffusion of H in InOx film from buffer layers after vacuum annealing were investigated for various temperatures. The InOx film was deposited using PEALD on top of thermal oxidized Si wafer, PECVD SiO2, and ALD Al2O3. Electrodes were fabricated on InOx for conductivity measurements. SIMS analysis revealed that vacuum annealing caused the out-diffusion of H in both buffer layers and InOx. For InOx films with SiO2 buffer layers, out-diffusion from both the InOx film and buffer layer was more severe at higher annealing temperatures. However, the out-diffusion trend was not clear in samples with Al2O3 buffer layers. There was no clear correlation for conductivity of InOx films and H concentration. Further study should be conducted to investigate the chemical state of H inside InOx films.

user: Why there's error?
chatgpt_after:
I apologize for the error. I misunderstood your previous message. 

To answer your question, active voice is when the subject of a sentence performs the action, while passive voice is when the subject is acted upon. 

For example, in the active voice sentence <sent>"The cat chased the mouse,"</sent> the subject "cat" is performing the action of chasing. In contrast, in the passive voice sentence <sent>"The mouse was chased by the cat,"</sent> the subject "mouse" is being acted upon, and the subject "cat" has become the object of the sentence.

user: I learned about the hyphen rules. But I was not fully understood about it. Why should I hyphenate the following: Low-frequency ? Just writing 'low frequency' without hyphen is wrong?
chatgpt_after: Yes. When you use a hyphen between two words like "low-frequency," it creates a compound modifier. This means that the two words now function together as one unit to describe or modify the noun that comes after them. In the case of "low-frequency," it is describing a noun, so it needs to be hyphenated. If you simply wrote "low frequency" without a hyphen, it would not convey the same meaning as "low-frequency." Without the hyphen, "low" and "frequency" would be read as separate words, and the reader would not understand that they were meant to be taken together as a unit modifying the noun. Does that make sense?

essay: Conventional cationic liposome was prepared by microfluidic device mixing ethanol phase and aqueous phase rather than the film hydration method. At ethanol phase, DOPC, cholesterol, DOTAP and TPGS were used with 4: 2: 3: 1 ratio. 123mM ammonium sulfate solution in distilled water was used at aqueous phase. Total flow rate (TFR) and Flow rate ratio (FFR) are 10 and 3:1, respectively. After the liposome nanoparticles were synthesized, desalting step was followed. Then, 5% w/w DOX-HCl was inserted and stirred at 250 rpm for an hour at 60‚ÑÉ. Amicon concentration was conducted at 8000xg 20 min X 2 to purify liposome from left doxorubicin. Finally, liposomes were coated with one-fifth concentration CSA or TCSA solution dissolved in DW for 3 hours at room temperature with 180 rpm. The whole procedures after inserting doxorubicin were conducted under blocking lights conditions. Because doxorubicin has intrinsic fluorescence at 595nm, light can weaken its property.

user: Then usually people write their discussion in the results part in the scientific paper?
chatgpt_after: No, it is not appropriate to write a discussion in the results part of a scientific paper. As I mentioned earlier, the results section simply presents the raw data that you have collected, often in the form of tables, graphs, or figures. This section does not offer any interpretation or analysis of the data that you have collected. In contrast, the discussion section is where you can interpret and analyze the results, and discuss their implications. It is important that you keep these two sections separate in your paper.
prev_essay:
Introduction and discussion
Introduction: write about the work of other researcher; describe what type of work existed in the field, Locate a gap in the research; describe a problem associated with existing research., Write about the present paper, creating an interface with content of work so you could move the reader to the central section of paper.

Discussion: Describe your study in relation to what is already in the field. Describe to what extent you have responded to that gap in the research field or how you have solved that problem., Revisit aspects of your study and guide readers away from your current report to future research.

<essay>We investigated personality type depending on having siblings for the students in the F class of ‚Äòscientific writing‚Äô. As shown in Fig 1., the percentage of only child and one who having siblings is 86.7% and 13.3%, respectively. The percentage of E (extroverted) and I (introverted) is 46.7% and 53.3%, respectively. Actually, this result couldn‚Äôt reflect the relationship between the existence of siblings and personality. We have difficult to evaluate hypotheses that having brothers and sisters has an extroverted personality than only child.
For this reason, we retry to examine the individual results as you can see in Fig 2. The number of students of the introverted is 7 and the extroverted is 6 among having siblings, respectively, while the number of students of the introverted is 1 and the extroverted is 1 that exhibited the same number among only child. It is shown that the presence or absence of siblings is not directly related to the personality type (extroverted and introverted)
As a result, it exhibited the hypothesis that having siblings is relatively extroverted than only child. It seems that there are many factors like the environment of growth. And thus, it could not conclude a person‚Äôs personality by having brothers and sisters. Also, considering that the subject of investigation is a very small standard group of class students, it is judged that the number of standard groups should be increased for a more accurate comparative analysis.</essay>
chatgpt_after:
Well done! Overall, your results section provides a clear and concise summary of your study findings. However, there are a few suggestions that may help improve the clarity of your writing. Firstly, in the first sentence, consider rephrasing the sentence to "Our study investigated the relationship between personality types and the presence or absence of siblings among students in the F class of Scientific Writing."

Secondly, in the third sentence, it would be helpful to provide the actual number of students in the survey, for example "Out of the total number of students surveyed, 86.7% were only child while 13.3% had siblings."

Thirdly, the sentence "Actually, this result couldn't reflect the relationship between the existence of siblings and personality." is a bit unclear. Consider rephrasing it to "However, the results obtained were inconclusive in establishing a relationship between the presence or absence of siblings and personality traits."

Finally, in the fourth and fifth paragraph, you did a great job of explaining the findings and interpreting the results. However, the sentences could be refined and restructured to enhance clarity. Consider breaking them down into smaller statements, with clear and concise wording. For example, "Based on the survey, the number of students exhibiting introverted characteristics was similar in both the only-child and having-siblings group. However, there was a higher percentage of extroverted students among the having-siblings group."

Overall, great work! Keep practicing and refining your scientific writing skills.

Our study investigated the relationship between personality types and the presence or absence of siblings among students in the F class of Scientific Writing. As shown in Fig 1., the percentage of only child and one who having siblings is 86.7% and 13.3%, respectively. The percentage of E (extroverted) and I (introverted) is 46.7% and 53.3%, respectively. However, the results obtained were inconclusive in establishing a relationship between the presence or absence of siblings and personality traits. We have difficult to evaluate hypotheses that having brothers and sisters has an extroverted personality than only child.
For this reason, we retry to examine the individual results as you can see in Fig 2. The number of students of the introverted is 7 and the extroverted is 6 among having siblings, respectively, while the number of students of the introverted is 1 and the extroverted is 1 that exhibited the same number among only child. It is shown that the presence or absence of siblings is not directly related to the personality type (extroverted and introverted)
As a result, it exhibited the hypothesis that having siblings is relatively extroverted than only child. It seems that there are many factors like the environment of growth. And thus, it coouuld not conclude a person‚Äôs personality by having brothers and sisters. Also, considering that the subject of investigation is a very small standard group of class students, it is judged that the number of standard groups should be increased for a more accurate comparative analysis.

essay:
We prepared a cationic liposome coated with TCSA (taurocholic acid-chondroitin sulfate) by electrostatic attraction (Figure 1A). The cationic liposome was prepared with DOPC, cholesterol, DOTAP and TPGS in a ratio of 4: 2: 3: 1. DOPC and cholesterol were used for stability of liposome, TPGS was used as an inhibitor of p-gp activity, and DOTAP was used specifically for coating the liposome with TCSA polymer. 

However, to coat the cationic liposome with TCSA polymer stably, the concentration of TCSA was optimized (Figure 1B). At the polymer concentration of w/w one-fifth and half, the zeta potential value shows -28.8 and -28.5 respectively and it indicates the liposome was coated stably. However, in case of the w/w concentration of 1/10 and 1/20, the concentration of polymer was too low so the zeta potential value shows positive charge of cationic liposome. Since the residual amount of polymer was not separately purified, we processed polymer coating with one-fifth w/w concentration of TCSA. The final nanoparticles coated with TCSA size distribution, PDI, and zeta potential were 74.87 nm, 0.276, and -30.2 mV, respectively (Figure 1C).

essay:
We prepared a cationic liposome coated with TCSA (taurocholic acid-chondroitin sulfate) by electrostatic attraction (Figure 1A). The cationic liposome was prepared with DOPC, cholesterol, DOTAP and TPGS in a ratio of 4: 2: 3: 1. DOPC and cholesterol were used for stability of liposome, TPGS was used as an inhibitor of p-gp activity, and DOTAP was used specifically for coating the liposome with TCSA polymer. 

However, to coat the cationic liposome with TCSA polymer stably, the concentration of TCSA was optimized (Figure 1B). At the polymer concentration of w/w one-fifth and half, the zeta potential value shows -28.8 and -28.5 respectively and it indicates the liposome was coated stably. However, in case of the w/w concentration of 1/10 and 1/20, the concentration of polymer was too low so the zeta potential value shows positive charge of cationic liposome. Since the residual amount of polymer was not separately purified, we processed polymer coating with one-fifth w/w concentration of TCSA. The final nanoparticles coated with TCSA size distribution, PDI, and zeta potential were 74.87 nm, 0.276, and -30.2 mV, respectively (Figure 1C).

<essay>We have developed the platform of a novel bile acid-based liposome loaded doxorubicin for effective oral anti-cancer therapy. Our nanoplatform is designed with conjugation of taurocholic acid polymer to drug-loaded cationic liposome via electrostatic attraction. This developed nanoparticle demonstrated increased absorption ability, which is one of the limitations for oral delivery, compared to other non-coating groups and showed powerful anti-cancer efficacy through apoptosis test. Furthermore, the tocofersolan modification on liposome for p-gp inhibition also proved the synergistic effect by inhibiting drug efflux from cancer cell resulting in maximizing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin on cancer cell.
The development of the effective oral nanoplatform implies that it might provide an innovatory and convenient quality of anti-cancer treatment for cancer patients. Also, this nanoplatform can apply to other intravenous drugs of bacterial diseases as well as other cancer types for conversion to oral administration. Its possibilities are endless due to the properties of lipid platform synthesized microfluidic device. Though this research has used taurocholic acid which is one type of secondary bile acids for oral ability of nanoparticle, other secondary bile acid like glycocholic acid might have superior ability to apply on drug delivery platform. We found the targeting efficacy of taurocholic acid in this paper so the next step for commercialization of oral administration is optimization of the bile acids. These efforts might open the opportunities for improved quality of life to suffering cancer patients. </essay>

prev_essay: The survey findings provide partial support for our hypothesis. Participants who made daily or weekly reminders seemed to experience less forgetfulness than those who did not make reminders. However, it was intriguing to observe that 40% of respondents did not forget important tasks at all, even though some of them did not make reminders. This suggests that, while making reminders might have a positive impact on reducing forgetfulness, other factors such as individual memory capabilities and coping strategies may also contribute to managing task-related forgetfulness among graduate students. The variation in the perception of colleagues' forgetfulness further highlights the complexity of this issue.

essay: In the enchanting realm of literature, the power of imagination takes the reader on a transformative journey, whisking them away to unknown worlds and compelling them to experience life from various perspectives. The beauty of a well-crafted narrative lies in its ability to captivate the audience and elicit a plethora of emotions, allowing them to empathize with the characters, while simultaneously broadening their understanding of the human experience. For instance, in Harper Lee's seminal work, "To Kill a Mockingbird," the author skillfully employs vivid imagery and dynamic characters to highlight the complexities of race, social class, and morality in the Deep South during the Great Depression. Through the eyes of the young protagonist, Scout Finch, readers are confronted with the harsh realities of prejudice, ultimately encouraging them to question their own beliefs and examine the impact of societal expectations on individual identity.

essay: Cellular respiration is a fundamental process in which cells convert the energy stored in glucose molecules into adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary molecule responsible for powering cellular activities. This process occurs in three stages: glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, and the electron transport chain. Glycolysis takes place in the cell's cytoplasm and breaks glucose down into two molecules of pyruvate, releasing energy in the form of ATP and reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH). The citric acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, occurs in the mitochondria and generates additional ATP, NADH, and another electron carrier called flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2). Finally, the electron transport chain uses the electrons from NADH and FADH2 to generate a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, which drives the synthesis of the majority of a cell's ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.

Hi today I learned about modal verbs

Modal verbs : ex) may, might, could 

Modals are different from regular verbs
Do not have subject-verb agreement
Do not take the infinitive ‚Äúto‚Äù before the next verb
Some change their meaning in the negative form

Example)
The drop in pressure was due to a crack in the pipe : Fact
The drop in pressure may have have been due to a crack in the pipe : Possible
THe drop in pressure must have been due to a crack in the pipe : There is no sufficient evidence to prove it. 

Modal verb usage
Ability/Capability ‚Üí can , could(+have)
Possibility/Options ‚Üí may, might, could, can (+have - except can)
Probability/Belief/Expectation ‚Üí should, ought to (+have)
Virtual certainty ‚Üí must, have to , cannot (+have)
Advice/Opinion ‚Üí should, ought to (+have)
Necessity/Obligation ‚Üí must, need to, have to

2. Possibility/ options

Present simple : MAY / MIGHT / COULD / CAN
Present simple negative : MAY NOT / MIGHT NOT (but not COULD NOT or CANNOT)
Past simple : MAY HAVE / MIGHT HAVE / COULD HAVE (nut not CAN HAVE)
Past simple negative: MAY NOT HAVE / MIGHT NOT HAVE (but not COULD NOT HAVE or CANNOT HAVE)

Modal Verbs
Don‚Äôt follow standard grammar rules
Convey nuances of meaning
Have more than one meaning

Difference between ‚ÄúCan not‚Äù and ‚ÄúCannot‚Äù
Can not(= Possibly not = may/might not) vs Cannot(=impossible)

Ex)
This can not only damage the sample, it may even destroy it completely.
We realize that this cannot be due to a change in pressure.

3. Probability/ Belief / Expectation
Present simple : SHOULD / OUGHT TO
Present simple negative : SHOULD NOT / OUGHT NOT TO
Past simple : SHOULD HAVE / OUGHT TO HAVE
Past simple negative: SHOULD NOT HAVE / OUGHT NOT TO / HAVE

4. Virtual certainty
Present simple : MUST / HAVE TO
Present simple negative : CANNOT
Past simple : MUST HAVE
Past simple negative: CANNOT HAVE / COULD NOT / COULD NOT HAVE

Modal Verb Usage: ability/Capability, Possibility/Options, Probability/Belief/Expectation, Virtual certainty, Advice/Opinion, Necessity/Obligation
 
Modals are different from regular verbs
-       Do not have subject-verb agreement
-       Do not take the infinitive ‚Äòto‚Äô before the next verb ex)I can do it
-       Some change their meaning in the negative form
Ex) The drop in pressure was due to a crack in the pipe
The drop in pressure may have been due to a crack in the pipe.
The drop in pressure must have been due to a crack in the pipe.
 
Modal Verbs: Do not follow standard grammar rules, Convey nuances of meaning, Have more than one meaning
 
1.     Ability/capability: can/cannot/could, could have/could not/could not have
2.     Possibility/options: may, might,. Could, can/may not, might not(but not could not cannot), may have, might have, could have(but not can have)/ may not have, might not have(but not could not have or cannot have)
 
Cannot vs. can not
-       Can not = Possibly not(may/might not): This can not only damage the sample, it may even destroy it completely.
-       Cannot = Impossible: We realized that this cannot be due to a change in pressure.
3.     Probability/belief/Expectation: should, ought to/should not, ought not to/should have. Out to have/should not have, ought not to have
4.     Virtual certainty: must, have to/cannot/must have/cannot have, could not, could not have
5.     Advice/Opinion: should, ought to/ should not, ought not to/ should have, ought to have/should not have, ought not to have
6.     Necessity/Obligation: must, need to, have to/need not, do not need to, do not have to/needed to, had to/did not need to, did not have to, need not have 

Now, it's question
Choose inappropriately paraphrased sentences of the following: "We felt sure the damage was caused by heat exposure."

a. The damage cannot have been caused by heat exposure.
b. The damage could have been caused by heat exposure.
c. The damage should not have been caused by heat exposure.
d. The damage must have been caused by heat exposure.

Present simple negative : SHOULD NOT / OUGHT NOT TO
Past simple : SHOULD HAVE / OUGHT TO HAVE
Past simple negative: SHOULD NOT HAVE / OUGHT NOT TO / HAVE

4. Virtual certainty
Present simple : MUST / HAVE TO
Present simple negative : CANNOT
Past simple : MUST HAVE
Past simple negative: CANNOT HAVE / COULD NOT / COULD NOT HAVE

Modal Verb Usage: ability/Capability, Possibility/Options, Probability/Belief/Expectation, Virtual certainty, Advice/Opinion, Necessity/Obligation
 
Modals are different from regular verbs
-       Do not have subject-verb agreement
-       Do not take the infinitive ‚Äòto‚Äô before the next verb ex)I can do it
-       Some change their meaning in the negative form
Ex) The drop in pressure was due to a crack in the pipe
The drop in pressure may have been due to a crack in the pipe.
The drop in pressure must have been due to a crack in the pipe.
 
Modal Verbs: Do not follow standard grammar rules, Convey nuances of meaning, Have more than one meaning
 
1.     Ability/capability: can/cannot/could, could have/could not/could not have
2.     Possibility/options: may, might,. Could, can/may not, might not(but not could not cannot), may have, might have, could have(but not can have)/ may not have, might not have(but not could not have or cannot have)
 
Cannot vs. can not
-       Can not = Possibly not(may/might not): This can not only damage the sample, it may even destroy it completely.
-       Cannot = Impossible: We realized that this cannot be due to a change in pressure.
3.     Probability/belief/Expectation: should, ought to/should not, ought not to/should have. Out to have/should not have, ought not to have
4.     Virtual certainty: must, have to/cannot/must have/cannot have, could not, could not have
5.     Advice/Opinion: should, ought to/ should not, ought not to/ should have, ought to have/should not have, ought not to have
6.     Necessity/Obligation: must, need to, have to/need not, do not need to, do not have to/needed to, had to/did not need to, did not have to, need not have

<sent>As mentioned before, the aim of this work is to create an automated defect diagnosis AI that accurately detects the location of defects in 3D Printed CFRP composites by depth and presents the size of the defect quantitatively. In our study, we manufactured a 3D Printed CFRP composite control surface and acquired UWPI data through laser ultrasonic testing. In addition, robust normal and defect data of the specimen were acquired and labeled through X-ray Micro-CT and image processing techniques. DECNN was devised and designed to learn the labeled data, and GAN was designed to solve the data imbalance problem. In this section, we present the analysis of signals with different sizes and features at different depths, the results of DECNN training, and the visualization of the defect detection diagnosed by the AI with specific figures. Perform 5-Fold Cross Validation with validation data not used for training and calculate the network's performance metric values. To demonstrate the effectiveness of data augmentation, we compare the performance metrics of the network before and after data augmentation. With the finalized DECNN model, we visualize the defects on the validation control surfaces in 3D to provide quantitative information on the location and size of the defects.</sent>

 Is there anything I can fix in that post?

- The transition from "robust normal and defect data" to "DECNN" is a bit abrupt. You could clarify the connection between these by adding a sentence like: "This labeled data was used to train a deep learning model, specifically a novel type of convolutional neural network called the DECNN."
- In the second-to-last sentence, you could specify what types of defects were detected: "With the finalized DECNN model, we visualize surface defects on the validation control surfaces in 3D to provide quantitative information on the location and size of the detected defects."

Overall, great job summarizing your study!

prev_essay:
A InGaAs MFS capacitor was fabricated using atomic layer deposition (ALD) machine, e-beam evaporator, and rapid thermal annealing (RTA) machine. Then, ferroelectricity of the capacitor was demonstrated both electrically and chemically. Electrical properties as polarization, capacitance, and endurance of the capacitor were measured using parameter analyzer to show ferroelectricity as in other works [1-3]. Also, ferroelectricity additionally demonstrated using X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and scanning TEM (STEM) analysis.
InGaAs MFS capacitor was fabricated as in Fig. 2(a). First, 500 nm-thick InGaAs layer was epitaxially grown on InP substrate. Then, this III-V wafer was cleansed in a sonicator, using acetone, methanol, and, deionized water subsequently for 5 minutes each. After the removal of native oxide of the InGaAs layer in buffered oxide etch for 10 seconds, the sample was promptly transferred to the CN1 atomic layer deposition (ALD) machine for hafnium-zirconium-oxide (HZO) film growth. 10 nm-thick HZO film was deposited on the InGaAs layer by thermal ALD at 270 ¬∞C with Hf : Zr = 1:1 cycle ratio and H2O as oxygen source. Then, a 65 nm-thick molybdenum top electrode was formed by e-beam evaporation. The MFS capacitor was then annealed in RTA with various temperatures in 280 ¬∞C ~ 630 ¬∞C range in 1 mTorr N2 ambient for 1 minute for HZO crystallization. The temperature precision of RTA was calibrated using Al-Si eutectic point to ensure accurate temperature as in other works [4].
All electrical properties of MFS capacitors were measured after 10k electric field cycling with bias voltage of -3V to 3V range. To measure polarization of MFS capacitor, 1 kHz positive-up-negative-down (PUND) measurement with using Keithley 4200A-SCS parameter analyzer to guarantee accurate polarization without dielectric component [5]. Also, the capacitance-voltage characteristic was measured using Keysight 1500A parameter analyzer with frequency range of 10kHz with 30mV oscillation to show defect density of ferroelectric film.
X-ray diffraction analysis for each annealing temperature was conducted for phase analysis of the pristine state, as it is indirect analysis without physically damaging the film. Different phases of HZO film were obtained using RIGAKU high resolution thin-film X-ray diffractometer, with incidence X-ray angle range of 24 ¬∞ ~ 65 ¬∞.
 HR-TEM and HR-STEM images were obtained to analyze phase transition after electric-field cycling engineering, as it is the only method to inspect phase of ferroelectric film directly [6]. The images were obtained using JEOL JEM-ARM200F Cs-corrected FE-TEM after sample preparation with Thermo Fisher Scientific Helios 5 UX focused ion beam

A InGaAs MFS capacitor was fabricated using atomic layer deposition (ALD) machine, e-beam evaporator, and rapid thermal annealing (RTA) machine. Then, ferroelectricity of the capacitor was demonstrated both electrically and chemically. Electrical properties as polarization, capacitance, and endurance of the capacitor were measured using parameter analyzer to show ferroelectricity as in other works [1-3]. Also, ferroelectricity additionally demonstrated using X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and scanning TEM (STEM) analysis.
InGaAs MFS capacitor was fabricated as in Fig. 2(a). First, 500 nm-thick InGaAs layer was epitaxially grown on InP substrate. Then, this III-V wafer was cleansed in a sonicator, using acetone, methanol, and, deionized water subsequently for 5 minutes each. After the removal of native oxide of the InGaAs layer in buffered oxide etch for 10 seconds, the sample was promptly transferred to the CN1 atomic layer deposition (ALD) machine for hafnium-zirconium-oxide (HZO) film growth. 10 nm-thick HZO film was deposited on the InGaAs layer by thermal ALD at 270 ¬∞C with Hf : Zr = 1:1 cycle ratio and H2O as oxygen source. Then, a 65 nm-thick molybdenum top electrode was formed by e-beam evaporation. The MFS capacitor was then annealed in RTA with various temperatures in 280 ¬∞C ~ 630 ¬∞C range in 1 mTorr N2 ambient for 1 minute for HZO crystallization. The temperature precision of RTA was calibrated using Al-Si eutectic point to ensure accurate temperature as in other works [4].
All electrical properties of MFS capacitors were measured after 10k electric field cycling with bias voltage of -3V to 3V range. To measure polarization of MFS capacitor, 1 kHz positive-up-negative-down (PUND) measurement with using Keithley 4200A-SCS parameter analyzer to guarantee accurate polarization without dielectric component [5]. Also, the capacitance-voltage characteristic was measured using Keysight 1500A parameter analyzer with frequency range of 10kHz with 30mV oscillation to show defect density of ferroelectric film.
X-ray diffraction analysis for each annealing temperature was conducted for phase analysis of the pristine state, as it is indirect analysis without physically damaging the film. Different phases of HZO film were obtained using RIGAKU high resolution thin-film X-ray diffractometer, with incidence X-ray angle range of 24 ¬∞ ~ 65 ¬∞.
 HR-TEM and HR-STEM images were obtained to analyze phase transition after electric-field cycling engineering, as it is the only method to inspect phase of ferroelectric film directly [6]. The images were obtained using JEOL JEM-ARM200F Cs-corrected FE-TEM after sample preparation with Thermo Fisher Scientific Helios 5 UX focused ion beam

In that case, you could modify the organization of the methods section as follows:

1. Constraints of VSR tasks: Start by outlining the specific constraints that VSR tasks present in terms of input data, resolution, frame rates, or processing speed.

2. Evolution of Vision Transformer: Discuss the different ways in which Vision Transformer architectures have been adapted or evolved to meet the specific challenges of VSR tasks. This could include modifications made to the original architecture, techniques to improve efficiencies, tailored attention mechanisms, among others.

3. Training strategies: In this section, you can describe how the models were trained, the batch sizes, different settings of learning rate and regularization, and other optimization strategies used to obtain good performance on VSR tasks.

4. Evaluation metrics: Describe the evaluation metrics used to measure the performance of the models, such as PSNR, SSIM, and others that are commonly used in VSR tasks. Explain what they measure and how to interpret them.

5. Comparative analysis: Finally, compare and contrast the different methods that you have identified in your survey. Analyze trends and provide insight into which approaches work best for different types of VSR tasks.

Remember that this is just one possible way to organize the methods section of your survey paper. You will need to ensure that the organization of the section makes sense for the specific studies you have analyzed and the questions you are trying to answer. I hope this helps!

Thank you, but I was asking about citing the overall list itself, as the individual papers will be referenced separately down the line.

What could I do in this case?
chatgpt_after:
I see what you mean now. To cite the accepted papers list of a conference, you would need to follow the citation style guidelines of the conference itself. 

In general, the accepted papers list of a conference can be cited like any other online document. You can use the following format to cite the accepted papers list:

- In-text citation: If you are referencing the list in the body of your paper, you can include a parenthetical citation with the name of the conference and the year of the proceedings. For example: (CVPR 2021 Accepted Papers).

- Reference list: At the end of your paper, you can include a reference to the conference proceedings. This would typically include information about the publisher, volume number, and location of the proceedings, as well as the specific page range for the list of accepted papers. The format of the reference will depend on the citation style you are using. For example, in APA format, you could cite the proceedings like this:

IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition. (2021). CVPR 2021 Accepted Papers. Retrieved from https://openaccess.thecvf.com/menu.php

For other citation styles, such as MLA or Chicago, you would need to check the specific guidelines for citing online documents or websites.

I hope this helps!

prev_essay:
Summarizing the above listed papers, we arrive at the following conclusions.

Transformers are indeed effective, albeit computationally heavy, at performing video super-resolution (VSR). Earlier works such as VSR-T [1] merely employed transformer blocks while retaining the same overall framework as existing convolutional or recurrent networks, and many design elements such as elaborate alignment modules also carried over from recurrent models to those early transformer-based models. Later works have since challenged that foundation, such as attempting to remove or greatly simplify the alignment mechanism between different frames,[2] or formulating radical redesigns to self-attention mechanisms.[3] These works serve to optimize transformer designs to suit the characteristics of vsr tasks specifically, where information from multiple distant frames as well as many different regions from the same frame needs to be aggregated for accurate and smooth reconstruction.

Although various model architectures have been tested, no particular transformer design appears to have won out over others, and emerging papers continue to propose wildly varying architectures. This suggests that there is still much room for experimentations on vsr transformer design.

Research on generalization capabilities and overfitting issues of vsr transformer models seems yet to have received the same level of attention as transformers being used for other tasks. Transformer models have a tendency to require much larger training datasets compared to convolutional or recurrent models, and even then they struggle to generalize to forms of degradation or data domains that were not seen during training. [4] As blind super-resolution [5] - the task to reconstruct low-resolution inputs that have been downsampled by arbitrary degradation mechanisms - is a very active field of research for single-image super-resolution, such generalization capability issues need to be tackled down the road.

VSR transformers have evolved to handle large numbers of video frames and aggregate large amounts of information over long spatial and temporal ranges. Design elements that enabled this can also be adapted for other video tasks, such as deblurring, optical flow estimation, or video frame interpolation. However, many design elements will need to be greatly altered to accommodate for their respective target tasks‚Äô own specific needs, like vsr transformers evolved to accommodate for vsr specific characteristics.

user:
Can you evaluate the following Materials and Methods subsection? Is it apparent for what purpose this test was performed? Why or why not? Suggest ways to re-write the passage.

<para>Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST)
Participants sorted cards according to color, shape, or number stimuli depicted on the card. Sorting the cards by color was initially verbally reinforced. After a participant responded correctly for 10 consecutive cards in that color category, the participant continued sorting by form and numbers without verbal stimuli or reinforcement. Subsequently, the ratio of correct responses to errors was computed, and the numbers of trials, errors, perseverative responses, and perseverative errors were analyzed. In the WCST (Berg, 1948), test subjects have to correctly identify, implement, and remember sorting rules.</para>
chatgpt_after:
Yes, overall, it is apparent from the passage that the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test was performed in order to measure participants' abilities to identify, implement, and remember sorting rules. However, the passage could be written more clearly, and some more information could be added to provide greater detail on the study methods.

Here's one possible way to re-write the passage with these changes:

<para>The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) was administered to each participant. During the testing, participants were presented with cards featuring stimuli in the form of colors, shapes, or numbers, and were asked to categorize the cards accordingly. Initially, participants were instructed to sort the cards by color, and were verbally reinforced for each correct response. Once the participant had correctly sorted 10 cards in a row by color, the verbal reinforcement was removed, and participants needed to continue sorting by form and numbers without any verbal feedback. The ratio of correct responses to errors was then computed, and the numbers of trials, errors, perseverative responses, and perseverative errors were recorded and analyzed. The purpose of the WCST, as described by Berg (1948), is to assess individuals' cognitive flexibility and ability to modify behavior in response to changing environmental cues.</para>

user: I have learned it but can you explain it to me one more time?
chatgpt_after: Sure, let me explain it to you. Relative pronouns 'who' and 'whom' are used to refer to people. However, 'who' is used when it functions as the subject of the sentence, while 'whom' is used when it functions as the object of the sentence. For example, "The girl who sings is my neighbor," where 'who' is the subject of the sentence, and "The girl whom my brother invited to the party will sing," where 'whom' is the object of the phrase 'my brother invited to the party.'

user: <para>One of the ways to learn causalities hidden in the observed objects is proposed in Visual Commonsense R-CNN (VC R-CNN). VC R-CNN is a visual region encoder and is trained to predict the contextual objects of a region like word2vec. However, unlike word2vec which uses conventional likelihood to make predictions, VC R-CNN makes predictions by causal intervention. In order to realize imaginative intervention which is called do-operation, the authors construct a confounder dictionary using pre-trained Faster R-CNN. Each entry is the averaged RoI feature of each category. However, according to our study, the averaged RoI features no more retain information about the corresponding class. This is problematic since each entry of confounder dictionary is assumed to represent corresponding class category when intervening. Class information of the RoI features seems to be lost when these features are averaged.</para>
chatgpt_after:
Here's a revised version of your paragraph:

A proposed method for uncovering causal relationships hidden within observed objects is Visual Commonsense R-CNN (VC R-CNN). This technique is a visual region encoder that's trained to predict the contextual objects of a region, similar to word2vec. However, unlike traditional likelihood-based prediction methods, VC R-CNN uses causal intervention for its predictions. To accomplish this, the authors create a confounder dictionary using a pre-trained Faster R-CNN. Each entry in the dictionary is represented by the averaged RoI feature of each category. However, recent findings suggest that the averaged RoI features no longer retain information about their corresponding class. This presents a major issue since each entry in the confounder dictionary is expected to represent a specific class category when intervening. It seems that class information associated with RoI features may be lost when the features are averaged.
prev_essay: Many vision-language tasks such as Visual Question Answering and Image Captioning use bottom-up features extracted by Faster R-CNN as a visual input. Bottom-up features enable models to focus on at the level of objects and other salient regions. However, it has been shown that these features lack common sense knowledge which is crucial for deeper understanding of images. Common sense knowledge implies unsupervised learning of causal relationships hidden within observed objects. Due to this lack of common sense knowledge, models may fail to accurately describe visual relationships or make predictions based on incorrect visual attention.

Common sense knowledge implies unsupervised learning of causal relationships hidden within observed objects. Due to this lack of common sense knowledge, models may fail to accurately describe visual relationships or make predictions based on incorrect visual attention.

However, "cannot" means impossible.

In scientific writing, the discussion section is essential because it provides an interpretation of your study results and their significance in the context of the scientific field. As for the use of modal verbs, it is essential to use them correctly to convey your message more accurately. You are correct that "cannot" means impossible, while "can not" means possible not. This distinction is critical because it affects the meaning of your sentence, and your readers may misinterpret it if you use them incorrectly. Keep up the good work!

user: Today I learned how to use active and passive voice. In this part, I have some question. What is abusive nominalization? This concept comes from <Argument for the active voice> part.
chatgpt_after: Great job learning about the active and passive voice! Abusive nominalization is a phenomenon where we turn verbs into nouns unnecessarily, which can make our writing less clear and precise. For example, instead of saying "the team collaborated," someone might write "the collaboration of the team." The latter example is an abusive nominalization because it needlessly turns the verb "collaborated" into the noun "collaboration". Is that helpful?

<essay>In order to use intermediate representation, two questions need to be answered: how to use it with feature output extracted from the backbone and how much it involves training the classifier. The following subsections describe two auxiliary branches that address the above requirements.

2.1 Representation Summarization (RS)
Vision models learn to summarize input into a dense representation with downsampling operation. More specifically, linearly embedded token [24] or feature map [18, 14] shrinks with downsampling operation as channel size C increases. In order for the intermediate representation to be dense and informative enough, we adapt the perspective from Hu et al. [15], which views a feature map as a collective of local descriptors whose summarized statistics express input. Thus, the Representation Summarization (RS) module is composed of 2d pooling to reduce channel-wise statistics and MLP to learn inter-dependencies between channels. The representation transformed by the MLP layer is activated by sigmoid throughout all experiments, but any other activation function can be applied. The transformed representation is denoted by zÀÜl = MLP(Pool2d(zl)). (2) Note. For patch representation in works such as [24], the spatial dimension is already mixed in the patch merging step. Therefore, we directly flatten the representation and apply pooling 1d. zÀÜl = Pool1d(z ‚Ä≤ l )) (3) where z ‚Ä≤ l denotes flattened zl .

2.2 Representation Mixup (RM)
Previous works either use representation extracted from Yim et al. [36] or use weights from layers of pre-trained models by simple averaging [34] or partial selection algorithm [10]. Along the line of this belief, intermediate representation can act as hints for capturing hard false negative samples with simple aggregation methods such as weighted sum or concatenation. The most straightforward method is to mix them in proper portion. We are inspired by several works on data augmentation using interpolation for mixing up in input space or feature space for better representation learning [39, 31]. An interpolation of hidden representations zi , zk with respect to zi is expressed as z ‚Ä≤ = zi + Œ±(zk ‚àí zi) (4) where Œ± denotes the scaling factor.

Given pre-trained backbone f, newly initialized linear classifier g, and input image x, the final output score s is s = g ‚ó¶ f(x). The final output representation from the pre-trained backbone is f(x) = zL. The pre-trained backbone can be expressed as two parts f(x) = f2 ‚ó¶ f1(x) and intermediate representation h can be retrieved while passing partial backbone f1. The final representation z ‚Ä≤ L passed to classifier g can be retrieved as follows: h = f1(x), hÀÜ = RS(h) ‚àà R N , z‚Ä≤ L = hÀÜ ¬∑ Œ± + f2(h) ¬∑ (1 ‚àí Œ±) (5) . This means we mixup two elements: intermediate representation and final representation. 

In this paper, following the recent works, we design a learninable parameter Œ± by summarizing the hidden representation into a single value between 0 and 1 as Œ± = œÉ(W ¬∑ zL + b). (6) While previous mixup-based works [41, 13] use a beta distribution for Œ±, here we use an auxiliary linear layer to learn the level of mix in an instance-wise manner.</essay>

2.1 Representation Summarization (RS)

More specifically, linearly embedded token [24] or feature map [18, 14] shrinks with downsampling operation as channel size C increases. In order for the intermediate representation to be dense and informative enough, we adapt the perspective from Hu et al. [15], which views a feature map as a collective of local descriptors whose summarized statistics express input. Thus, the Representation Summarization (RS) module is composed of 2d pooling to reduce channel-wise statistics and MLP to learn inter-dependencies between channels. The representation transformed by the MLP layer is activated by sigmoid throughout all experiments, but any other activation function can be applied. The transformed representation is denoted by zÀÜl = MLP(Pool2d(zl)). (2) Note. For patch representation in works such as [24], the spatial dimension is already mixed in the patch merging step. Therefore, we directly flatten the representation and apply pooling 1d. zÀÜl = Pool1d(z ‚Ä≤ l )) (3) where z ‚Ä≤ l denotes flattened zl .

2.2 Representation Mixup (RM)
Previous works either use representation extracted from Yim et al. [36] or use weights from layers of pre-trained models by simple averaging [34] or partial selection algorithm [10]. Along the line of this belief, intermediate representation can act as hints for capturing hard false negative samples with simple aggregation methods such as weighted sum or concatenation. The most straightforward method is to mix them in proper portion. We are inspired by several works on data augmentation using interpolation for mixing up in input space or feature space for better representation learning [39, 31]. An interpolation of hidden representations zi , zk with respect to zi is expressed as z ‚Ä≤ = zi + Œ±(zk ‚àí zi) (4) where Œ± denotes the scaling factor.

Given pre-trained backbone f, newly initialized linear classifier g, and input image x, the final output score s is s = g ‚ó¶ f(x). The final output representation from the pre-trained backbone is f(x) = zL. The pre-trained backbone can be expressed as two parts f(x) = f2 ‚ó¶ f1(x) and intermediate representation h can be retrieved while passing partial backbone f1. The final representation z ‚Ä≤ L passed to classifier g can be retrieved as follows: h = f1(x), hÀÜ = RS(h) ‚àà R ^N , z‚Ä≤ L = hÀÜ ¬∑ Œ± + f2(h) ¬∑ (1 ‚àí Œ±) (5) . In this paper, following the recent works, we design a learninable parameter Œ± by summarizing the hidden representation into a single value between 0 and 1 as Œ± = œÉ(W ¬∑ zL + b)  where œÉ is sigmoid to clamp the value between 0 and 1 . user: <para>Transfer Learning (TL) is a promising technique to improve the performance of a target task by transferring the knowledge of models trained on relevant source datasets. With the advent of advanced depth models, various methods of exploiting pre-trained depth models at a large scale have come into the limelight. However, for multi-label classification tasks, TL approaches suffer from performance degradation in correctly predicting multiple objects in an image with significant size differences. Since such a hard instance contains imperceptible objects, most pre-trained models lose their ability during downsampling. For the hard instance, this paper proposes a simple but effective classifier for multiple predictions by using the hidden representations from the fixed backbone. To this end, we mix the pre-logit with the intermediate representation with a learnable scale. We show that our method is effective as fine-tuning with few additional parameters and is particularly advantageous for hard instances.</para>
chatgpt_after:

- Consider adding a sentence or two at the beginning to provide some context for your study. For example, you could briefly explain why transfer learning is important or what problem you are trying to solve.
- Make sure to define any technical terms or acronyms that may be unfamiliar to readers. For example, you could define what you mean by "depth models" or "multi-label classification tasks."
- Try to simplify some of the language where possible. For example, instead of saying "various methods of exploiting pre-trained depth models at a large scale have come into the limelight," you could say something like "recently, researchers have developed new methods for using pre-trained depth models on a large scale."
- Consider breaking up the paragraph into shorter sentences or adding some subheadings to make it easier to read and follow the structure of your argument.

Overall, though, your abstract draft provides a clear and concise summary of your study and its main findings. Good job!

essay: Transfer Learning (TL) is a promising technique to improve the performance of a target task by transferring the knowledge of models trained on relevant source datasets. With the advent of advanced deep learning models recently, researchers have developed new methods for using pre-trained depth models on a large scale. However, for multi-label classification tasks, TL approaches suffer from performance degradation in correctly predicting multiple objects in an image with significant size differences. Since such a hard instance contains imperceptible objects, most pre-trained models lose their ability during downsampling. For the hard instance, this paper proposes a simple but effective classifier for multiple predictions by using the hidden representations from the fixed backbone. user:
Method

 Porous carbon material derived from carbon dioxide as the reference material for identifying the active site of boron for 2 electron reduction, which is doped with heteroatoms (Boron, Oxygen). As this porous carbon material contains boron and oxygen, which are simultaneously generated when NaBH4 is used as a reducing agent, it would be a suitable reference. To further dope the carbon material with additional oxygen, we used a polymer containing O. The polymer and carbon material were heat-treated together, the polymer would decompose into fragments and oxygen could be doped into the carbon material. To efficiently confirm the effect of oxygen doping, we selected a similar structure polymer without oxygen as the compare group.



1.     Synthesis of carbon materials by converting CO2

 To obtain carbon materials by converting CO2, reducing agent, NaBH4 (Sigma-Aldrich, >99%), was prepared. Placed 2g of NaBH4 in an alumina boat and put in a furnace, raising the temperature to 520¬∞C at a rate of 5¬∞C/min. To prevent the reaction, we flowed inert gas, Ar, at a rate of 55 sccm. When the temperature reached 500¬∞C, replaced Ar with CO2 as a carbon source and maintained the same flow rate of 55 sccm. We maintained the temperature at 500¬∞C for 2 hours for sufficient reaction between CO2 and NaBH4. After waiting for the temperature to cool down, the carbon material was obtained. To remove impurities, washed the obtained carbon material with a 5M HCl solution by stirring at 80¬∞C for 30 minutes and conducting filtration twice. Next, stirred the material in distilled water at 80¬∞C for 30 minutes and filtered it three times. Finally, converted the material to a neutral condition by treating it with an ethanol solution twice. After washing, dried the material at 80¬∞C overnight and obtained the basic carbon material, Boron doped porous carbon (BPC).



2.     Heat treatment of carbon materials with oxygen-containing polymers


 Carbon material obtained from carbon dioxide was modified by conducting thermal treatment with a polymer, polyethylene oxide (PEO, Sigma-Aldrich), which contains oxygen for additional doping. The mixture of the carbon material, BPC, and PEO was prepared in a 1:4 mass ratio (0.1g:0.4g) by mixing with a vortex mixer for 5 minutes to ensure proper mixing. The mixture was then placed in an alumina boat and heated in a furnace with argon gas flowing at a 55sccm and heat rate of 5‚ÑÉ/min up to a temperature of 500¬∞C, which was maintained for 3 hours after reached 500¬∞C. Afterward, the temperature was gradually cooled lowered to room temperature to obtain the material BPC_PEO, which was the result of the thermal treatment of BPC and PEO. The obtained material was subjected to a washing and drying process, which involved placing it in a 5M HCl solution and stirring it for 30 minutes at 80¬∞C, followed by filtration once. Then, the material was stirred in distilled water at 80¬∞C for 30 minutes and filtered twice. Finally, to neutralize the carbon material, the same process was repeated with an ethanol solution once. The washed material was then dried overnight at 80¬∞C and subjected to additional heat treatment to obtain the final carbon material, BPC_PEO.



3.     Heat treatment of carbon materials with non oxygen-containing polymers

 To prepare a comparison group for carbon materials doped with oxygen, a polymer Polyethylene (PE, Sigma-Aldrich) and the basic carbon material BPC with the same structure with PEO but non oxygen polymer were processed together. The process of obtaining the materials including thermal treatment was the same as the previous process. BPC and PE were mixed in a 1:4 ratio (0.1g:0.4g) using a vortex mixer for 5 minutes to ensure proper mixing. The mixture was then placed in an alumina boat and put into a furnace. Argon gas was flowed through the furnace, and the temperature was raised to 500¬∞C at a rate of 5‚ÑÉ/min. When the temperature reached 500¬∞C, it was maintained for 3 hours before being lowered to room temperature to obtain the material BPC_PE, where BPC and PE were co-processed. The obtained material underwent a cleaning process and drying process as follows: it was placed in a 5M HCl solution and stirred at 80 ¬∞C for 30 minutes before being filtered once. Then, it was stirred in distilled water at 80 ¬∞C for 30 minutes and filtered twice. Finally, to neutralize the carbon material, the solution was converted to an ethanol solution and the same process was repeated once. After washing, the material was dried overnight at 80 ¬∞C to obtain the final carbon material, BPC_PE, which was subjected to additional heat treatment.



4.     Electrochemical experiment



The catalytic ability of the materials in producing hydrogen peroxide was measured using Rotating Ring Disk Electrode (RRDE) in a three-electrode cell. Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode, and Pt coil electrode was used as the counter electrode and RRDE electrode. Solution consisting of 1 ml ethanol, 0.1 ml 5 wt% Nafion, and 4 mg catalyst was sonicated for 1 hour to disperse the catalyst well, and then 5 ul was dropped to load the catalyst. The electrode with the solution was rotated at 600 rpm for 30 minutes to dry and fix the catalyst on the electrode. LSV(Linear Sweep Voltammetry) measurements were then conducted underusing KOH 0.1M and Na2SO4 0.1M solutions as an electrolyte at a scan rate of 10 mV/s to test the performance of the catalyst with rotating 1600rpm. The actual current resulting from oxygen reduction was calculated as the difference between measurements taken in an argon-saturated solution initially and an oxygen-saturated solution subsequently.

user: tense is important. but i don't cleary divide when i use past tense and when i use present tense. can you explain about it?
chatgpt_after:
Yes, you are correct that using the right tense is important in the Results and Discussion section. Typically, the Results section is written using the past tense because it describes what you found during your study. On the other hand, the Discussion section is usually written in the present tense because it is where you interpret and explain the significance of your results, and in a way, your arguments become more alive in the present tense. 

For example, in the Results section, you might write: <sent>"We found that the average length of the male mice tail was 10.3 cm."</sent> while in the Discussion section, you would write something like: <sent>"These results suggest that male mice tails are typically shorter than those of female mice, which is consistent with previous studies."</sent> 

It's important to be consistent in your use of tense throughout the paper, so if you start the Results section using past tense, try to use it consistently throughout that section. And while you can use the present tense in the Discussion section, it should not be overused.

user:
<essay>‚ÄòEfficient High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) Interposer Design with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-Based Eye Diagram Estimation Considering Power Noise‚Äô

Methodology

In this study, we propose an efficient design methodology for high bandwidth memory (HBM) interposer using a generative adversarial network (GAN)-based eye diagram estimation technique. The methodology consists of several steps, including raw data generation, target channel and design parameters set-up, eye diagram simulation set-up, preprocessing of training datasets, determining the number of labels and eye diagram datasets, time series to images transformation methods for input datasets, and building Pix2Pix-based GAN for eye diagram estimation.
The process of raw data generation for GAN model training involves several steps, starting with the design specifications of HBM and the definition of the target channel. The design of the HBM interposer and the set-up of design parameters are then carried out, followed by the electromagnetic (EM) simulation of the HBM interposer, S-parameters, and eye diagram. Data collection is performed for training the GAN model. The target channel and design parameters are set up based on the physical dimension and material properties of the HBM interposer. The design target is defined as a victim of a 5mm strip line with adjacent aggressors, and the target channel is designed by fixing the thickness of all layers as 1 um.
For the eye diagram simulation set-up, the input voltage Vin is set to an amplitude of 0.4V, a data rate of 6.4Gbps, and a rise/fall time of 15.6ps/15.6ps. Equivalent source/load elements are set as TX: 50‚Ñ¶/0.5pF as an equivalent source resistance and load capacitance, and RX: 0.5pF as an equivalent load capacitance, following JEDEC standard JESD238 (HBM3). To evaluate the Power Supply Induced Jitter (PSIJ) in the proposed HBM interposer design, we designed a Power Delivery Network (PDN) to supply power to the HBM interposer. We applied power noise generated by switching multiple drivers simultaneously to the eye diagram simulation. This allowed us to analyze the effects of power noise on signal integrity in the HBM interposer. We examined various factors, such as noise margin, jitter, and eye opening, to investigate the impact of power noise on the design of the interposer. Through this analysis, we were able to identify potential PSIJ issues and propose solutions to mitigate them, thereby improving the overall performance and reliability of the HBM interposer design.
Preprocessing of training datasets involves EM simulation & Transient simulation using HFSS and ADS to extract raw data (csv file) containing labels like width, space, index, time, and density. MATLAB is then used to process raw data, plot eye diagrams, and save image datasets. Python is used to preprocess images, label datasets, create hierarchical data formats file with datasets (HDF5 file), extract datasets, build a GAN network, and train GAN. The number of labels and eye diagram datasets are determined based on the setting of two labels representing width and space, respectively. The minimum and maximum values of the parameters of each label and the step-size determine the total number of datasets. 
Time series to images transformation methods are employed for input datasets. 1-D time series data with high feature complexity due to sequential data can be transformed to enable data analysis through 2-D convolution. Finally, to build a Pix2Pix-based GAN for eye diagram estimation, a dataset containing input images and their corresponding target images is required. Pix2Pix is a supervised learning algorithm that takes an input image and produces an output image in a different style. It has been successfully applied to various image-to-image translation tasks.
In summary, our proposed methodology enables the design and analysis of the entire eye diagram with power noise without conventional time-consuming processes. It also presents a GAN-based eye diagram estimation methodology for fast and optimal design of HBM interposer.</essay>

To evaluate the Power Supply Induced Jitter (PSIJ) in the proposed HBM interposer design, we designed a Power Delivery Network (PDN) to supply power to the HBM interposer. We applied power noise generated by switching multiple drivers simultaneously to the eye diagram simulation. This allowed us to analyze the effects of power noise on signal integrity in the HBM interposer. We examined various factors, such as noise margin, jitter, and eye opening, to investigate the impact of power noise on the design of the interposer. Through this analysis, we were able to identify potential PSIJ issues and propose solutions to mitigate them, thereby improving the overall performance and reliability of the HBM interposer design.
Preprocessing of training datasets involves EM simulation & Transient simulation using HFSS and ADS to extract raw data (csv file) containing labels like width, space, index, time, and density. MATLAB is then used to process raw data, plot eye diagrams, and save image datasets. Python is used to preprocess images, label datasets, create hierarchical data formats file with datasets (HDF5 file), extract datasets, build a GAN network, and train GAN. The number of labels and eye diagram datasets are determined based on the setting of two labels representing width and space, respectively. The minimum and maximum values of the parameters of each label and the step-size determine the total number of datasets. 
Time series to images transformation methods are employed for input datasets. 1-D time series data with high feature complexity due to sequential data can be transformed to enable data analysis through 2-D convolution. Finally, to build a Pix2Pix-based GAN for eye diagram estimation, a dataset containing input images and their corresponding target images is required. Pix2Pix is a supervised learning algorithm that takes an input image and produces an output image in a different style. It has been successfully applied to various image-to-image translation tasks.
In summary, our proposed methodology enables the design and analysis of the entire eye diagram with power noise without conventional time-consuming processes. It also presents a GAN-based eye diagram estimation methodology for fast and optimal design of HBM interposer.

user:
<essay>‚ÄòEfficient High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) Interposer Design with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-Based Eye Diagram Estimation Considering Power Noise‚Äô

Results
The study aims to design an efficient High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) Interposer with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-Based Eye Diagram Estimation, considering power noise. The principles of GAN training were analyzed through the objective function, and the analysis of the training progress of GAN was conducted through discriminator and generator error.

Regarding the principles of GAN training, it was found that binary cross-entropy can be applied to the discriminator in GANs, as the discriminator in GANs is a binary classification problem representing true as 1.0 and false as 0.0. It was also observed that cross-entropy can be greater than 1.0 with logarithmic calculations, providing much greater feedback on the wrong answer. The ideal Binary Cross-Entropy (BCE) loss is 0.693 in situations where the discriminator and generator are balanced.

In the analysis of training progress of GAN, it was noted that according to the mathematical definition of binary cross-entropy, the ideal value of the loss function is ln 2. If the error of the discriminator is less than the ideal value, the discriminator outpaces the generator, and if it is similar to the ideal value, the generator is being trained well. It was found that the error in the discriminator is oscillated in between, indicating that the discriminator and generator compete with each other and learn well.
 
        Figure 1 Error in discriminator according to epoch shows the process of convergence
‚ÄÉ


Figure 2 Error in generator according to epoch ensures that the generator is trained well

As the epoch increases, the generator converges appropriately to produce various and plausible data. It is shown that if the epoch is excessively increased, the learning quality may deteriorate. The results of this study provide valuable insights into the training progress of GAN and eye diagram estimation. These findings can be useful in the design of efficient HBM interposer with GAN-based eye diagram estimation, considering power noise.
 
Figure 3 Eye diagrams generated by GAN by epoch</essay>

essay: The main use of the English present subjunctive, called the mandative or jussive subjunctive, occurs in that clauses (declarative content clauses; the word that is sometimes omitted in informal and conversational usage) expressing a circumstance which is desired, demanded, recommended, necessary, or similar. Such a clause may be dependent on verbs like insist, suggest, demand, prefer, adjectives like necessary, desirable, or nouns like recommendation, necessity; it may be part of the expression in order that... (or some formal uses of so that...); it may also stand independently as the subject of a clause or as a predicative expression.

During doing exercises, I got question.
<sent>'No way was the damage caused by heat exposure.' sentence was changed into 'The damage cannot have been/ could not have been caused by heat exposure.'</sent>.
I do not perfectly understand the usage of 'can'.
chatgpt_after: Yes, we did cover modal verbs in today's class, and it's great that you were able to practice using them. According to your question, "No way was the damage caused by heat exposure" can be rewritten using modal verbs as "The damage cannot have been/ could not have been caused by heat exposure." Here, "can" is used to express a possibility or a high degree of likelihood that the damage was not caused by heat exposure. It indicates that the speaker has a strong belief or conviction in the statement. In scientific writing, it is important to use modal verbs correctly to express the level of certainty or possibility of the research findings or statements made.

user: Is there any difference between can and could?
chatgpt_after: Yes, there is a difference between "can" and "could" in the usage of modal verbs. "Can" is used to express a strong possibility, ability, or likelihood of an event happening or statement being true in the present or future. On the other hand, "could" is used to express a possibility or ability that happened or existed in the past or hypothetical situations in the present or future. For example, "I can write a good research paper" means that I have the ability to do so now or in the future, while "I could write a good research paper" means that I had the ability to write one in the past or if certain conditions are met in the present or future. In scientific writing, "can" and "could" are used to express different degrees of probability and to clarify the level of certainty of research findings or statements.
