prev_essay:
Based on the formative study, we implemented a novel system, CreativeConnect, that helps designers to enhance their ideation process by effectively utilizing references. Designers can freely add, resize, move, and delete references for their design projects on the system. Users can also group references based on their specific goals. Then, the system provides three key features: (1) feature extraction, (2) feature integration, and (3) visualization.
The first feature is feature extraction, where the system extracts design-related features from the references. The system can extract layout, semantic objects, color schemes, and typography. To extract the layout and semantic objects from the reference, we used semantic segmentation model called IBM MAX-Object-Detector. Based on the segmented result, we trained Transformer-based model to get the hierarchical relationship between the objects and detect the layout. Python module called extcolors was used to extract the color scheme from the image, and font recognition open source code called DeepFont is used for font style extraction. These extracted features are then merged based on the reference group and displayed on the interface. When the user clicks on a specific reference, the extracted features for that image are displayed. Additionally, for groups of references, the system displays the common features shared by the images in the same group, enabling users to quickly identify the commonality of the group. CreativeConnect includes a search function that allows users to select specific design keywords or concepts and highlight reference images on the board based on those keywords. This function enables users to quickly discover new groups of references that they may not have considered before, expanding their ideation possibilities.
CreativeConnect provides feature integration, a unique feature to support designers in their ideation process. The system suggests novel and valuable connections between different design features extracted from references. Using collaborative filtering technique, the system suggests connections between different design features that are extracted from various references. The model selects the best connections based on the user's preference for the level of serendipity. Higher levels of serendipity lead to more recommendations of connections between unrelated features, and vice versa. Designers can choose to accept or reject the suggestions, and the system will continue to learn and refine its recommendations based on the user's feedback. This feature enables users to break free from their usual patterns and discover new possibilities for their designs.
The visualization feature in CreativeConnect allows designers to test and visualize the connections they select from the previous step, feature integration. Users can choose the design features they want to combine and view a real-time visual representation of the proposed combination. The system generates a new reference image that displays the merged features using DallE-2, the text2image generative models, and this can be added to the board as a new reference. This helps users to evaluate how the different features interact and determine whether the proposed design aligns with their vision. This visualization feature supports an iterative design process by enabling users to quickly test and refine their ideas until they achieve the desired outcome.

Users can choose the design features they want to combine and view a real-time visual representation of the proposed combination. The system generates a new reference image that displays the merged features using DallE-2, a text2image generative model. Designers can then add the new reference image to the board if they wish. This helps users to evaluate how the different features interact and determine whether the proposed design aligns with their vision. This visualization feature supports an iterative design process by enabling users to quickly test and refine their ideas until they achieve the desired outcome.

As for repetitive information, you mention "expanding their ideation possibilities" at the end of Paragraph 4 and then again in the first sentence of Paragraph 5. One possible way to avoid repetition would be to combine the two sentences into one, for example: "CreativeConnect includes a search function that allows users to discover new groups of references and expand their ideation possibilities. Users can select specific design keywords or concepts and highlight reference images on the board based on those keywords."</para>
prev_essay:
Based on the formative study, we implemented a novel system, CreativeConnect, that helps designers to enhance their ideation process by effectively utilizing references. Designers can freely add, resize, move, and delete references for their design projects on the system. Users can also group references based on their specific goals. Then, the system provides three key features: (1) feature extraction, (2) feature integration, and (3) visualization.
The first feature is feature extraction, where the system extracts design-related features from the references. The system can extract layout, semantic objects, color schemes, and typography. To extract the layout and semantic objects from the reference, we used semantic segmentation model called IBM MAX-Object-Detector. Based on the segmented result, we trained Transformer-based model to get the hierarchical relationship between the objects and detect the layout. Python module called extcolors was used to extract the color scheme from the image, and font recognition open source code called DeepFont is used for font style extraction. These extracted features are then merged based on the reference group and displayed on the interface. When the user clicks on a specific reference, the extracted features for that image are displayed. Additionally, for groups of references, the system displays the common features shared by the images in the same group, enabling users to quickly identify the commonality of the group. CreativeConnect includes a search function that allows users to select specific design keywords or concepts and highlight reference images on the board based on those keywords. This function enables users to quickly discover new groups of references that they may not have considered before, expanding their ideation possibilities.
CreativeConnect provides feature integration, a unique feature to support designers in their ideation process. The system suggests novel and valuable connections between different design features extracted from references. Using collaborative filtering technique, the system suggests connections between different design features that are extracted from various references. The model selects the best connections based on the user's preference for the level of serendipity. Higher levels of serendipity lead to more recommendations of connections between unrelated features, and vice versa. Designers can choose to accept or reject the suggestions, and the system will continue to learn and refine its recommendations based on the user's feedback. This feature enables users to break free from their usual patterns and discover new possibilities for their designs.
The visualization feature in CreativeConnect allows designers to test and visualize the connections they select from the previous step, feature integration. Users can choose the design features they want to combine and view a real-time visual representation of the proposed combination. The system generates a new reference image that displays the merged features using DallE-2, the text2image generative models, and this can be added to the board as a new reference. This helps users to evaluate how the different features interact and determine whether the proposed design aligns with their vision. This visualization feature supports an iterative design process by enabling users to quickly test and refine their ideas until they achieve the desired outcome.

prev_essay:
By analyzing participants‚Äô think-aloud scripts, we found out that all participants had three primary goals for their ideation: relevant design, aesthetically pleasing design, and novel design. They aimed to create a design that aligned well with the given topic, looked visually appealing, and stood out from existing designs. Based on these three goals, we analyzed how participants accomplish these goals using visual references in three separate ideation stages, which are reference search, idea generation, and narrowing down.
During the reference search stage, we observed various strategies to stimulate novelty and creativity. Two of the six participants intentionally used general search terms to discover diverse results instead of topic-specific keywords. A different participant obtained references from a field unrelated to brand design, specifically interior design. Three participants used generative models in the hopes that the randomness of AI would lead to new ideas. As visual styles are difficult to explain in words, three out of six participants used recommendation functions for styles instead of formulate them as search keywords. They discovered one of the random images with a style they liked, and then proceeded with the further exploration by getting recommended images similar to the original image. After searching for references, all participants categorized them using their own criteria. These criteria were frequently divided into two categories: style-related keywords and topic-related keywords.
In the idea generation stage, participants employed two primary strategies. The first is to extract the commonness from multiple references. Five participants grouped the topic-related references and discover effective ways to convey topics by extracting common objects. For example, P3 said, ‚ÄúLooking at various references related to travel, I discovered that travel hats appeared frequently, and I decided to use this.‚Äù Three participants discovered the specific design elements (e.g., font, color) from the group of references that they liked, and decided to use this for their own design as well. However, this commonness sometimes affects their design in an opposite way. Two of the participants said that they aimed to identify and avoid design styles that were too common. The second strategy was to merge multiple references. Participants divided the topic into keywords, found references for each of them, and merged them together. They changed particular elements from a favorite reference to another element that can highlight the topic more effectively. They also combined references for different design elements, such as typography and color, and applied design elements from other references to a favorite reference.
After generating a range of design concepts, the participants utilized visual references to build prototypes quickly and narrow their choices down. We observed that four participants utilized their references to validate their design concepts by confirming if several references complemented each other and if the design would appear visually appealing after developing this design concept. Additionally, two participants mentioned utilizing references to compare diverse design concepts by taking distinct design elements and implementing them interchangeably.
Based on the interview after the ideation task, we identified various needs when utilizing references in design ideation. In terms of reference search, designers expressed a desire for a search function based on reference groups, rather than recommendations from single references. They also sought a tool to provide references for non-existent or abstract concepts, in addition to a recommendation system for specific design elements, like font, layout, and color. During the idea generation phases, designers desired a tool to automatically extract common design elements from their reference groups, as well as to modify specific parts of references to create new design variations. However, during the narrowing-down phase, we observed a lack of systems to support this aspect of the ideation process. These observations suggest an opportunity for developing computational tools to aid designers in the different stages of ideation.
In summary, this formative study aimed to investigate the strategies employed by designers when using different references together to generate creative ideas. The study found that designers tend to group multiple references according to their own criteria and utilize them as a collective source of inspiration rather than relying on a single reference. During the ideation process, designers extract common elements from their reference groups to guide their design direction, or merge multiple references to create new and creative design ideas. References are used as both a source of direction and stimulus for generating divergent ideas and as a material for making design decisions during the convergent phase. The study also revealed a need for a reference search tool that can provide references for non-existent or abstract concepts, as well as a recommendation system that can provide granular suggestions for different design elements. Finally, it was found that designers currently utilize generative models as reference providers.

user: For example, if my work's limitation is that it only works at the specific domain (graphic design), how can I write my limitation well?
chatgpt_after:
That's a great example! If your work is limited to a specific domain, you can phrase the limitation in a way that acknowledges the contribution of your study while still being honest about its boundaries. 

For example, you could say something along the lines of:

"Although our findings provide valuable insights for graphic design practitioners, it is important to note that our study was conducted within a specific domain and may not be generalizable to other contexts. Future research could examine the applicability and effectiveness of this approach in other domains."

By taking this approach, you have identified the limitation of the study while also emphasizing its contributions and suggesting potential directions for future research.

user: Today I learned about unclear pronoun reference. When you use pronoun such as "it", "this" and "those" in the sentence, that sentence can have ambiguity. So, in that case, you should use expression or precise name rather than pronoun.
chatgpt_after: Yes, that's correct. Using pronouns without a clear antecedent can create confusion for the reader, leading to a lack of clarity and understanding in the sentence. By clarifying the noun that the pronoun refers to, you can make your writing more concise and easier to understand. Additionally, using precise language instead of vague pronouns is one way to make your writing more specific and less open to interpretation. So, it's important to use pronouns carefully and correctly in your scientific writing. Well done on learning about this topic!
essay: Text-to-speech (TTS) systems synthesize raw speech waveforms from given text through several components. With the rapid development of deep neural networks, TTS system pipelines have been simplified to two-stage generative modeling apart from text preprocessing such as text normalization and phonemization. The first stage is to produce intermediate speech representations such as melspectrograms (Shen et al., 2018) or linguistic features (Oord et al., 2016) from the preprocessed text,1 and the second stage is to generate raw waveforms conditioned on the intermediate representations (Oord et al., 2016; Kalchbrenner et al., 2018). Models at each of the two-stage pipelines have been developed independently. Neural network-based autoregressive TTS systems have shown the capability of synthesizing realistic speech (Shen et al., 2018; Li et al., 2019), but their sequential generative process makes it difficult to fully utilize modern parallel processors. To overcome this limitation and improve synthesis speed, several non-autoregressive methods have been proposed. In the text-to-spectrogram generation step, extracting attention maps from pre-trained autoregressive teacher networks (Ren et al., 2019; Peng et al., 2020) is attempted to decrease the difficulty of learning alignments between text and spectrograms. More recently, likelihood-based methods further eliminate the dependency on external aligners by estimating or learning alignments that maximize the likelihood of target mel-spectrograms (Zeng et al., 2020; Miao et al., 2020; Kim et al., 2020). Meanwhile, generative adversarial networks (GANs) (Goodfellow et al., 2014) have been explored in second stage models. GAN-based feed-forward networks with multiple discriminators, each distinguishing samples at different scales or periods, achieve high-quality raw waveform synthesis (Kumar et al., 2019; Bi¬¥nkowski et al., 2019; Kong et al., 2020). Despite the progress of parallel TTS systems, two-stage pipelines remain problematic because they require sequential training or fine-tuning (Shen et al., 2018; Weiss et al., 2020) for high-quality production wherein latter stage models are trained with the generated samples of earlier stage models. In addition, their dependency on predefined intermediate features precludes applying learned hidden representations to obtain further improvements in performance. Recently, several works, i.e., FastSpeech 2s (Ren et al., 2021) and EATS (Donahue et al., 2021), have proposed efficient end-to-end training methods such as training over short audio clips rather than entire waveforms, leveraging a mel-spectrogram decoder to aid text representation learning, and designing a specialized spectrogram loss to relax lengthmismatch between target and generated speech. However, despite potentially improving performance by utilizing the learned representations, their synthesis quality lags behind two-stage systems. In this work, we present a parallel end-to-end TTS method that generates more natural sounding audio than current two-stage models. Using a variational autoencoder (VAE) (Kingma & Welling, 2014), we connect two modules of TTS systems through latent variables to enable efficient end-to-end learning. To improve the expressive power of our method so that high-quality speech waveforms can be synthesized, we apply normalizing flows to our conditional prior distribution and adversarial training on the waveform domain. In addition to generating fine-grained audio, it is important for TTS systems to express the one-to-many relationship in which text input can be spoken in multiple ways with different variations (e.g., pitch and duration). To tackle the one-to-many problem, we also propose a stochastic duration predictor to synthesize speech with diverse rhythms from input text. With the uncertainty modeling over latent variables and the stochastic duration predictor, our method captures speech variations that cannot be represented by text. Our method obtains more natural sounding speech and higher sampling efficiency than the best publicly available TTS system, Glow-TTS (Kim et al., 2020) with HiFiGAN (Kong et al., 2020). We make both our demo page and source-code publicly available.

essay: Text-to-speech (TTS) systems synthesize raw speech waveforms from given text through several components. With the rapid development of deep neural networks, TTS system pipelines have been simplified to two-stage generative modeling apart from text preprocessing such as text normalization and phonemization. The first stage is to produce intermediate speech representations such as melspectrograms (Shen et al., 2018) or linguistic features (Oord et al., 2016) from the preprocessed text,1 and the second stage is to generate raw waveforms conditioned on the intermediate representations (Oord et al., 2016; Kalchbrenner et al., 2018). Models at each of the two-stage pipelines have been developed independently. Neural network-based autoregressive TTS systems have shown the capability of synthesizing realistic speech (Shen et al., 2018; Li et al., 2019), but their sequential generative process makes it difficult to fully utilize modern parallel processors. To overcome this limitation and improve synthesis speed, several non-autoregressive methods have been proposed. In the text-to-spectrogram generation step, extracting attention maps from pre-trained autoregressive teacher networks (Ren et al., 2019; Peng et al., 2020) is attempted to decrease the difficulty of learning alignments between text and spectrograms. More recently, likelihood-based methods further eliminate the dependency on external aligners by estimating or learning alignments that maximize the likelihood of target mel-spectrograms (Zeng et al., 2020; Miao et al., 2020; Kim et al., 2020). Meanwhile, generative adversarial networks (GANs) (Goodfellow et al., 2014) have been explored in second stage models. GAN-based feed-forward networks with multiple discriminators, each distinguishing samples at different scales or periods, achieve high-quality raw waveform synthesis (Kumar et al., 2019; Bi¬¥nkowski et al., 2019; Kong et al., 2020). Despite the progress of parallel TTS systems, two-stage pipelines remain problematic because they require sequential training or fine-tuning (Shen et al., 2018; Weiss et al., 2020) for high-quality production wherein latter stage models are trained with the generated samples of earlier stage models. In addition, their dependency on predefined intermediate features precludes applying learned hidden representations to obtain further improvements in performance. Recently, several works, i.e., FastSpeech 2s (Ren et al., 2021) and EATS (Donahue et al., 2021), have proposed efficient end-to-end training methods such as training over short audio clips rather than entire waveforms, leveraging a mel-spectrogram decoder to aid text representation learning, and designing a specialized spectrogram loss to relax lengthmismatch between target and generated speech. However, despite potentially improving performance by utilizing the learned representations, their synthesis quality lags behind two-stage systems. In this work, we present a parallel end-to-end TTS method that generates more natural sounding audio than current two-stage models. Using a variational autoencoder (VAE) (Kingma & Welling, 2014), we connect two modules of TTS systems through latent variables to enable efficient end-to-end learning. To improve the expressive power of our method so that high-quality speech waveforms can be synthesized, we apply normalizing flows to our conditional prior distribution and adversarial training on the waveform domain. In addition to generating fine-grained audio, it is important for TTS systems to express the one-to-many relationship in which text input can be spoken in multiple ways with different variations (e.g., pitch and duration). To tackle the one-to-many problem, we also propose a stochastic duration predictor to synthesize speech with diverse rhythms from input text. With the uncertainty modeling over latent variables and the stochastic duration predictor, our method captures speech variations that cannot be represented by text. Our method obtains more natural sounding speech and higher sampling efficiency than the best publicly available TTS system, Glow-TTS (Kim et al., 2020) with HiFiGAN (Kong et al., 2020). We make both our demo page and source-code publicly available.

prev_essay:
The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) is a neuropsychological test of set-shifting, which is the capability to show flexibility when exposed to changes in reinforcement. In the WCST (Berg, 1948), test subjects have to correctly identify, implement, and remember sorting rules. The order of the test is as follows. 
 Firstly, participants sorted cards according to color, shape, or number stimuli depicted on the card. Sorting the cards by color was initially verbally reinforced. After a participant responded correctly for 10 consecutive cards in that color category, the participant continued sorting by form and numbers without verbal stimuli or reinforcement. Subsequently, the ratio of correct responses to errors was computed, and the numbers of trials, errors was computed, and the numbers of trials, errors, perseverative responses, and perseverative errors were analyzed.
essay:

 Firstly, participants sorted cards according to color, shape, or number stimuli depicted on the card. Sorting the cards by color was initially verbally reinforced. After a participant responded correctly for 10 consecutive cards in that color category, the participant continued sorting by form and numbers without verbal stimuli or reinforcement. Subsequently, the ratio of correct responses to errors was computed, and the numbers of trials, errors was computed, and the numbers of trials, errors, perseverative responses, and perseverative errors were analyzed.

user: Furthermore, I learned that the purpose, background, experimental approach, results and interpretation of results are needed in the result section. In this situation, how can I make this paragraph better by indicating precisely the 6 things in the previous sentence?
chatgpt_after:
I'm glad you were paying close attention in class! You are correct that a Results section in a scientific paper typically includes purpose, background, experimental approach, results, and interpretation of results. To make the paragraph better, you could consider dividing it into separate sentences or using bullet points to clearly indicate each of these components. Here's an example of a restructured paragraph:

The Results section of a scientific paper should provide the following six components:

- Purpose: Clearly state the purpose of the study, outlining what question or hypothesis the research addresses.
- Background: Provide a brief summary of the key literature in the field, including earlier research that has been done on the topic.
- Experimental approach: Detail the methods used in the study, including information about study design, materials, and data collection.
- Results: Present the primary findings of the study, using tables and figures as needed to demonstrate these clearly.
- Interpretation of results: Analyze the data, discussing the significance of the findings and any relationships or patterns that have been observed.
- Conclusion: Sum up the results and discuss any implications for future research.

By clearly indicating each of these components, you can make the Results section easier to read and follow for your readers. Would you like me to go over any of these components in more detail?
prev_essay:
Data obtained in previous research has already reported the increase in sightings of UFOs prior to earthquakes. According to Kim et al. (2005), the median average of  UFO appearance numbers increased by about 50% before the earthquake occurrence. 
 In our study, our data were collected using the UFO observation model (UOM) mentioned in our methodology section. Modelled results were compared with UFO sightings for 7 days prior to the earthquake, earthquake magnitude, average weekly UFO sightings, and descriptions of UFOs in 5 countries.
 Table 1 shows the UFO sightings within 300 km of the epicenter using UOM.
Kim et al had reported only about the increasing magnitude of earthquakes according to the increased average weekly UFO sightings. However, the modeled data could not predict when an earthquake is likely to occur.
 We added the UFO sightings for 7 days prior to the earthquake and the descriptions of UFOs were also considered. If the number of UFO sightings for 7 days prior to the earthquake increased than average weekly UFO sightings, the earthquake had occurred. Although most UFOs had a light or color, if the UFO did not have a light or color such as in India, the earthquake occurred even though the number of UFO sighting for 7 days prior to the earthquake was similar to the average weekly UFO sightings.
 Magnitude of earthquakes increased as average weekly UFO sightings increased, the exception was the USA which had high-speed. Therefore, the criteria of the description of UFO should be more organized. Nevertheless, these results suggest that our theory to interpret the collected data may provide more affordable information for predicting the time and magnitude of earthquakes.

Data obtained in previous research has already reported the increase in sightings of UFOs prior to earthquakes. According to Kim et al. (2005), the median average of  UFO appearance numbers increased by about 50% before the earthquake occurrence. 
 In our study, our data were collected using the UFO observation model (UOM) mentioned in our methodology section. Modelled results were compared with UFO sightings for 7 days prior to the earthquake, earthquake magnitude, average weekly UFO sightings, and descriptions of UFOs in 5 countries.
 Table 1 shows the UFO sightings within 300 km of the epicenter using UOM.
Kim et al had reported only about the increasing magnitude of earthquakes according to the increased average weekly UFO sightings. However, the modeled data could not predict when an earthquake is likely to occur.
 We added the UFO sightings for 7 days prior to the earthquake and the descriptions of UFOs were also considered. If the number of UFO sightings for 7 days prior to the earthquake increased than average weekly UFO sightings, the earthquake had occurred. Although most UFOs had a light or color, if the UFO did not have a light or color such as in India, the earthquake occurred even though the number of UFO sighting for 7 days prior to the earthquake was similar to the average weekly UFO sightings.
 Magnitude of earthquakes increased as average weekly UFO sightings increased, the exception was the USA which had high-speed. Therefore, the criteria of the description of UFO should be more organized. Nevertheless, these results suggest that our theory to interpret the collected data may provide more affordable information for predicting the time and magnitude of earthquakes.

user: Today I learned about four common problems of the results section: 1) Missing components (purpose of experiment, experimental approach, results, or their interpretation), 2) Inclusion of irrelevant or peripheral information, 3) Excessive experimental details, 4) Inclusion of comparisons, speculations, and conclusions beyond the interpretation of results. How can you revise my draft in terms of removal of the four common problems?
chatgpt_after:
That's a great question. Let me take a look at your draft to see if there are ways we can address these common problems. 

Based on what we discussed in class, here are some suggestions for revising your draft:

1. Make sure all of the essential components of the results section are present, including the purpose of the experiment, the experimental approach, and the results themselves. If any of these are missing, make sure to include them.

2. Remove any irrelevant or peripheral information that doesn't directly relate to your findings. Stick to the main points and avoid going off on tangents.

3. Be sure to include enough details to support your findings, but don't include excessive experimental details that are not relevant or important to your results. If you find yourself providing too much detail, consider which details are essential and which can be shortened or removed.

4. Avoid making comparisons, speculations, or conclusions beyond what the results can support. Stick to what you have found and be clear about what your results do and do not imply.

I hope this helps you revise your draft and avoid these common problems in your results section. Do you have any questions or further concerns I can help you with?
prev_essay:
To explore the forces behind the strong tendency of husbands to decrease their share of housework, and the low tendency to increase their share of housework in the course of marriage, we looked at the finds from the multivariate event-history models. We first explored the role of economic resources in changing couple‚Äôs division of housework in the course of marriage (Table 1). We investigate the impact of the spouse‚Äôs relative economic resources on the likelihood of dividing housework either more equally or less equally in the course of marriage. We find that husbands who work a similar number of hours (Husband = Wife), or lower number of hours (Husband < Wife) than their wives, are less likely to decrease their share in household labor, compared to husbands who work longer hours than their wives (Husband > Wife). Equal earning levels between the spouses also seem to reduce the likelihood for husbands to decrease their share of housework in the course of marriage (model 3b). For couples with an ‚Äúatypical‚Äù female provider earnings ratio (Husband < Wife) the effect is not significant, however. It appears that a winning margin in economic resources does more for the husband than for the wife when housework is redistributed. 
	We also looked at the effects of family formation on the gender division of household tasks to assess how shifts in economic resources play in this context (Table 2). We found a pronounced and significant effect for both directions of change. During the first year after childbirth, fathers seem to be about twice as likely to decrease their contribution to housework. In the same period, fathers‚Äô likelihood to increase their share in housework is reduced by almost 50 percent, compared to childless men. 
	This push towards a more traditional division of housework seems to come to a halt when the youngest child reaches age two. We found no indication, however, that parents readjust back to a more egalitarian division of housework when kids grow older and mothers return to their previous jobs. The time-varying economic indicators (models 2ab and 3ab) do not seem to explain these processes at all. Here, we need to be cautious not to interpret lack of significance in the economic indicators as lack of relevance, especially since the share of parents in the ‚Äúnon-traditional‚Äù resource categories is low. The number of mothers out-earning or working longer hours than their husbands is small in this sample, and the share of continuously working mothers is low.

Based on what we discussed in class, here are some suggestions for revising the three paragraphs you provided:

To explore the gender division of housework in couples and the forces behind the low tendency of husbands to increase their share of housework, we used multivariate event-history models. In our study, we investigated the impact of economic resources on changing the division of housework between couples over the course of marriage. We found that husbands who work similar or lower hours than their wives are less likely to decrease their share in household labor, as compared to husbands who work longer hours than their wives. We also found that equal earning levels between spouses reduce the likelihood of husbands decreasing their share of housework in the course of marriage, while "atypical" female provider earnings ratios have no significant effect. 

To assess shifts in economic resources and how they may affect family formation, we examined how family formation affects the gender division of household tasks. It is important to note that the lack of significance in the time-varying economic indicators does not invalidate their potential relevance. The small share of mothers out-earning or working longer hours than their husbands is a limitation of our study, but should not diminish the possible importance of economic resources in shaping dynamics of housework division between couples. 

Do you have any questions or feedback on these suggestions?

Today, I learned about common problems of the discussion section.

prev_essay:
Our findings indicate that fertilization among sea urchins is intraspecies specific and that surface components of both gametes are involved in the fertilization specificity. Results of intraspecies specific fertilization between different gametes of several different individuals of the species S. purpuratus displayed varying degrees of fertilization success. 

Approximately one third of the examined individuals show significant differences in fertilization. The percent of individual crosses of gametes yielding significantly reduced fertilization specificity corresponds to the previously reported amount of ‚Äúdefective‚Äù gametes encountered during fertilization (5) and egg agglutination experiments (9) However, in  our study, crosses for gametes of an individual that yield significantly reduced fertilization in one cross reached normal levels with other individual of the opposite sex, suggesting that a low fertilization success is not due to immature or defective gametes. 

It seems intuitive that the molecules that mediate sperm-egg interactions may play an important role in speciation since individuals are in separate gene pools if the sperm and egg cannot interact to form a zygote. How these systems evolve so that once common ancestors become reproductively isolate is not so obvious. Geographic isolation is believed to be the principal mechanism of speciation of marine animals (6). However, speciation does not have to be accompanied by major genomic reorganization (5, 7). A few mutations in bindin and its receptor can be sufficient to accomplish reproductive isolation because these proteins are major components of the fertilization mechanism. The hypothesis that bindins and their receptors contain multiple adhesive elements would allow mutations to occur within an individual element of bindin without catastrophic consequences for mutant individuals in the absence of a simultaneous compensating mutation in the receptor. 

In summary, fertilization among sea urchins appears intraspecies specific due to surface components of both gametes. It is conceivable that these surface components contain multiple adhesive elements. Based on our hypothesis, mutations in these elements may result in reproductive isolation and speciation.

prev_essay:
4. Experiment Results
4.1 Algorithm Performance Evaluation
In this study, a Joint-Optimization approach for QoE and confidentiality in Intelligent Drone Edge Computing (JOIDEC) algorithm has been proposed. To evaluate the performance of the algorithm, experiments were conducted under various environmental conditions. The experimental results show a comparable algorithm performance to existing methods that did not consider confidentiality.

Fig. 1 Processed fps at target latency (No result yet)
Fig. 1 illustrates the performance comparison between the proposed approach and existing methods. The X-axis represents the target latency, and the Y-axis represents the processed fps. Consequently, it can be confirmed that the proposed approach achieves a similar performance to existing methods.

4.2 Confidentiality Assurance through Intermediate Result Transmission
In this study, we presented a method to ensure confidentiality through the transmission of intermediate results (IR). This method allows for more efficient confidentiality assurance by transmitting the intermediate results generated at each edge node to the next edge node, rather than transmitting all data at once.

Fig. 2 Intermediate image on each partition point (No result yet)
Fig. 2 shows the impact of the intermediate result transmission method on confidentiality. The X-axis represents the size of the transmitted data, and the Y-axis represents the confidentiality metric. As a result, it can be confirmed that the intermediate result transmission method ensures higher confidentiality compared to the method of transmitting all data at once.

4.3 DNN Partitioning
In this study, we achieved co-optimization of QoE and confidentiality in edge computing environments using DNN partitioning. DNN partitioning allows for the simultaneous improvement of QoE and confidentiality by dividing the entire model into multiple sub-models, which can be independently processed at each edge node.

Fig. 3 Confidentiality at each partition point (No result yet)
Fig. 3 demonstrates the impact of DNN partitioning on QoE and confidentiality. The X-axis represents the number of sub-models, and the Y-axis represents the metrics of QoE and confidentiality, respectively. As a result, it can be confirmed that both QoE and confidentiality are improved as the number of sub-models increases.

4.4 Conclusion
The proposed co-optimization approach for QoE and confidentiality in intelligent drone edge computing (Lyapunov optimization) demonstrated higher performance compared to existing methods that did not consider confidentiality. Additionally, successful co-optimization of QoE and confidentiality was achieved through confidentiality assurance via intermediate result transmission and DNN partitioning. These results demonstrate the need for a new approach considering both QoE and confidentiality in edge computing environments for intelligent drones and provide an essential foundation for future research.

user: Generally, we need to look at the type of noun we are using, whether it is proper noun or common noun.
chatgpt_after: Hmm, I think I may need to clarify what we went over in class. When it comes to article usage in scientific writing, it's less about whether a noun is proper or common and more about whether it's specific or general. Specifically, when we use "a" or "an," we're indicating that the noun we're referring to is indefinite or general, while when we use "the," we're indicating that the noun is definite or specific. So, for example, if we were discussing a new finding in a journal article and we said, "A recent study found that...", we're talking about a general finding, whereas if we said, "The study conducted by Smith and Jones in 2020 found that...", we're talking about a specific study. Does that make sense?
prev_essay: The reflective type VFRS backplane array was fabricated on a glass substrate coated with colorless polyimide (CPI, received and manufactured from Kolon, Republic of Korea). The 4.89 nm-thick CPI was firstly coated on a glass substrate via spin-coating. The SiNx (100 nm)/Al2O3 (30 nm) double buffer layers were later introduced via plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) and thermal atomic layer deposition (T-ALD) due to water and hydrogen protection layers of the Al-ITZO TFTs, respectively. To begin with, the 80 nm-thick Mo was sputtered as the first stage of the fabrication of the TFT array over the prepared substrate, followed by the wet etching process in which the Mo film was photolithographed to construct a bottom gate electrode. To avoid diffusion of hydrogen during post-annealing from the gate insulator (GI) through the Al-ITZO active layer, a 200 nm-thick SiO2 was deposited at 380 ‚ó¶C. Then, via sputtering with 30 % oxygen partial pressure (PO2) and wet patterning, the 80 nm-thick Al-ITZO active layer was deposited and patterned accordingly, resulting in the length and width of the channel of 10 ¬µm. Afterwards, by sputtering, the 80 nm-thick Mo film was prepared as the source and drain (S/D) electrode. To reduce the carrier concentration of the back channel, the fabricated TFTs surface was treated with the N2O plasma process in a PECVD chamber prior to passivation. Subsequently, the 100 nm-thick SiOx passivation layer (PL) was deposited by in situ PECVD process at 300 ‚ó¶C using N2O and SiH4 gases, and the TFTs array was then post-annealed at 300 ‚ó¶C for 2h under vacuum. Then, the remaining layers were coated with a 1.5 ¬µm-thick organic inter-layer dielectric (ILD; DW-10; negative photoresist, received and manufactured from Dongwoo Fine Chemical, Republic of Korea) to planarize and smooth the surface morphology. The ILD was patterned with via holes that facilitated the subsequent connection with the ITO bottom electrode of OPD. Next, 150 nm-thick indium-tin oxide (ITO) as the bottom electrode of OPD was deposited via DC sputtering. Heat treatment at 230 ‚ó¶C for 2h in vacuo was performed to ensure a uniformity and clean-etch profile. The ITO thin film was patterned and followed by wet-etching. A 1 ¬µm-thick Black pixel define layer (B-PDL: Chemical name; negative photoresist, received and manufactured from Dongwoo Fine Chemical, Republic of Korea) was spin-coated and patterned to prevent optical crosstalk between each pixel.

We use "a" or "an" for singular countable nouns, "the" for both singular countable and uncountable nouns, and we don't use an article at all for plural countable and uncountable nouns. For example, we'd say "a protocol," "the protocol," "rice," and "research" respectively. Does that sound familiar?

user: Yes, but in class, some nouns can be either count or non-count too.
chatgpt_after: You are correct. In scientific writing, some nouns can function as both countable and non-countable depending on how they are used in a sentence. For instance, glass is usually a non-count noun when referring to the material, e.g. "The slide was made of glass," but it can also be used in a countable form when referring to glasses or cups, e.g. "The scientist poured the solution into two glass beakers." The context in which we use non-count and countable nouns influences the choice of article we use.

user:
With reference to these contents, is there any modification to comma, semicolon, and colon in my introduction? My introduction is as follows.

<essay>Muscle fatigue is usually defined as a reduction in maximum force[1]. Decreases in muscle force production have been shown to be detrimental in various situation, and muscle fatigue leads to postural instability[2] and affects the ability of limb control[3]. The detection and assessment of muscle fatigue are essential to prevent sports injuries and work-related musculoskeletal disorders. If the accumulation of muscle fatigue is not resolved, it will lead to overwork, and muscle damage and even threatens human health[4].
        Investigating the musculoskeletal system of human is challenging because of the complexity of the interactions between biological and neurological factors[5]. There are many factors that affect muscle fatigue including the length and volume change of muscle, imbalance of intramuscular chemical components, and some other neurological impairment. Although it is almost impossible to determine the proportion of each factor, all factors can contribute to muscle fatigue, and it can partially explain why it is challenging to represent the muscle model analytically.</essay>
chatgpt_after:
Your introduction looks great, and I can see that you've used commas effectively for separating word groups and adjectives. 

In the first sentence, it would be beneficial to use a comma after the introductory phrase "Muscle fatigue is usually defined as" since it is part of the first stage that sets the context for the research problem.

Regarding your use of semicolons and colons, I think you've done a great job of using appropriate sentence structure and avoiding errors. 

Overall, you have an excellent introduction that takes the reader accurately from the general to specific details of the research problem. You've used commas, semicolons, and colons in a way that enhances the clarity and coherence of the text.
prev_essay:
Muscle fatigue is usually defined as a reduction in maximum force[1]. Decreases in muscle force production have been shown to be detrimental in various situation, and muscle fatigue leads to postural instability[2] and affects the ability of limb control[3]. The detection and assessment of muscle fatigue are essential to prevent sports injuries and work-related musculoskeletal disorders. If the accumulation of muscle fatigue is not resolved, it will lead to overwork, and muscle damage and even threatens human health[4].
	Investigating the musculoskeletal system of human is challenging because of the complexity of the interactions between biological and neurological factors[5]. There are many factors that affect muscle fatigue including the length and volume change of muscle, imbalance of intramuscular chemical components, and some other neurological impairment. Although it is almost impossible to determine the proportion of each factor, all factors can contribute to muscle fatigue, and it can partially explain why it is challenging to represent the muscle model analytically.
	Many studies have proposed the muscle fatigue models to predict and analyze muscle fatigue and recovery. Various approaches have been used to develop muscle fatigue models. The first muscle fatigue model was proposed by Rohmert[6], introducing the relationship between the percentage of maximum muscle exerted and endurance time during static contraction. It showed that if the force exerted is less than 15% MVC, the muscle can sustain indefinitely. A fatigue model based on the Ca2+ cross-bridge mechanism was proposed and verified via a simulation experiment[7]. However, there were too many parameters to consider, which required a huge amount of calculation.
	Like this, muscle fatigue models have been developed before, but some adapt to the static condition, and others are limited to be dynamic motions. Thus, a generalized muscle fatigue and recovery model that is computationally friendly and reflects the physiological change needs to be developed.
	This study aimed to develop a muscle fatigue model that can be applied to dynamic fatigue tasks with physiological changes caused by muscle fatigue. The model was based on an existing muscle model with several muscle parameters. The overall process will be divided into several detailed objectives: First, proper muscle parameters were identified to express muscle fatigue and recovery based on the existing muscle model. Second, muscle fatigue and recovery were quantified by performing an experiment to determine the muscle model parameters.

prev_essay:
Among various robotic devices, wearable robots physically interact with the musculoskeletal system of the human body. For complete paraplegic patients, the motor torque of the wearable robot is the only internal torque of the combined human-robot system and
generates the motion of the human-robot. In the case of incomplete paraplegia, the joint
torque generated by the human and the motor torque of the robot are combined to create
the movement of the human body and the robot. Interaction torque is the assistive torque
received by humans. In this paper, we introduce a soft pneumatic muscle sensor system that
can measure the interaction torque between a human and a wearable robot. The system was
embedded in the fabric bands of the wearable robot Angel Legs to measure muscle activity
and interaction torque during robot operation. As a preliminary study, we propose a knee joint
torque experiment. Additional research progress and experimental results will be presented at
the conference session.
essay:
A soft force measurement unit based on air pressure with an extensive measurement range was proposed in this paper. sFMU consists of silicone rubber embedding three air sacs that can measure internal pressure. We made it easier to fabricate air sacs without leakage of air by using polyurethane film and thermal bonding film with a high-frequency welding machine.
The size of sFMU is 50√ó50√ó20mm which is small enough for application in human movement. The force measurement range verified in this paper is about 160N on the z-axis and 15N in the x- and y-axis force.
Numerous soft multi-axis force sensors have been suggested by researchers. These sensors utilize electric principles, such as the Hall effect or metal resistivity, and incorporate electric components like magnets or microchannels containing liquid conductors [1, 2]. These sensors are capable of measuring forces below 10N. In a different approach, Choi et al. proposed a design employing three radially positioned pneumatic chambers, where pressure is correlated with the applied force [3]. Nevertheless, this design also has limitations regarding its measurement range. Considering the range of the multi-axis force sensor for comparison, the proposed sFMU can have a larger scale of force measurement. This means that sFMU has a high potential for use in various human motion analyses such as measuring ground reaction force.
Although it has a lot of advantages in force measurement in human-robot interactions and human motion analysis, there might be the possibility to improve the sFMU. It is possible that the nonlinearity of the z-axis force of sFMU comes from the sensor's elasticity and the air sac's restoring time. This can lead the calibration equation to be quadratic. This means that the calibration matrix of the z-axis force is a 3√ó6 matrix with 6 state variables which is each sensor value and its squared value. This can be improved for better calculation computing. Compensation for the nonlinearity can be processed by modeling the sFMU considering its elasticity. Next, obtaining the calibration equation must be done for each sensor unit. This can be improved by making the environment of each air sac the same, introducing a new algorithm, or using machine learning for nonlinear regressions. The potential applications of sFMU extend beyond artificial skin or flexible human-computer interaction devices. It is also anticipated to be utilized in motion analysis and force-based balance control for wearable robots and devices.

user: How can I improve this article?

prev_essay:
Transformers (TFs) are commonly used in radio frequency (RF) CMOS circuits for an impedance-matching purposes [1-8]. TFs are designed by these iterative procedures: 1) design an ideal impedance matching circuit (MC) with passive elements (i.e., resistor, inductor, capacitor); 2) verify whether the ideal impedance MC operates appropriately; 3) transform the ideal impedance MC to a TF layout based on electromagnetic (EM) theory; 4) verify whether the TF layout operates appropriately using EM simulation. However, these procedures are very iterative and time-consuming because it needs lots of EM simulations due to the inaccuracy of theoretical models from the parasitic elements‚Äô distributed behavior [9].
Many researchers have tried to study circuit auto-synthesis platforms for analog and digital circuits. [10, 11] used genetic algorithms to select topology and make compact layouts. An auto-synthesis tool for operational amplifiers was developed using a feedforward neural network (NN) that uses a genetic algorithm [12]. There were many automated circuit synthesis techniques not only for analog and digital circuits but also for RF circuits. In order to extract the equivalent circuit of a spiral inductor, a least-fitting algorithm was proposed in [13]. Moreover, for designing tunable inductors, analysis and simulation of inductors and TFs for integrated circuits were presented [14, 15]. A multilayer perceptron lets us predict square microstrip spiral inductors‚Äô operation [16]. The concept of space mapping with a knowledge-based NN was proposed to synthesize microstrip bandpass filters [17]. In [18-20], for the synthesis of LC filters or microstrip filters, an NN was researched with electrical performance (input) and appropriate layout (output). Inverse modeling reduces iterative tasks in design procedure of TFs [21, 22].
A novel automated matching circuit synthesizer (AMCS) is proposed in the article to simplify the time-consuming process of synthesizing MCs for single-stage amplifiers in RF applications. Instead of manually synthesizing MCs, the AMCS uses an NN to determine the layout of MCs consisting of a TF and two shunt capacitors to meet the required performance, such as output impedances. The AMCS uses two NN cores, where the first core generates multiple layout candidates that can potentially match the core transistors to 50 ohms. The second core calculates the performance of the amplifier with the suggested MCs. The designer looks up the estimated performance and considers other design factors which NN cannot consider and choose a prefer MC candidate. MC‚Äôs output impedance and layout compose the one-to-many relationship which can be problem in NN training. To address one-to-many relationship, we utilize input feature that composed of TF's quality factor (Q-factor) and insertion loss (IL). Because core transistor cannot be matched to 50 ohms without shunt capacitor, this work assumes the MCs are generalized to consist of a TF and a pair of shunt capacitors. The AMCS employs the concept of human-in-the-loop (HITL), where the designer retains control over the design process and selects the most suitable MC layout. The AMCS significantly reduces the time required to synthesize MCs, and the article presents MC design examples for single-stage amplifiers operating at different frequencies from 28 GHz to 70 GHz or in different bandwidths from 10% to 32.5%. These examples showcase the AMCS's effectiveness and potential to transform the MC synthesis process for single-stage amplifiers in RF applications.

user: For explaining conventional material, present tense is commonly used.
chatgpt_after: Yes, that's correct. When explaining conventional materials, it is common to use the present tense, as these materials are already well-known and in use by other researchers. For example, if you were describing a chemical that you used in your experiment, you might write something like, "Sodium chloride is added to the solution in order to...", rather than "Sodium chloride was added to the solution in order to...". This helps to emphasize the fact that this material is widely known and accepted in the scientific community, and that you are building upon existing knowledge. However, it's important to follow the specific guidelines and style requirements of the journal or publication you are submitting to, as they may have their own conventions for describing materials.

user: When should we use present tense and past tense when explaining results?
chatgpt_after: Great question! You should use the present tense to describe your results when discussing facts or concepts that are generally true or when describing your experimental design. You should use the past tense when you are describing the specific results of your experiment. It's important to be consistent with the tense you use throughout your results section. When in doubt, it's a good practice to use past tense to describe the results of the experiment.

user:
what is the difference in using as and like here
Using the geothermal energy does not pollute the environment (as , like) the burning of fossil fuels does.
chatgpt_after:
Great question! In scientific writing, it's important to use the correct word to indicate a comparison. "As" should be used when making direct comparisons between two things that are equal or share similar characteristics. For example, "He works as a doctor." In contrast, "like" is used when making comparisons between things that share some similar characteristics, but may not be equal. For example, "He looks like his brother." 

In the sentence you provided, "as" would be the appropriate word choice to indicate that using geothermal energy does not pollute the environment in the same way that burning fossil fuels does. So the correct sentence would be: "Using geothermal energy does not pollute the environment, as the burning of fossil fuels does."

- "The catalytic converter converts harmful emissions into harmless gases, like a filter cleans out impurities from water."

- "The process of photosynthesis is an important source of energy for plants, as it allows them to convert sunlight into energy."

- "A chemical reaction occurs when two or more substances combine and produce a new substance, like when an acid and a base are mixed together."

- "Bacteria can be beneficial to the human body, as they help to break down food in the digestive system."

- "Using renewable energy sources, like solar and wind power, can help to reduce our reliance on non-renewable resources."

please check this examples:
Example 1. The drop in pressure was due to a crack in the pipe. 
Example 2. The drop in pressure may have been due to a crack in the pipe. 
Example 3. The drop in pressure must have been due to a crack in the pipe.
chatgpt_after:
Great examples! Here's a brief assessment of the modal verbs used in each sentence:

- Example 1: This sentence uses "was due to," which suggests a high degree of certainty. It implies that there is a definitive causal relationship between the crack and the drop in pressure, which may not be completely supported by the available evidence.
- Example 2: This sentence uses "may have been due to," which suggests a lower degree of certainty. It acknowledges that there are other possible explanations for the drop in pressure, but it also implies that the crack is a plausible explanation based on the available evidence.
- Example 3: This sentence uses "must have been due to," which suggests the highest degree of certainty of the three. It implies that the crack is the only plausible explanation for the drop in pressure, which may not be justified based on the available evidence.

In scientific writing, it's generally better to err on the side of caution when it comes to making definitive statements. That's because science is a constantly evolving field, and it's important to acknowledge the limitations of our studies and the uncertainties in our findings. Modal verbs like "may," "might," "could," and "should" can be very useful for expressing these kinds of caveats.

Furthermore, 74% of the students strongly agree that the videos are an appropriate length, while 58% strongly agree that the amount of time spent checking homework tasks is appropriate. Overall, the survey findings indicate that the students have mixed feelings regarding the efficacy of textbook content in developing their writing abilities, while they typically find the video and classroom content to be satisfactory. The findings may help the instructors adjust their teaching methods and course materials to better meet the needs and expectations of the students.

user: is it okay to put discussion in results section?
chatgpt_after: It is important to keep each section of a scientific paper distinct and separate. Therefore, it is generally not recommended to include the Discussion section in the Results section. The Results section should simply report the findings and summarize the data in a clear and concise way. On the other hand, the Discussion section should interpret the results, provide explanations for the findings, compare them to previous research, and present conclusions based on the study. These two sections serve distinct purposes and are meant to be separate. However, it is common and often useful to reference the findings from the Results section when writing the Discussion section.

user:
THIS IS MY PARAGRAPH? CAN YOU TAKE A LOOK AT IT AND GIVE ME FEEDBACK, PLEASE?
<para>Methodology
Overview
The study is testing the company‚Äôs ESG commitment and the attributes of the CEO while controlling some variables that could affect this relationship, mainly the supervising board and CEO‚Äôs respective responsibilities regarding ESG matters of the firm.
Sample
The sample used for this study is collected from the Carbon Disclosure Project database of 2020 (CDP 2020). CDP collected data about the CEO‚Äôs responsibilities, board positions, and carbon emissions from over 4000 companies from several countries. The details about the CEO education attributes not included in the CDP database are collected from public sources, including companies' annual reports or LinkedIn profiles.
Survey Structure
The companies were asked to fill out a form with questions about their carbon emissions, governance structure, and the CEO‚Äôs responsibility.
For the governance structure, companies were asked to provide details about the department supervising the ESG-related matters, whether it is a specific board or an executive member. This data helps us control the influence of other executive members on CEO decisions.
As for the CEO‚Äôs responsibility, the questionnaire included inquiries about the CEO‚Äôs role in ESG-related matters and whether they are directly or indirectly reported to him.
Regarding carbon emissions, the companies were asked to report their yearly emissions number and indicate their level of engagement in reducing them. This data helps measure the dependent variable of our model.
The CDP database did not include details about the CEO education attributes our study focuses on. Therefore, we had to collect them individually through publicly available sources. We quantified whether the CEO studied abroad and the presence or absence of ESG awareness in their educational background. This helps us measure the independent variable of our study.</para>

2. Data Collection: It would be helpful to further explain the process of how you collected and analyzed the data. For example, were the surveys sent to all the companies in the CDP database, or were they randomly selected? How did you decide which companies to include in your sample? Are there any other variables that you were unable to control for in your analysis? Acknowledging limitations can help readers understand the strengths and weaknesses of your study.

user: "We successfully established the dTAG system in the HAP1 cell line, enabling rapid and precise knock-out of the CHD3 protein. After treatment with dTAG-13, we confirmed that depletion of CHD3 affects transcription factors present in the histone gene cluster. Through ChIP-seq, Hi-C, and mass spectrometry, we demonstrated that CHD3 specifically interacts with transcription repressors located in the histone gene cluster, thereby regulating transcription initiation. This evidence supports the hypothesis that CHD3 functions independently of the NuRD complex to regulate histone gene expression." This paragraph is for the scientific paper, discussion and conclusion part. I'm confused to what tenses to use. Can you give me some advice?
chatgpt_after:
Yes, I can definitely help you with that. In scientific writing, it is important to use the past tense when describing the methods and results of your study. This means that you should use past tense verbs when describing what you did in the study, such as "established," "confirmed," and "demonstrated." 

When discussing the implications of your results and drawing conclusions, you can use the present tense. This means that you can use present tense verbs when discussing the significance of your findings, such as "supports the hypothesis" and "regulates transcription initiation." 

Overall, it's important to be consistent with your tenses throughout your paper. If you're unsure about which tense to use, it's always a good idea to consult a style guide or ask your instructor for guidance.
prev_essay: Gene regulation is a highly coordinated process that requires not only ordered recruitment of various transcription factors, but also the alterations in chromatin structure. Chromatin remodelers play an important role in regulating the compaction of chromatin to organize genomic DNA. These conserved enzymes can be divided in 4 families: SWI/SNF, ISWI, CHD, and INO80, depending on what characteristic domains they have. These chromatin remodelers mediate post-translational histone modification or utilize energy derived from ATP hydrolysis to alter the histone-DNA contacts within the nucleosome.
essay: We successfully established the dTAG system in the HAP1 cell line, enabling rapid and precise knock-out of the CHD3 protein. After treatment with dTAG-13, we confirmed that depletion of CHD3 affects transcription factors present in the histone gene cluster. Through ChIP-seq, Hi-C, and mass spectrometry, we demonstrated that CHD3 specifically interacts with transcription repressors located in the histone gene cluster, thereby regulating transcription initiation. This evidence supports the hypothesis that CHD3 functions independently of the NuRD complex to regulate histone gene expression.

chatgpt_after:
Your fixed paragraph looks good. However, I have a few suggestions that may help improve the clarity of your writing. 

First, you may want to consider rephrasing the sentence "10 mM beta-mercaptoethanol was used for efficient cell wall digestion, and time for RNase and Proteinase K reactions was extended for complete removal of contaminants." It's unclear what you mean by "time for RNase and Proteinase K reactions." Instead, you could say "10 mM beta-mercaptoethanol was added to enhance cell wall digestion, and the RNase and Proteinase K reactions were extended to ensure complete removal of contaminants." 

Secondly, you may want to clarify what "Ethanol down" means, as this phrase is likely unfamiliar to readers. It sounds like you're referring to an ethanol precipitation step, so you could say "Samples were precipitated with ethanol and the DNA was eluted with 30 ¬µl of distilledwater." 

Taking these suggestions into account, here is your paragraph with revised sentences:

"Micrococcal nuclease (MNase) digestion to obtain mononucleosomes was performed based on the recently published protocol (McKnight et al., 2019) with minor adjustments for efficient cell wall digestion and proteinase activation for fission yeast (Lantermann et al., 2009). To enhance cell wall digestion, 10 mM beta-mercaptoethanol was added, and the RNase and Proteinase K reactions were extended to ensure the complete removal of contaminants. Fifty milliliters of cell culture were cross-linked with formaldehyde (final concentration of 1%) at room temperature for 15 minutes, and quenched with 2.5M glycine (final concentration of 125 mM) at room temperature for 5 minutes. The cells were washed with cold distilled water and flash-frozen for storage. Frozen cells can be stored indefinitely at -80¬∞C and resuspended with 1 ml of spheroplast buffer containing 1 M sorbitol, 50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, and 10 mM beta-mercaptoethanol. Cell walls were digested with 400 units of Zymolyase (nacalai, 07765), for 15 minutes at 30¬∞C with gentle shaking. Spheroplasted cells were then treated with 120 units of MNase for 25 minutes at 37¬∞C without shaking. MNase digestion was stopped with EDTA and EGTA, each at a final concentration of 50 mM. RNA was digested with 0.3 mg/ml of RNase at 42¬∞C for 1 hour. Samples were de-cross-linked with 1 mg/ml of proteinase K at 65¬∞C with 1%SDS overnight. DNA was precipitated with ethanol and eluted with 30 ¬µl of distilled water."

user:
<essay>METHODS
This study focuses on the role of anterior cingulate Cortex (ACC) in audiovisual multisensory integration and its potential involvement in auditory dominance in mice facing cognitive conflict scenarios.

Experimental Model Details
Approval from KAIST Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee was obtained for all procedures. Mice of both sexes aged P40-P120 were used for this study. Experiments were performed on wild type (WT, C57BL/6J n=[number]) male and female mice. Subjects were housed under light (starting at 8am) and dark (starting at 8 pm) cycle in single cages with food (mouse chow) available at will. Weight loss of no more than 10% of the initial weight was approved for experiments. 

Dual Retrograde Tracing
Mice of age P50-90 were lightly anesthesized with isoflurane and set on a stereotaxic device (David Kopf Instruments). Throughout the surgery the mice were kept under 1.0-1.5% isoflurane in oxygen, and on a heating pad to maintain the body temperature. After ensuring proper anaesthesia through toe pinch reflex, the mice were head fixed with ear bars and eyes were covered in Vaseline to avoid dryness. The hair on the head was removed with hair removal cream, and the scalp was opened with a single cut down the middle. After removal of periosteum and cleaning of the skull (with ethanol and 1X phosphate buffered saline (PBS)) the target areas were marked on the right hemisphere in reference to Bregma and Lambda. The coordinates used were AP +0.50 ML -0.20 DV -1.00 for ACC and AP -1.94 ML -.1.90 DV -0.40 for posterior parietal cortex (PPC), decided using Paxinos Atlas and Allen Brain Atlas (1, 2). Small craniotomies of 0.1 mm diameter were made over the target coordinates. Injections were done with Nanoliter injector (World Precision Instruments), 400 nl per area, both at 0.3 nl/sec speed. PPC was injected with pseudotyped AAV virus containing red fluorescence (PAAV-CAG-tdTomato), and ACC was injected with pseudotyped AAV virus containing green fluorescence (PAAV-CAG-tdTomato). Neurons projecting to PPC were expected to show red signals, and neurons projecting to ACC were expected to show green signals, while neurons projecting to both areas would be observed in yellow. After the injections the incision was close by suturing, and mice were sacrificed after 2 weeks for histology. 

Histology
Dual retrograde tracing mice were sacrificed after 2 weeks of virus incubation. The mice were anesthesized deeply with isoflurane and perfused with 1X PBS followed by 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA). The brains were extracted from the skull and left for postfixation in 4% PFA either for 1 hour in room temperature (RT) or overnight in 4C. After fixation, brain samples were transferred into 30% sucrose in RT on a shaker for 2-3 days. After the brains sunk to the bottom of the tube, they were embedded into optimal cutting temperature (OCT) medium (Tissue Tek) and stored at -80C freezer. Cryosectioning was performed at 30 nm thickness at the cryostat (Leica), from posterior areas to PPC to anterior areas to ACC, collecting one section and discarding the next. Sections were collected on microscope slides, washed in 1X PBS 3 times for 10 minutes each, and mounted in DAPI. Slides were imaged at the scanning microscope, in the channels DAPI, EGFP, and TdTomato.
Behavioural experiment

Surgery
P40-60 mice were fixed at the stereotaxic device and kept at the same conditions as mentioned in the Dual Retrograde Tracing surgery. The scalp skin was cut and removed from between the eyes to the ears to expose the skull. Neck muscles were cut and removed. Skull was cleaned and PPC and ACC were marked. Headplates were attached to the skull with Loctite and dental cement. 

Head-fixed training
Head-fixed training was performed to later test the mice in multisensory decision making. Training was done in soundproof chambers, fixed in a head-fixed tube apparatus. The mice were set in licking distance from a water port, a 7 inch gamma-corrected LCD monitor 10 cm away from the left eye (minimum & maximum luminance set as 1 & 120Lux), and a speaker 10 cm away from the left ear. In an attempt to provide a sound proof environment, the wooden chambers were covered with insulating foam on the inside. The mice were trained in a Go/No-Go task for auditory and visual modalities simultaneously. Black and white gradient horizontal/vertical drifting gratings were used for visual stimuli. 5 kHz and 10 kHz pure tones were used for auditory stimuli. Vertical left-to-right drifting gratings and 5 kHz pure tone were trained as Go stimuli and horizontal bottom-to-top drifting gratings and 10 kHz pure tone were trained as No-Go stimuli. The animals were water deprived for 2 days before the training. The first days were free-water period, where the mouse would get 4ul water reward with every lick, with no stimuli present. When the lick rate reached 200 licks/20 min, the mouse was advanced to conditioning period. In this period the mouse was given 1 ul water reward for Go trials regardless of lick response for the association of the stimuli to the reward. No punishment was present at this stage. When the Hit Rate ((Hit x 100)/(Hit+Miss)) reached 70%, the animal would be moved onto the training period. Training period consisted of hit, miss, false alarm and correct rejection according to the mouse‚Äôs licking the lick port within the response window after stimulus presentation. Hit trials were rewarded with 1 ul of water if mice licked within the response window. False Alarm trials were punished with a 200 ms airpuff. Miss and Correct rejection trials were neither rewarded nor punished. If animals did not get 1 ml water in total from training in a day, it was given the amount of water to complete the consumption to 1 ml after the training. The training was regarded complete when the Correct Rate (((Hit+Correct Rejection) x 100)/Number of Trials)) reached 80%. In the case of one modality reaching the treshold faster, the mouse was trained in single modality until they were on the same level. 
There were going to be more subsections but I ran out of time I‚Äôm sorry:‚Äô)

REFERENCES
1.        Paxinos G, J. FKB. The Mouse Brain in stereotaxic coordinates. Academic Press; 2019. 
2.        Allen Mouse Brain Atlas [dataset] [Internet]. 2011. Available from: http://mouse.brain-map.org/ </essay>
chatgpt_after: Overall, your use of commas in this paragraph looks good! You've used them to separate items in a list and to set off non-essential information. One thing I might suggest is using a comma after "overnight in 4C." This would be an example of setting off non-essential information, as the use of "overnight in 4C" adds detail but is not necessary for understanding the sentence. Another small adjustment you might consider is adding a comma after "Hit Rate" and "Correct Rate" since these are independent clauses. But these are minor suggestions, and your comma usage is generally correct and effective in your writing.
