prev_essay:
In the previous years, a trend of students enrolled in undergraduate or higher degrees moving farther away for education has been observed. Although having a bigger radius for university selection increases the number of opportunities, students who have close relationships with their families may experience homesickness. Paying frequent visits to the family may alleviate this issue. Furthermore, visiting their family for students often ends up with the benefit of receiving more supplies such as homemade food. We have hypothesized that students who visit their family more often are on average happier, and conducted a survey consisting of four questions.
Before finding a relationship between the frequency of visiting family and happiness, we needed to check some factors which can affect the frequency. To this end, we first asked people about the distance they live from their families. Among our 16 respondents, the most frequent visitor was the person who lived the closest to their family (0-50km) with 16 visits on average within 4 months, while people living farther than 300km away showed the lowest results with two no visits and one 1 visit (Figure 1). However, between 100-200km, no significant trend was observed. We then questioned whether the closeness of the relationship between the respondents and their families affected the number of visits. As can be seen in Figure 1, no correlation was observed. Three people reported their closeness to their family as a 7 on a scale of 0 to 10. While one of them visited 16 times in the given period, the other two remained at the low numbers of 1 and 2. This could be attributed to the distance factor, as the respondent visiting their family 16 times lives the closest to their home at 0-50km; however, two people living in the same distance interval (100-200km) reported their closeness level as 8 and visited home 8 and 1 times. Overall, it can be observed in Figure 1 that at the closest and farthest ends of the scale (0-50km & 300km) distance plays a significant role in the frequency of home visits, while it shows variety in the middle range (100-200km). Emotional closeness, on the other hand, does not seem to factor into the results. 

Lastly, we compared the frequency of visiting family with perceived level of happiness to test our hypothesis (Figure 2). No correlation was observed between the two factors. While respondent 1 with an average of 16 home visits in 4 months reported 4 on their level of happiness, respondent 15 scored the highest score, 10, on the happiness chart and did not visit their family at all. However, no inverse correlation was observed, as respondents with high responses on both questions (see respondent 3) and low responses on both questions (see respondent 7) were also present. Overall, our data has shown that there is no direct correlation between students‚Äô level of happiness and their amount of home visits.

In the previous years, a trend of students enrolled in undergraduate or higher degrees moving farther away for education has been observed. Although having a bigger radius for university selection increases the number of opportunities, students who have close relationships with their families may experience homesickness. Paying frequent visits to the family may alleviate this issue. Furthermore, visiting their family for students often ends up with the benefit of receiving more supplies such as homemade food. We have hypothesized that students who visit their family more often are on average happier, and conducted a survey consisting of four questions.
Before finding a relationship between the frequency of visiting family and happiness, we needed to check some factors which can affect the frequency. To this end, we first asked people about the distance they live from their families. Among our 16 respondents, the most frequent visitor was the person who lived the closest to their family (0-50km) with 16 visits on average within 4 months, while people living farther than 300km away showed the lowest results with two no visits and one 1 visit (Figure 1). However, between 100-200km, no significant trend was observed. We then questioned whether the closeness of the relationship between the respondents and their families affected the number of visits. As can be seen in Figure 1, no correlation was observed. Three people reported their closeness to their family as a 7 on a scale of 0 to 10. While one of them visited 16 times in the given period, the other two remained at the low numbers of 1 and 2. This could be attributed to the distance factor, as the respondent visiting their family 16 times lives the closest to their home at 0-50km; however, two people living in the same distance interval (100-200km) reported their closeness level as 8 and visited home 8 and 1 times. Overall, it can be observed in Figure 1 that at the closest and farthest ends of the scale (0-50km & 300km) distance plays a significant role in the frequency of home visits, while it shows variety in the middle range (100-200km). Emotional closeness, on the other hand, does not seem to factor into the results. 

Lastly, we compared the frequency of visiting family with perceived level of happiness to test our hypothesis (Figure 2). No correlation was observed between the two factors. While respondent 1 with an average of 16 home visits in 4 months reported 4 on their level of happiness, respondent 15 scored the highest score, 10, on the happiness chart and did not visit their family at all. However, no inverse correlation was observed, as respondents with high responses on both questions (see respondent 3) and low responses on both questions (see respondent 7) were also present. Overall, our data has shown that there is no direct correlation between students‚Äô level of happiness and their amount of home visits.

user: How can we write a transition paragraph in a Cause and effect essay? I'm writing a essay in a block structure.
chatgpt_after:
In a block structure for a cause and effect essay, a transitional paragraph, also known as a bridge paragraph or pivot paragraph, is important to smoothly transition the reader from one topic to the next. To write a transitional paragraph, you can follow these steps:

1. Summarize the previous section: Begin by summarizing the main points of the previous section relating to your cause and effect essay.
2. Introduce the next section: Guide the reader to the next topic by introducing it and making it clear how it‚Äôs related to the previous material.
3. Add a transition sentence: At this point, you should add a sentence that ties the two topics together in a concise way.
4. State the new topic sentence: Finally, state the topic sentence for the new section.

Here is an example of a transitional paragraph:

"Having explored the causes and effects of pollution on our environment, we must now turn our attention to its impact on our health. Pollution not only affects our surroundings but our health as well. In this next section, we will examine the ways that pollution affects our health and well-being."

user: Can we use hyphens when we add some more informations at a paragraph?
chatgpt_after:
If you are adding more information to a paragraph or sentence, you can use hyphens to create a compound modifier. A compound modifier consists of two or more words that work together to modify a noun. When these modifiers come before a noun, they are usually hyphenated to show that they are working together to modify the noun as a single idea. 

Here's an example: 

Incorrect: The teacher handed out the confusingly written assignment. 

Correct: The teacher handed out the confusingly-written assignment. 

In the correct sentence, "confusingly-written" is a compound modifier that comes before the noun "assignment". The hyphen connects these words and shows that they should be read as a single idea.

user:
South Korea has an extensive network of trains connecting major cities and tourist destinations across the country. Among the various types of trains available, the Mugungwha and the KTX are two of the most popular options. While both provide reliable transportation, there are significant differences between the two that make them suited to different needs.

The Mugungwha train is a conventional train that runs on a slower and more local route than the KTX. It is a cost-effective option for those who are looking to travel between cities and towns within the country. The train is popular among locals and budget-conscious travelers as it is cheaper than the KTX. It offers comfortable seating and a decent level of amenities, such as toilets, vending machines, and air conditioning.

On the other hand, the KTX is a high-speed train that travels at speeds of up to 350 kilometers per hour. It is a faster and more convenient option for those looking to travel between major cities, such as Seoul, Busan, and Daegu. The train is more expensive than the Mugungwha, but it offers a higher level of comfort and luxury. It has spacious seats, free Wi-Fi, and food service. Moreover, the KTX is punctual and reliable, making it an attractive option for business travelers and tourists who want to maximize their time in Korea.

essay:
In our university, KAIST, we are major-free in the first year. When other usual universities select a major before they come to university and keep on trach of it, we choose major in second year. This policy makes a lot of benefits to students and university.
 First, students can have a extra time to think about their dream. Since the university make a score of students high school work, it's so important for students that they are afraid of changing their major area in the second or third year of high school. Instead, they choose the major in first grade of school and continuously work on it for three years, only for the college. How could a person make a decision of what to do in whole life, only in a age of 17? In the effect of policy about education in Korea, students don't have enough time to experience largely, and widely. So 'the first year of college be major free' can help students to have a time wondering what they will be in future, and experience lots of things as a adult. It could seen as wasting time (for 1 years) to study on their dream and major, but it could also seen as saving the time, because changing a major at the end of college Iwould take a time more than a year.
 Second, students can take a break after a hard time studying in high school for three years. Even though some students totally made a decision about major before college, it would be not a bad sounds to hear. Many people dream about campous life. Everyone knew that university is a place where we study about deeper knowledge of many things, but having a good time with college friends from the world (or just ofther city) can helpful to students. Not only taking a break, but also meeting much more people than school can improve their wideth and depth of thoughts and creativity.
 Third, as the time goes, many major areas share a same topic, like AI or argorithum. And if we plus the classes we have to listen like physics or math, their would be no time waste which some people are worried about. This could be the change of the study through years. A lot of time before, there was little subjects to share between different majors. And now, it's the time we have to change.
 And last but not least, colleges can also less worry about enrolling student amount of each major. Some majors are more popular then others. Then do we have to change the people amout to enroll, Like hundred in chemistry and fifty in physics? By using this policy, colleges don't need to think about that kind of enrollment, Students will change their major as they want. College would just have to see is they would study hard in college.

user:
Here is my essay.

<essay>In our university, KAIST, we are major-free in the first year. Unlike other universities, where students select their majors before starting college and continue to study it, we choose a major in the second year. This policy has several benefits for both students and university. The reason for this is because of various causes and effects.
Firstly, being major-free in the first year allows students to have extra time to make decisions about their future. High school grades are very important when it comes to selecting majors, which puts a lot of pressure on students. Often, students choose their major solely based on their high school performance, which might not be a reliable indicator of interests or strengths. Choosing a major at the early age of 17 is difficult, and it is important to provide students with enough time to explore their options. Therefore, being major-free in the first year can provide students with time to experience different things as adults and have time to think about their dreams. This can help prevent students from feeling rushed to make such important decisions.
Secondly, students can benefit from a break after a demanding high school experience that had lasted for three years. Even if students have already decided on their major, taking time to meet people from all over the world and spend time with new friends can be beneficial. This time can help students to learn new perspectives, increase creativity, and improve their worldview. So, students can benefit by taking a break and having the freedom to explore college life without the constraints of a specific major.
Furthermore, over time, many subjects within different majors have started overlapping, especially with the rise of artificial intelligence. Giving students the opportunity to explore various subjects can improve their understanding of the shared topics, which improves their perspective on their major. Since many majors share similar course requirements like mathematics and physics, there would be no concern about wasting time on unrelated courses. Thus, students can benefit from a well-rounded education.
Lastly, colleges can worry less about enrolling students for different majors, as not all majors are equally popular. By allowing students to change their major as they wish, colleges do not have to worry about involuntary enrolment in less popular majors or over-enrolling in popular ones. Instead, they can focus solely on ensuring that enrolled students are studying and meeting their academic obligations. As a result, the university can benefit from a more flexible system that can adapt to the needs of students without the burden of bureaucratic obstacles.
Overall, being major-free in the first year of university can provide many benefits for both students and universities. Through the use of cause and effect paragraphs, we can better understand how this policy can benefit society as a whole.</essay>
chatgpt_after:
Great start! Here are some suggestions to help you further organize and improve your essay based on what we've learned about complex sentences:

1. Incorporate complex sentences to show relationships between ideas.

You have included several examples of cause and effect relationships, which can be expressed more effectively using dependent clauses. Here's an example:

Before: <sent>"Choosing a major at the early age of 17 is difficult, and it is important to provide students with enough time to explore their options."</sent>

After: <sent>"Since choosing a major at the early age of 17 is difficult, it is important to provide students with enough time to explore their options."</sent>

By starting the sentence with a subordinating conjunction, you can clearly show the cause and effect relationship between the two ideas.

2. Vary your sentence structure.

To keep your essay engaging and avoid repetition, you can vary your sentence structures. Here's an example:

Before: <sent>"Even if students have already decided on their major, taking time to meet people from all over the world and spend time with new friends can be beneficial."</sent>

After: <sent>"Despite having already decided on their major, students can benefit from taking time to meet people from all over the world and spend time with new friends."</sent>

In this revised sentence, we've used the dependent clause "despite having already decided on their major" to show a contrasting idea, which adds variation to your essay.

3. Use transitions to show connections between paragraphs.

Transitions help guide the reader through your essay and show the connections between ideas. Here's an example:

Before:

Furthermore, over time, many subjects within different majors have started overlapping, especially with the rise of artificial intelligence. Giving students the opportunity to explore various subjects can improve their understanding of the shared topics, which improves their perspective on their major.

After:

Furthermore, over time, many subjects within different majors have started overlapping, especially with the rise of artificial intelligence. As a result, giving students the opportunity to explore various subjects can improve their understanding of the shared topics and, in turn, improve their perspective on their major. 

By starting the second paragraph with "as a result," we can clearly show how the two ideas are connected.

I hope these examples are helpful! Remember, these are just suggestions - feel free to revise in your own voice and style.

Today I learned about the unity and coherence. Each paragraph only has one main idea
expressed in a topic sentence. All sentences and details focus on supporting that one main idea. Everything should be connected, and it is unity. Unity helps the reader follow the writer's ideas. The reader expects each paragraph to have one main idea. When both the writer and reader follow this agreement, both writing and reading become a lot easier. And coherence is how well ideas are connected within a paragraph. Coherence is a logical bridge between words and sentences in essays. Sentences need to be ordered in a logical way with clear transitions.

First, let's focus on unity. Can you identify the main idea of each paragraph in your essay? If not, go through each paragraph and write down the main idea in one sentence. 

Once you have identified the main idea of each paragraph, make sure that all the sentences in that paragraph support that main idea. If there are any sentences that do not support the main idea, consider removing them or rephrasing them to better fit the paragraph's focus.

Next, let's work on coherence. Look at the order of your sentences within each paragraph. Are they in a logical order? Do they flow smoothly from one sentence to the next? If not, consider rearranging the sentences or adding transition words to help connect them.

Finally, make sure that there are clear transitions between each paragraph. This will help the reader follow your ideas and understand how they are connected. Consider using transition words or phrases such as "in addition," "however," or "therefore" to help connect your paragraphs.

Remember, the goal is to have each paragraph focus on one main idea and to have all the sentences within that paragraph support that main idea. Additionally, the sentences should be ordered in a logical way with clear transitions between paragraphs. Keep these principles in mind as you revise your essay.

<essay>In these days, most students use their own tablets or laptop computers in class. They use these internet technology devices to write down what they learn in class, download professor's lecture notes, and search something that they do not know exactly. There are two big advantages of using a tablet or a laptop computer in class.
The first advantage is that students can participate in class well by using the devices. For example, playing Kahoot quiz about what students have learned increases understanding of the concept they have learned, and using QR codes to join some activity in class will rise interest of students. In addition, we are in the post-covid era, students and professor can contact online via Zoom of Google Meets, and it can also increase participation of students in class who are far away. By using tablets and laptops, students can participate in class more actively.
The second advantage is the usefulness of using such devices. In class, professor do their class using lecture notes and sometimes they write down some letters on the white board. Students who use tablets or laptops can easily download the lecture note, write what they understand down on it, take some pictures of the white board and share some copy of their online notes. Also, by using some internet platforms such as KLMS or Google Classroom, students can upload their homework or handout more comfortably. The most important part of the advantages, usefulness, is that students can do those things with only one electronic device, they need no paper, no pencil, no erasers.
There are two main advantages, the increase of participation of students in class, and the usefulness of using the devices. By these advantages, students use their own tablet or laptop computers in class.</essay>

<essay>The prevalence of electronic devices in classrooms has surged in recent years, and while there are advantages and disadvantages to this trend, they can be managed effectively. The most notable benefits include increased student participation and greater usefulness in the classroom.

For instance, playing Kahoot or Quizlet games enhances understanding and retention of key concepts. Similarly, online platforms like Zoom or Google Meets offer students the opportunity to engage with professors and peers, regardless of their physical location. These technologies allow for more active participation and a more immersive learning environment.
On the opposite end, some critics argue that a dependence on electronic devices in the classroom has adverse effects, such as fostering a culture of distraction that undermines students' ability to focus. Additionally, technology can sometimes fail, leading to disruptions in teaching and learning. Furthermore, while electronic documents are convenient, they can be easily lost if not properly saved or backed up.
However, the benefits of using electronic devices in the classroom outweigh the disadvantages. In particular, these devices enable greater collaboration, productivity, and flexibility among students and professors. By taking advantage of these benefits, students can use their own tablet or laptop computers in class with more ease and productivity.
In conclusion, while there are some downsides to the use of electronic devices in the classroom, there are many ways to overcome these challenges and maximize the advantages they offer. Ultimately, educators and students should work together to view these devices as a tool to enhance learning, and not as a distraction.</essay>

user: Is it okay to put specific example in introduction?
chatgpt_after:
While it is not a strict rule, it is generally not recommended to put specific examples in the introduction. The introduction should provide context and background information on the topic, as well as an overview of what the essay will cover. Putting specific examples in the introduction may confuse the reader or distract them from the main point you are trying to make.

Instead, save your specific examples for the body paragraphs, and use them to support and reinforce your main points. This will help your essay to be more organized and clear for your readers. 

So, you might want to consider removing any specific examples in your introduction and instead focus on providing background information and a general idea of what your essay will cover.

Most of the nations around the world have their own policies to help their citizens. Some countries have policies aimed at supporting those who are most in need. For example, the Nordic countries and Canada have comprehensive welfare systems and employment insurance program. Although they have specific policies for those in need, they also has basic systems for all citizens. I think government should provide support all citizens regardless of socioeconomic background. 
 Firstly, the government should ensure fundamental rights of citizens. The most important example is safety and healthcare. If nations help differently according to their socioeconomic background, it could be a non-just society. To make equitable society, nations should provide support equally. USA is now providing law enforcement, and fire emergency services, and disaster response, etc. Similarly, other nations are helping all citizens and ensure their safety.
 Furthermore, the government should make a just and equitable society. Socioeconomic status is a factor that is beyond on individual's control, such as race, ethnicity, gender, or family background. Therefore, it is important for governments to provide support and assistance all citizens regardless of their socioeconomic status. If they treat differently, it can cause a lot of issues. For example, it can lead to discrimination problem and social problem. When individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds are treated differently than those from more privileged backgrounds, they may feel marginalized and excluded from society. To prevent these situations, government should support all citizens equally.
 All citizens have fundamental rights as a citizen of their nation. If the government treat differently according to their socioeconomic status, it could lead to lots of social problem, such as disparities, social exclusion. Therefore, the government should provide support for all citizens regardless of their socioeconomic backgrounds, and they have to make a just and equitable nations.

user: Explain about "unclear pronoun"
chatgpt_after: Sure, an unclear pronoun is a common writing problem where the reader cannot clearly identify which noun a pronoun is referring to. For instance, consider the following sentence: "John gave the money to his brother, but he refused to take it." Here, it is unclear who refused to take the money, John or his brother. This ambiguity can make the sentence confusing and difficult to understand. user: How can we remove unclear pronoun in essay?
chatgpt_after:
To remove unclear pronouns from your essay, you can follow these steps:
 
1. Identify the pronouns in your writing
Scan through your essay to locate any pronouns you've used. These may include words such as "he," "she," "they," "it," "them," "who," and so on. 

2. Identify the noun the pronoun is referring to
Once you've located a pronoun, look for the noun it refers to. If you can't find a clear noun, try to rephrase the sentence so that the antecedent is more specific.

3. Use a clear noun instead of the pronoun
Once you've identified the antecedent, replace the pronoun with a clear and specific noun. Using a noun, instead of a pronoun, will minimize any confusion and enhance the clarity of your writing.

4. Read your revised sentence aloud
To ensure that your revised sentence is clear and easy to comprehend, read it aloud. If it sounds good, and you can discern the noun the pronoun refers to, you are on the right track!

user: What is similar transition of contrast word with therefore?
chatgpt_after: The transition word that is similar to "therefore" but shows contrast is "however." "Therefore" is a transition word that shows a cause-and-effect relationship between two ideas, while "however" is a transition word that shows a contrast or a difference between two ideas. For example, "I studied hard for the exam; therefore, I got an A" shows a cause-and-effect relationship, while "I studied hard for the exam; however, I still didn't understand some of the questions" shows a contrast between the effort put in and the outcome achieved.

<essay>How to Make a Good Impression on Friend
     Giving a good impression on friend requires three steps. First, taking first is important. To start a conversation and be closer, it is necessary to talk first to others. Make the word before the friend talks. That way, the friend will have less burden to talk first when they meet later. Next, be polite to others. If a speaker talks politely, the listener will also try to be so. Polite taking will make friends to be closer because the speaker will think that the listener is focusing to the speaker‚Äôs word. Finally, always make smile. Smile makes people look more friendly and kind. Also, the smile will spread out, and the conversation will be happier. To sum up, it is important to talk first, be polite, and make a smile to friend.</essay>

chatgpt_after:
Sure, here are the grammatical errors I found in your essay and instructions on how to correct them:

1. Use "make" or "taking" before "first" to signify you "take the initiative" to start a conversation with a friend.
 
Correction: "First, taking the initiative is important. To start a conversation and become closer, it is necessary to talk first to others."

2. The sentence "Make the word before the friend talks" is unclear. Perhaps you meant to say "Speak before the friend talks"?

Correction: "Speak first before your friend does. That way, your friend will have less burden to talk first when you meet later."

3. The grammar in the sentence "If a speaker talks politely, the listener will also try to be so" is incorrect. It should be "If a speaker speaks politely, the listener will also try to do so."

Correction: "Next, be polite when speaking to others. If you speak politely, the listener will also try to do so. Polite conversation will make friends feel closer to you because they know you are actively paying attention to their words."

4. Use "always smile" instead of "always make smile", as "make" implies creating something, while "smile" is a verb that communicates a state of being.

Correction: "Finally, always smile. A smile makes you look more friendly and kind. Additionally, others will likely respond positively to your smile, which will create a happier conversation. In summary, it is important to take the initiative, be polite when speaking, and always smile around friends."

essay:
Government has a duty for helping its citizens. However, the scale of people who will be helped is a hot potato these days. Some says that the government should help only those most in need, and other says that it should help all of its citizens, regardless of their socioeconomic background. I think it is better to help only those most in need. So from now on, I'll talk about my opinion with specific reasons. 

First, it will help to make a balanced society. Since resources that government can use for citizens are limited, it would be better to help people who really needs help, rather than helping every citizens. These days, many society's wealth gap between the top and the bottom are tremendous, which means it is very unbalanced. I think a good society should be balanced in everything, so I'd choose to help only those most in need.

Secondly, I think it is a social duty. Have you ever heard about the word 'Noblesse Oblige'? It is a word which has a long history and it is about some duties that rich people should follow for others. So, we can know that it was trivial for rich people to help other people for a long time. From this perspective, helping only those most in need seems trivial. Of course, there are some people who really worked hard and got a high socioeconomic background, but in many cases the socioeconomic background depends on their luck, such as parent's background. So, I think it is right for high class people to turn back the benefits to society they have had, and giving up the government's help for those most in need will be a idea of it. 

So, I think the government should help only those most in need, rather than helping all the citizens regardless of their socioeconomic background for two reasons. First it will help to make a balanced society, and second, it is a social duty such as 'Noblesse Oblige'. Thank you.

can you tell me if there is any comma splice or run on errors in my essay following? 
<essay>First year in KAIST, undergraduates does't have a specific major. Many other university opened major that has no major first year, and some university even have under graduates be free of majors until graduation. Universities should require the first year of college to be major-free. I have three supporting reason that no major on the first year of college is beneficial in different reasons. 
First, an year without major gives students more freedom to choose, and it enables them to live a more non-passive life. Students can select what their lives and their first year on college would be like. Computer science student from the year would not try to find what they are truly interested in but passively accept the fate that leaning computer science is the fixed future they'll take. On the other hand freshmen with no major will consider carefully what they can choose and design their future on their own. The process is likely to be painstaking, however actively choosing the path of life will help students build their identity and passion to motivate themselves. Same student will choose challenging scheduals attending lots of classes. Others can attend diverse major class.
Secondly, major-free freshmen can create networks with diverse peope. Integration between fields is what makes a breakthrough in not only academic areas but also arts and buissiness. Major-less freshmen will easily make bonds with people with diverse interests and history. Students with major would also make bonds, but not as easily and strong as students without major would. 
Lastly, it's hard to get interested in one major until highschool graduation. Lacking life experience, highschool students often choose majors by first look or without knowing what the major is actually about. Universities in South Korea grade highschool students by their 'major compatable rate' that make highschool student lie  on their interests on the school records. First year without major will loosen this tendancy and for the students who weren't truly interested in the major they applied a second chance.</essay>

Yes, there are some comma splice errors and run-on sentences in your essay. 
Let us revise your essay while addressing these issues.

The first sentence should be revised to: "During their first year at KAIST, undergraduates do not have a specific major." 

The second sentence contains a run-on error. We can revise it like this: "Other universities have majors that do not have a specific major first year, and some universities even allow undergraduates to be free of majors until graduation." 

The third sentence contains a comma splice error. It can be revised like this: "For this reason, universities should require the first year of college to be major-free." 

In your fourth paragraph, the first sentence is a run-on sentence. You can break it up like this: "There are three primary benefits to having a major-free first year of college. First, a year without a major gives students more freedom to choose, enabling them to live a less passive life." 

The remaining sentences in the same paragraph contain errors of word choice, subject-verb agreement, and unclear pronoun reference. We can modify the paragraph to: "Students with a specific major would not try to explore their interests and would miss out on discovering their true passion. In contrast, freshmen without a specific major can make informed and thoughtful decisions about their future. Though students may face a painstaking process in making decisions, the act of actively choosing one's life path will help them build identity and motivation. Furthermore, students without a major can attend a variety of classes, challenge themselves, and gain exposure to diverse subjects."

In your fifth paragraph, the first sentence is a run-on sentence. We can revise it like this: "Secondly, by being major-free, freshmen can create networks with people of diverse interests, which can lead to breakthroughs, not just in academic areas, but also in arts and business." 

Your final paragraph contains some word choice errors, as well as pronoun reference and subject-verb agreement issues. We can revise it to: "Lastly, high school students, lacking life experience, often choose majors without knowing what they entail. Universities in South Korea grade high school students by their 'major compatible rate' and students frequently deceive examiners by lying about their interests on school records. By having a year without a major, students who were not truly interested in the major they applied for have a second chance to explore their interests." 

Overall, your essay has great ideas, and with minor revisions, it can be an impressive piece of writing.

chatgpt_after:
Yes, I can certainly provide you the corrected essay with typos in the following format:

1. "does't" -> "do not"
2. "opened major that has no specific major" -> "have majors that do not require a specific major"
3. "be free of majors until graduation" -> "be free of a major until graduation."
4. "beneficial in different reasons" -> "beneficial and has different reasons."
5. "a more less passive life" -> "a less passive life."
6. "Computer science student from the year" -> "A computer science student from the first year"
7. "active students" -> "freshmen without a major."
8. "can choose and design their future" -> "can make informed and thoughtful decisions about their future."
9. "it's hard to become interested in one major" -> "it's hard to become interested in a specific major."
10. "what the major is actually about" -> "what the major entails."
11. "major compatable rate" -> "major-compatible rate."
12. "cause high school student lie" -> "cause high school students to lie."
13. "will reduce this tendancy" -> "will reduce this tendency."
14. "who were not truly interested" -> "who were not truly interested."
15. "for a second chance" -> "a second chance to explore their interests."  

Here is the corrected text:

First-year undergraduates at KAIST do not have a specific major. Many other universities have majors that do not require a specific major in the first year, and some universities even allow undergraduates to be free of a major until graduation. For this reason, universities should require the first year of college to be major-free. There are three primary benefits to having a major-free first year of college.

First, a year without a major gives students more freedom to choose and enables them to live a less passive life. Students can select what their lives and their first year of college will be like. A computer science student from the first year might not try to explore other interests and might blindly accept that computer science is their predetermined future, instead of discovering their true passion. On the other hand, freshmen without a major can make informed and thoughtful decisions about their future. Though students may face a painstaking process in making decisions, the act of actively choosing one's life path will help them build identity and motivation. The same student will choose challenging schedules by attending lots of classes, while others can attend diverse classes in various majors.

Secondly, by being major-free, freshmen can create networks with people of diverse interests, which can lead to breakthroughs not just in academic areas but also in arts and business. Major-free freshmen will easily make bonds with people with diverse interests and history. Students with a specific major would not try to explore their interests, challenge themselves, or gain exposure to different subjects as much as freshmen without a major would.

Lastly, it's hard to become interested in a specific major until high school graduation. Lacking life experience, high school students often choose majors at first glance or without knowing what the major entails. Universities in South Korea grade high school students by their 'major-compatible rate,' which cause high school students to lie about their interests on school records. Having a year without a major will reduce this tendency and give students who were not truly interested in the major they applied for a second chance to explore their interests.

essay:
I believe that government should those most in need, not all of its citizens. There are two reasons for my opinion.
  First, when government helps all of its citizens,  ore people who are in need will be neglected. Have you ever read an article about elderly people who live alone in a very poor environment because they don't have money? These people desperately need help, but it is true that people in need don't get enough help from the government. It will be worse when government expands the range of people who get supported. I think minority of people should get a concentrated help. 
  Second, people who are very wealthy don't need any help from the government. I believe it is right for people to help each other. Rich people shouldn't receive benefits from the government. Rather, they have to pay more. It is a well-known fact that minority of super-rich people own majority of the wealth. To make our society a better place for everyone, people should be less selfish.
  These are two reasons why I believe government should help those most in need. We live in a society where the gap between the rich and the poor is very large. To overcome this, not only government but all of us should try hard, and take care of each other.

- First, by focusing aid on those most in need, the government can ensure that resources are not wasted on those who do not require it. This targeted approach can provide greater support for those struggling to make ends meet.
- Second, providing aid to the wealthy creates a disparity in the distribution of resources. The government has a responsibility to prioritize the needs of its most vulnerable citizens, rather than providing unnecessary aid to those who already have the means to support themselves.  

In both of these statements, we used similar sentence structures and parallel phrasing to make the argument clearer and more cohesive. 

Now let's move on to your conclusion. You can use parallel structure here as well to summarize your main points. For example:

- In conclusion, the government should focus its aid on those who are most in need, rather than attempting to provide assistance to all citizens. By doing so, we can ensure that resources are distributed more fairly, and that those who require the most support receive it. 

Here, we used similar phrasing to the thesis statement at the beginning of the essay, which creates a sense of closure and reinforces your argument.

prev_essay:
I believe that government should those most in need, not all of its citizens. There are two reasons for my opinion.
  Firstly, if the government tries to help everyone, it is inevitable that some of the most vulnerable people in society will be overlooked. For example, there are many elderly citizens who live alone in poverty and desperately need support. If the government's resources are spread too thin, these individuals are unlikely to get the assistance they require. Therefore, I believe that the government should concentrate its efforts on supporting the most disadvantaged members of society.  
  Secondly, it is unfair for wealthy individuals to receive government benefits when they don't need them. I think that those who have an abundance of resources should be required to contribute more to society. For instance, it is a well-established fact that a small minority of individuals possess the majority of wealth in our country. In order to create a more equitable society for everyone, I believe that the wealthy should pay higher taxes and be willing to contribute more to social welfare initiatives.  
  Overall, I believe that the government should focus its resources on aiding those who are most in need. This is particularly important given the deep divide between the rich and the poor in our society. I am confident that if we all work together and extend a helping hand to those who require it the most, we can create a better world for ourselves and for future generations.

The universities should be major free in first year of college. These days in Korea, lots of smart students who are in high scored universities like Seoul, Yonsei, or Kaist, leave their schools. It could be due to universities‚Äô system that they should choose their major before they enter to universities. Instead of this, there are lots of problems in choosing major early. Thus, universities should be required to major-free in first year of college.
At first, in high school, it is hard to choose the major. In universities, there are many major and classes. However, in high school, every students learn just few subjects like chemistry and physics. Also, they cannot get the information of major easily. Thus, there are less information of major, so students cannot choose major well. Un addition they do not have much time to think about major. Korea‚Äôs national exam ‚ÄòÏàòÎä•‚Äô is very hard and it is hard to get good grade. Due to this, high school students have to study very hard than others. Thus, they do not have time to search their dream or major. In conclusion, high school students do not have sufficient information and time to choose major, so first grade of college should be major free. 
Second, the major-free year could be provide diverse experience to students. When we choose the major, we have to choose the course related to our major, so undergraduate student‚Äôs background information could be limited. Especially, these days, the collaboration of diverse major is important. It could be help people to be more creative and think diverse way. Thus, for more experiences, the first year in college should be major free.
At next, the major-free policy could help the Korea‚Äôs education system changing. The past and current education system is not helpful to students‚Äô future. For example, in high school students study hard for ‚ÄòÏàòÎä•‚Äô. But when they finished the exam, they forgot lots of things and did not study them again. Thus, the three years of students in high school is not that efficiency. On the other hand, some students who want to be a biologist of chemist, study the Earth science or East Asian history, because these subjects are easy to them. It is not good education. When, every college change the first year to major-free, students do not have to study for get the good major. In addition, students choose the major that are highest they can get with their grade. For example, in our school, student who want to be biologist go to mechanic school, and student who want to be a physicist go to medical school. Like this, most of students in Korea, they cannot study what they want tin college. So, the first year in college should be major-free. 
In conclusion, when the first year of college become major-free, it can help high school students who are hard to choose the major due to less information and time, undergraduate students to get many experiences, and education system in Korea. There are lots of benefit than disadvantages, so first year of college should be major-free.

user: I don't know why I have to but comma at 'When' in third paragraph.
chatgpt_after:
Great question! In the sentence "When we choose the major, we have to choose the course related to our major," the word "when" is used to introduce an adverbial clause. The adverbial clause modifies the main clause by giving more information about the time when something happens. 

When an adverbial clause is introduced by a subordinating conjunction (in this case, "when"), you need to add a comma after the adverbial clause. The comma separates the subordinate clause from the main clause, so that the reader can clearly distinguish between the two parts of the sentence. 

Therefore, the sentence should be written like this: "When we choose the major, we have to choose the course related to our major."

user: I learned about run-on error, so I want to check run-on errors in my essay.
chatgpt_after:
Great! To check for run-on errors in your essay, first, you need to understand what a run-on sentence is. A run-on sentence occurs when two or more independent clauses are joined together without proper punctuation or coordinating conjunctions.

To assess your essay for run-on errors, I suggest reading it aloud and paying attention to places where you use multiple clauses or ideas that go on for an extended period. If it feels like you're saying too much in one breath, that could be a sign of a run-on sentence.

After you've identified a possible run-on sentence, check for correct punctuation and consider whether the clauses are independent of each other or whether they need to be separated or paired with appropriate coordinating conjunctions.

Now, I'd suggest you read through your essay, looking for examples of this type of error. Once you find a sentence, mark it with a highlighter or pencil, and then we can revise it together.

user:
<essay>I think the government should help all of its citizens regardless of their socioeconomic background. 
Firstly, government is an organization for all people. Government is here for everyone. It is true that when the government help people in need, it will be able to help people as much as possible, which will be very helpful for them. However, the fact that helping people in need has many positive aspects does not meas that it is okay to ‚Äònot help others‚Äô. Government only working for a small part of people and ignoring the rest should not happen. Also, I think it is unfair either. I agree to helping a bit more to the people in need. There are people who can‚Äôt live without some help of the government. There are problems that government should deal with in order to help people. However, only helping those who need help could be viewed as discriminating others. As I already wrote, government is an organization for all. Making nobody feel discriminated by the government is the way I think government should go. 
Secondly, in a realistic point of view, government could not exist only with those who are in need, so that they should take care of others. For example, government is managed by money that people pay as tax. To get much tax, they should have many people who are rich in the country. In order to keep them in the country, the country should do something for them. If the government only help those in need and ignore others, the government could not exist. Therefore, the best way to help those in need is not just helping them fully but helping them steady. 
These are the reasons why I think government should help all of its citizens regardless of their socioeconomic background.</essay>
chatgpt_after:
Great! Let's start by addressing the choppy sentences. 

Firstly, your essay has several short sentences that could be combined. Here's an example: 

Original: <sent>Government is here for everyone. It is true that when the government help people in need, it will be able to help people as much as possible, which will be very helpful for them. </sent>

Revised: <sent>The government is here for everyone, and it's true that helping people in need will be helpful for them. </sent>

Notice how I combined the first two sentences using "and" and rephrased the second sentence to make it more concise. 

Next, your essay could use more complex sentence structures using subordination and coordination. Here's an example: 

Original: <sent>There are people who can‚Äôt live without some help of the government. There are problems that government should deal with in order to help people. However, only helping those who need help could be viewed as discriminating others. </sent>

Revised: <sent>For some people, government assistance is necessary to sustain their livelihood. While it is important to acknowledge the problems that the government should address, solely assisting those in need could be perceived as discriminatory towards others. </sent>

Notice how I combined the first two sentences using "for" and inserted "while" to make the second sentence dependent on the first. 

Finally, make sure to proofread your work for grammatical errors, punctuation mistakes, and typos. 

Keep these tips in mind as you revise your essay. Good luck!

user: Today I learned about the comma rules. When there is a list that contains two or more elements, we should use commas to separate them.
chatgpt_after:
Great! It sounds like you've got a good handle on one of the most basic comma rules. Let's see if you can apply that rule to your essay. 

First, look through your essay and identify places where you have lists of two or more elements. Once you've found them, make sure that you have used commas to separate those elements. 

If you haven't used commas, add them in where necessary. For example:

Original: On my trip I visited Paris London and Rome.

Revised: On my trip, I visited Paris, London, and Rome.

If you have used commas, double-check that you've used them correctly. Remember that there should be a comma between each element in the list, and the final element should also be followed by a comma before the coordinating conjunction (e.g. and, or).

Once you're done with that step, look over your essay again to make sure that there are no places where you've used a comma incorrectly. For example:

Original: I went to the store, to get some milk.

Revised: I went to the store to get some milk.

In this case, the comma is unnecessary and should be removed.

Let me know if you have any questions, and we can work through them together.
essay:
In past, almost students of university have used their textbooks and pens. Because of this, most students had to take load when they went to listen lectures. Nowadays, however, lots of students including high school students, university students doesn‚Äôt have to take their loads like textbooks. They just take their laptop or tablet. Almost students of KAIST already have their own laptop of tablet, or both. Why many people use that in class? Let me explain why laptop/tablet are more convenient than textbooks and pens.
First of all, it is light. Things which are light have many advantages. It is less hand to pick light things than heavy things. Because of this reason, It is convenient to take whenever students go.
Second, laptop and tablet doesn‚Äôt have limit to include infinite files that are helpful to lessons or their own study. For example, lots of students use PDF when they study or listen their lectures. PDF helps students not to take various textbooks when they have various lectures on only one day.
Lastly, it can increase students‚Äô academic achievements. Specifically, just writing using their own hands have limit to write fastly. But typing using laptop is faster than hand writing. In addition, laptop and tablet can search internet like Google. Therefore, whenever students doesn‚Äôt know any informations that are important to understand their class, they can search the information by using tablet and laptop. When students sumit their homeworks to professor, laptop and tablet are convenient, because offline sumit request more time, more effort than online sumit.
In short, laptop and tablet have many advantages like weigh(for portability), infinite saving space, and increasing students‚Äô academic achievements.

prev_essay:
Advantages of making first year students major-free

 In Korea, most of the universities require the freshmen to choose their major before they start their first year. But very few of them including -IST universities like KAIST, let the first year students to be major-free. They choose their major in second year, or in the end of their first year. Even though there are many advantages and disadvantages with it, I think the first year students of college should be major-free.
 One of the most important benefit of first-year-major-free is that the freshmen can have chances to have contact with various fields of study. Some people may say major-free can make students stressed by forcing them to listen to unintersted subjects. But in the near future, we have to work on topics that are not only included to one field. We will need knowledges and perspectives of various fields, and the basic knowledge from the first year class will help overcoming it. Also, we can find unexpected interests. Learning about new fields of study may help them find their interests.
 Secondly, some other people say major-free is a waste of time for students who already decided their major, but it is not quite true. For example, despite my university is major-free in the first year, there are friends who listen to the classes for particular major. Some of them are accquiring organic, or biochemistry, and another friend is accquiring programming class for 3rd, or 4th years. Likewise, students with concrete dicision about their major can participate to such class, because it's major-'free'.
 Lastly, major-free can help first-year students meet diverse people. In most universities that require their first students to choose their major usually divides the dormitory or class by major. This prevents students to meet people from other major, who have different point of view. Major-free can make students team-up with students of other majors, and help them grow abilities to cooperate with people who think different from them.
 In conclusion, letting first-year students of college to be major-free can help them find new interests, freely listen to their intersted subjects, meet diverse people. For these reasons, I strongly believe making first-year students of universities will help the students and the society.
essay:
Advantages of making first year students be major-free

In Korea, most of the universities require the freshmen to choose their major before they start their first year. But very few of them, including -IST universities like KAIST, let the first year students be major-free. They choose their major in the second year, or at the end of their first year. Even though there are many advantages and disadvantages to it, I think the first year students of college should be major-free.

One of the most important benefits of being major-free in the first year is that freshmen can have the chance to have contact with various fields of study. Some people may say being major-free can make students stressed by forcing them to listen to uninterested subjects. But in the near future, we will have to work on topics that are not only included in one field. We will need knowledge and perspectives from various fields, and the basic knowledge from the first year classes will help in overcoming it. Also, we can find unexpected interests. Learning about new fields of study may help students find their interests.

Secondly, some other people say being major-free is a waste of time for students who have already decided their major, but it is not quite true. For example, despite my university being major-free in the first year, there are friends who attend classes for a particular major. Some of them are acquiring knowledge about organic or biochemistry, and another friend is acquiring programming classes for 3rd or 4th years. Likewise, students with a concrete decision about their major can participate in such classes because they are major-free.

Lastly, being major-free can help first-year students meet diverse people. In most universities that require their freshmen to choose their major, they usually divide the dormitories or classes by major. This prevents students from meeting people from other majors, who have different points of view. Being major-free can make students team-up with students of other majors and help develop the ability to cooperate with people who think differently from them.

In conclusion, allowing first-year college students to be major-free can help them find new interests, freely listen to their interested subjects, and meet diverse people. For these reasons, I strongly believe that allowing first-year university students to be major-free will help both the students and society.

prev_essay:
Advantages of making first year students be major-free

In Korea, most of the universities require the freshmen to choose their major before they start their first year. But very few of them, including -IST universities like KAIST, let the first year students be major-free. They choose their major in the second year, or at the end of their first year. Even though there are many advantages and disadvantages to it, I think the first year students of college should be major-free.

One of the most important benefits of being major-free in the first year is that freshmen can have the chance to have contact with various fields of study. Some people may say being major-free can make students stressed by forcing them to listen to uninterested subjects. But in the near future, we will have to work on topics that are not only included in one field. We will need knowledge and perspectives from various fields, and the basic knowledge from the first year classes will help in overcoming it. Also, we can find unexpected interests. Learning about new fields of study may help students find their interests.

Secondly, some other people say being major-free is a waste of time for students who have already decided their major, but it is not quite true. For example, despite my university being major-free in the first year, there are friends who attend classes for a particular major. Some of them are acquiring knowledge about organic or biochemistry, and another friend is acquiring programming classes for 3rd or 4th years. Likewise, students with a concrete decision about their major can participate in such classes because they are major-free.

Lastly, being major-free can help first-year students meet diverse people. In most universities that require their freshmen to choose their major, they usually divide the dormitories or classes by major. This prevents students from meeting people from other majors, who have different points of view. Being major-free can make students team-up with students of other majors and help develop the ability to cooperate with people who think differently from them.

In conclusion, allowing first-year college students to be major-free can help them find new interests, freely listen to their interested subjects, and meet diverse people. For these reasons, I strongly believe that allowing first-year university students to be major-free will help both the students and society.

I think that the government should help those most in need because of three reasons. First, the government can do things that individuals can‚Äôt. Second, it is hard for those in need to live well by their own. And last, the help of the government will make the whole society happy.
	Why do you think the government takes places at the first place? It is to do things that individuals can‚Äôt by themselves. It is hard for normal people to find those who need help, and give help to them. Helping those in need is one of the best thing that the government can do.
	Second, money comes from money. Unlike helping all of the citizens, helping particular people makes the society much more different. If the government helps all the people, the gap between the rich and the poor will not be reduced, but be intensified. There fore, the rich will be easy to maintain life, and the poor should scrub along. However, if the government help those in need, they will have a base to develop, and that‚Äôs not making the society become fixed, but making it much more different and flexible in a good way.
	Lastly, the particular help of the government will make the whole society happy. Have you seen articles that cover that most of the capital is owned by very tiny percent of the society? As it says, too much capital is unnecessarily taken by few people. For the good of much more people, the government should at least help people that are exactly the opposite side of the very tiny percent of the society that takes most of the capital. 
	Because of these three reasons, for the good for all people, I strongly believe that the government should help those most in need.

1. In the first paragraph, you could revise <sent>"the government can do things that individuals can‚Äôt"</sent> and <sent>"it is hard for those in need to live well by their own."</sent> for parallel structure. Remember to use similar grammatical structures and phrases to create balance in your writing. Now, let's move on to the sentence problems.

Read through your essay carefully and identify any sentence problems. Here are a few common sentence problems to consider:

1. Run-on sentences: When two or more sentences are joined together without proper punctuation, it creates a run-on sentence. To fix this, you could either separate the sentences or use proper punctuation, such as a comma or semicolon.

2. Sentence Fragments: A sentence fragment is an incomplete sentence that is missing a subject or verb. To fix this, you could add a subject or verb to complete the sentence.

3. Misplaced Modifiers: A misplaced modifier can create confusion or change the meaning of a sentence. To fix this, you could place the modifier next to the word it modifies or revise the sentence structure to avoid the problem.

Keep these sentence problems in mind as you review your essay for clarity and coherence.

user: then how can i say my opinion in third person's view?
chatgpt_after:
When you are writing in third person point of view, you generally should not express your own opinion by using phrases like "I think" or "I believe." Instead, you might include someone else's opinion using phrases like:

- According to [source], [opinion]
- [Name] believed that...
- Experts argue that...

For example, instead of saying "I think that the main character was foolish to make that decision," you might say something like "According to literary critic Jane Doe, the main character's decision was foolish and demonstrated their lack of critical thinking skills."

By referencing outside sources, you can convey opinions without breaking away from third person perspective. However, be sure to cite your sources appropriately if you are including quotes or ideas from someone else's work.

user:
<essay>Fast food is a type of food that is known for its quick preparation time and easy accessibility, while having lots of problems. The popularity of fast food has grown significantly since the 1950s when it was first introduced. Fast foods can be found in chain restaurants that sell only fast foods for sales. For well known chain restaurants, there are  McDonald‚Äôs, Lotteria, Burger King, and KFC.  Because these chain restaurants are in almost every place, the accessibility of fast foods are very good. However, while fast food is a convenient and affordable option for many people, it has been associated with several health problems that have many people in the society has, or has a risk of  getting those problems. In this essay, the reason why people prefer fast foods, and the effects of fast foods will be dealt with. 

One of the primary reasons for the popularity of fast food is its convenience. There are big 3 reasons why fast foods are convenient. First, fast food restaurants are typically located in busy areas or all over the world. So when people travel around the world and doesn‚Äôt have anything to eat, fast foods are one of the best choice. 

        Second, they are open for extended hours, when other restaurants are on a break time or are closed. For students or office workers that work last and are hungry, the only choice to fill one‚Äôs hunger. 

Lastly, when there is less time or inappropriate place to eat, fast food has a benefit. For people with busy schedules or who has a next schedule, like the word ‚Äúfast food‚Äù, the cooking process and distribution process are so fast, so that it's good to fill up the energy quickly. Additionally, fast food is easy to eat while driving or walking, further contributing to its convenience factor.

The low cost of fast food is one of the primary reasons why it has become so popular among people of all ages and backgrounds. Why are fast foods cheap? There are several reasons. Fast food restaurants tend to have simple menus with limited options, which helps to reduce costs by minimizing the number of ingredients needed and simplifying the cooking process. They also tend to rely on pre-packaged and pre-portioned ingredients, which reduces waste and helps to keep costs down.

Also, fast food restaurants typically have lower overhead costs than sit-down restaurants. They often operate in high-traffic areas with lower rent costs, and they require less space for seating and dining areas. This allows them to focus on the food preparation and service, rather than on creating an elaborate dining experience.
For these these reasons, fast food restaurants offer a quick, convenient, and affordable option for people who are looking for a quick bite to eat without breaking the bank. While fast food has been associated with a range of health problems, there are also some benefits to its low cost.
One of the most significant benefits of the low cost of fast food is its affordability for people on a tight budget. For many people, fast food is the only viable option when it comes to eating out. Eating at a sit-down restaurant or purchasing groceries and preparing meals at home can be expensive, and not everyone has the resources or time to do so. In these cases, fast food can be a lifesaver, providing an affordable and convenient option for people who are on a tight budget.

However, while fast food is convenient and affordable, it has been linked to several health problems. One of the most significant health issues associated with fast food is obesity. Fast food is often high in calories, fat, and sugar, which can contribute to weight gain. Studies have shown that people who eat fast food regularly are more likely to be overweight or obese than those who do not. Moreover, fast food is often high in salt, which can lead to high blood pressure and other health problems.

Another health problem associated with fast food is diabetes. Fast food is often high in carbohydrates, which can cause blood sugar levels to spike. Over time, this can lead to insulin resistance and diabetes. A diet high in fast food can also increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Fast food is also linked to heart disease. Fast food is often high in saturated and trans fats, which can increase cholesterol levels and lead to the buildup of plaque in the arteries. This can result in heart disease, heart attacks, and strokes. In addition, fast food consumption has been associated with an increased risk of certain cancers, including breast, colon, and prostate cancer.

Moreover, fast food has been linked to mental health problems, including depression and anxiety. This is thought to be due to the high levels of sugar and fat in fast food, which can affect mood and contribute to mental health problems. Fast food consumption has also been associated with poor academic performance in children and teenagers, potentially due to the negative effects of a poor diet on cognitive function.

Despite the negative effects of fast food, it remains a popular choice for many people. This may be due in part to the addictive qualities of fast food, which can make it difficult for people to resist. Additionally, fast food is often marketed to children and teenagers through targeted advertising and promotions, which can make it an appealing choice for young people.

Aside from health problems, fast food has other negative effects as well. For instance, it can harm the environment due to the generation of large amounts of waste, including packaging, food waste, and plastic utensils. This waste contributes to pollution and can have adverse impacts on wildlife. Additionally, fast food chains can negatively impact local economies, as they can drive smaller, locally-owned restaurants out of business, leading to job losses and a decrease in economic activity in the local community.

        Fast food, with its easy accessibility and affordability in both urban and rural areas, provides a quick source of energy. However, despite the convenience it offers, frequent consumption of fast food can lead to various negative impacts, most notably health issues. The high salt and fat content of fast food can contribute to a range of health problems, including heart disease, diabetes, and even mental health conditions such as depression.</essay>

Next, in the body of the essay, you have discussed the reasons for the popularity of fast food, the low cost of fast food, and the negative health effects of fast food. However, you could improve the structure of the essay by further dividing these sections into subheadings. This would make it easier for the reader to follow your argument.

Furthermore, there are some grammatical errors and awkward phrasings throughout the essay. It would be beneficial to revise and edit your sentences to make sure they are clear and concise.

Lastly, the conclusion could be strengthened by reemphasizing the main points made in the essay and leaving the reader with a final thought or call to action.

In summary, some areas that could be revised include adding a clear thesis statement in the introduction, organizing the body of the essay with subheadings, improving grammar and sentence structure, and strengthening the conclusion. Keep up the good work!

The low cost of fast food is one of the primary reasons why it has become so popular among people of all ages and backgrounds. Why are fast foods cheap? There are several reasons. Fast food restaurants tend to have simple menus with limited options, which helps to reduce costs by minimizing the number of ingredients needed and simplifying the cooking process. They also tend to rely on pre-packaged and pre-portioned ingredients, which reduces waste and helps to keep costs down.

Also, fast food restaurants typically have lower overhead costs than sit-down restaurants. They often operate in high-traffic areas with lower rent costs, and they require less space for seating and dining areas. This allows them to focus on the food preparation and service, rather than on creating an elaborate dining experience.
For these these reasons, fast food restaurants offer a quick, convenient, and affordable option for people who are looking for a quick bite to eat without breaking the bank. While fast food has been associated with a range of health problems, there are also some benefits to its low cost.
One of the most significant benefits of the low cost of fast food is its affordability for people on a tight budget. For many people, fast food is the only viable option when it comes to eating out. In these cases, fast food can be a lifesaver, providing an affordable and convenient option for people who are on a tight budget.

However, while fast food is convenient and affordable, it has been linked to several health problems. One of the most significant health issues associated with fast food is obesity. Fast food is often high in calories, fat, and sugar, which can contribute to weight gain. Studies have shown that people who eat fast food regularly are more likely to be overweight or obese than those who do not. Moreover, fast food is often high in salt, which can lead to high blood pressure and other health problems.

Another health problem associated with fast food is diabetes. Fast food is often high in carbohydrates, which can cause blood sugar levels to spike. Over time, this can lead to insulin resistance and diabetes. A diet high in fast food can also increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Fast food is also linked to heart disease. Fast food is often high in saturated and trans fats, which can increase cholesterol levels and lead to the buildup of plaque in the arteries. This can result in heart disease, heart attacks, and strokes. In addition, fast food consumption has been associated with an increased risk of certain cancers, including breast, colon, and prostate cancer.

Moreover, fast food has been linked to mental health problems, including depression and anxiety. This is thought to be due to the high levels of sugar and fat in fast food, which can affect mood and contribute to mental health problems. Fast food consumption has also been associated with poor academic performance in children and teenagers, potentially due to the negative effects of a poor diet on cognitive function.

Despite the negative effects of fast food, it remains a popular choice for many people. This may be due in part to the addictive qualities of fast food, which can make it difficult for people to resist. Additionally, fast food is often marketed to children and teenagers through targeted advertising and promotions, which can make it an appealing choice for young people.

Aside from health problems, fast food has other negative effects as well. For instance, it can harm the environment due to the generation of large amounts of waste, including packaging, food waste, and plastic utensils. This waste contributes to pollution and can have adverse impacts on wildlife. Additionally, fast food chains can negatively impact local economies, as they can drive smaller, locally-owned restaurants out of business, leading to job losses and a decrease in economic activity in the local community.

	Fast food, with its easy accessibility and affordability in both urban and rural areas, provides a quick source of energy. However, despite the convenience it offers, frequent consumption of fast food can lead to various negative impacts, most notably health issues. The high salt and fat content of fast food can contribute to a range of health problems, including heart disease, diabetes, and even mental health conditions such as depression.

1. Introduction - Try to rephrase your sentences to sound more professional. For example, you might consider changing "while having lots of problems" to "though associated with various health risks". Also, try to limit your introduction to two or three sentences.

- "For well known chain restaurants" should be "For well-known chain restaurants"

- "For these these reasons" should be "For these reasons"

4. Conclusion - Like your introduction, try to rephrase your conclusion to sound more professional. Also, try to summarize your essay in one or two sentences.

I hope these suggestions help you to revise your essay effectively. Let me know if you have any questions!
