essay:
Fast food is a type of food that is known for its quick preparation time and easy accessibility, though associated with various health risks. The popularity of fast food has grown significantly since the 1950s when it was first introduced. Fast foods can be found in chain restaurants that sell only fast foods for sales. For well-known chain restaurants, there are  McDonald‚Äôs, Lotteria, Burger King, and KFC.  Because these chain restaurants are in almost every place, the accessibility of fast foods are very good. However, while fast food is a convenient and affordable option for many people, it has been associated with several health problems that have many people in the society have, or have a risk of  getting those problems. In this essay, the reason why people prefer fast foods, and the effects of fast foods will be dealt with. 

One of the primary reasons for the popularity of fast food is its convenience. There are big 3 reasons why fast foods are convenient. First, fast food restaurants are typically located in busy areas or all over the world. So when people travel around the world and don‚Äôt have anything to eat, fast foods are one of the best choice. 

        Second, they are open for extended hours, when other restaurants are on a break time or are closed. For students or office workers that work last and are hungry, the only choice to fill one‚Äôs hunger. 

Lastly, when there is less time or inappropriate place to eat, fast food has a benefit. For people with busy schedules or who has a next schedule, like the word ‚Äúfast food‚Äù, the cooking process and distribution process are so fast, so that it's good to fill up the energy quickly. Additionally, fast food is easy to eat while driving or walking, further contributing to its convenience factor.

The low cost of fast food is one of the primary reasons why it has become so popular among people of all ages and backgrounds. Why are fast foods cheap? There are several reasons. Fast food restaurants tend to have simple menus with limited options, which helps to reduce costs by minimizing the number of ingredients needed and simplifying the cooking process. They also tend to rely on pre-packaged and pre-portioned ingredients, which reduces waste and helps to keep costs down.

Also, fast food restaurants typically have lower overhead costs than sit-down restaurants. They often operate in high-traffic areas with lower rent costs, and they require less space for seating and dining areas. This allows them to focus on the food preparation and service, rather than on creating an elaborate dining experience.
For these these reasons, fast food restaurants offer a quick, convenient, and affordable option for people who are looking for a quick bite to eat without breaking the bank. While fast food has been associated with a range of health problems, there are also some benefits to its low cost.
One of the most significant benefits of the low cost of fast food is its affordability for people on a tight budget. For many people, fast food is the only viable option when it comes to eating out. Eating at a sit-down restaurant or purchasing groceries and preparing meals at home can be expensive, and not everyone has the resources or time to do so. In these cases, fast food can be a lifesaver, providing an affordable and convenient option for people who are on a tight budget.

However, while fast food is convenient and affordable, it has been linked to several health problems. One of the most significant health issues associated with fast food is obesity. Fast food is often high in calories, fat, and sugar, which can contribute to weight gain. Studies have shown that people who eat fast food regularly are more likely to be overweight or obese than those who do not. Moreover, fast food is often high in salt, which can lead to high blood pressure and other health problems.

Another health problem associated with fast food is diabetes. Fast food is often high in carbohydrates, which can cause blood sugar levels to spike. Over time, this can lead to insulin resistance and diabetes. A diet high in fast food can also increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Fast food is also linked to heart disease. Fast food is often high in saturated and trans fats, which can increase cholesterol levels and lead to the buildup of plaque in the arteries. This can result in heart disease, heart attacks, and strokes. In addition, fast food consumption has been associated with an increased risk of certain cancers, including breast, colon, and prostate cancer.

Moreover, fast food has been linked to mental health problems, including depression and anxiety. This is thought to be due to the high levels of sugar and fat in fast food, which can affect mood and contribute to mental health problems. Fast food consumption has also been associated with poor academic performance in children and teenagers, potentially due to the negative effects of a poor diet on cognitive function.

Despite the negative effects of fast food, it remains a popular choice for many people. This may be due in part to the addictive qualities of fast food, which can make it difficult for people to resist. Additionally, fast food is often marketed to children and teenagers through targeted advertising and promotions, which can make it an appealing choice for young people.

Aside from health problems, fast food has other negative effects as well. For instance, it can harm the environment due to the generation of large amounts of waste, including packaging, food waste, and plastic utensils. This waste contributes to pollution and can have adverse impacts on wildlife. Additionally, fast food chains can negatively impact local economies, as they can drive smaller, locally-owned restaurants out of business, leading to job losses and a decrease in economic activity in the local community.

	Fast food, with its easy accessibility and affordability in both urban and rural areas, provides a quick source of energy. However, despite the convenience it offers, frequent consumption of fast food can lead to various negative impacts, most notably health issues. The high salt and fat content of fast food can contribute to a range of health problems, including heart disease, diabetes, and even mental health conditions such as depression.

user: Yes because I forgot.
chatgpt_after:
Sure thing! Here are some common capitalization rules to keep in mind:

1. Capitalize the first letter in a sentence.

2. Proper nouns should always be capitalized. These include the names of people, places, organizations, and things.

3. Titles of people, like President or Doctor, should be capitalized when they come before the person's name, but not when they come after (e.g., President Obama vs. Barack Obama, MD).

4. Titles of books, articles, songs, movies, and other creative works should have the first letter of each major word capitalized. Minor words such as "and" and "the" are not capitalized, unless they are the first word in the title.

5. Capitalize the important words in titles, including the first and last words, as well as all nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, and pronouns.

6. Capitalize days of the week, months, and holidays.

7. Capitalize the first word of a sentence that is a direct quote.

Keep in mind that there are many more rules of capitalization, and it is always best to use a reference or guide to ensure that you use proper capitalization.

4. "Effective for education" is a bit vague. It may be helpful to clarify what aspects of education you are referring to, such as student engagement, improved learning outcomes, or cost savings. 

Does that help?
prev_essay:
Increasingly, schools across the nation are embracing the use of personal technology in the classroom. According to a recent study, over 75% of middle schools now allow students to use their own personal devices, and some teachers even provide them. However, this has been controversial because people were not sure whether it is effective for education or not. The reason why governments still allow them to use such electric devices, even though there are some controversies, is because it has some advantages that can not be taken only with general books or notebooks.
 First, it is easier to write and erase letters since digital notebooks allow one to remove words that are written as a mistake, and the size of the letters can be changed easily, unlike paper notebooks. Furthermore, digital notebooks have more color options, allowing users to include various color pens.
 Second, they are useful to search for necessary information. It is hard to find some concepts in books during class; however, it will be much faster to look for them online. Therefore, extra time after a particular class to help students understand what the teachers taught would not be required since they can discover more documents that can help them learn specific concepts.
 Third, each of the students in a certain class can be connected. As a result, they can share useful information and have debates about what they learned during the day, offering high school students the opportunity to experience teamwork or the cooperation projects usually shown in colleges earlier.

user:
Peer edit a paragraph below. Don't forget annotation like [1],[2], etc.

<para> For decades, gas turbine engines have been played an important role over various fields, such as jet engines, rockets, power plants, etc. Among them, gas turbines for power generation is one of the main methods of energy generation nowadays. In terms of energy production, the gas turbine method has several benefits compared to other plants, including convenience of starting engine, large power output per mass, low pollutant emission such as carbon dioxide, nitrous oxides(NOx), etc. Especially for emission, fuels without carbon, for instance, hydrogen and ammonia, is rising as carbon neutrality policies came into effect gradually. [2] To fulfill low-emission system, gas turbine plants with fuel lean-burn can play key roll, which means combustion with excess of air, in addition to efficiency for using fuel. Currently those gas turbine combustors in industrial use adopt premixed flame for the most, which combusts with fuel and oxidizer completely before ignition, because of high effectiveness and low emission compared to diffusion flame, which is fuel and oxidizer separately enter the combustion chamber. Also, there are several types of gas turbine combustors; can type, cannular type, can-anunlar type, and annular type. For can-annular type combustors, which combined type and annular type combustor, are commonly used on industrial fields. There are some advantages of can-annular combustors; easy to maintain as each can be removed easily and wored on independently. [3] 
On the other hand, there are some risks about fuel lean premixed combustors, including a risk due to premixed flame, which have been resolved to some extent today. The most challenging problem is combustion instability, in presence of lean-burn. Moreover to the combustion instability of the combustor itself, the can-annular type combustors have a additional combustion instability about area called a "cross-talk section" that interacts due to the joining at the end of each combustor as Fig.1 shown. This area is used to equalize the pressure in each can [3]. Although instability of can-annular combustor is notable, relatively little research were conducted about combustion instabililty with respect to combustor-to-combustor interaction. 
The purpose of this paper is to understand basics of characteristics of combustion instabillity, interaction between combustors that could occur in can-annular combustors as well as, comprehending emissions in gas turbine combustor. In the end, we can be expected to use this literature as a reference at future works. 
[1] K. Moon , H. Jegal , C. Yoon , K.T. Kim , Cross-talk-interaction-induced combustion instabilities in a can-annular lean-premixed combustor configuration, Com- bust. Flame 220 (2020) 178‚Äì188.
[2] Ministry of environment republic of Korea, South Korea to move towards the goal of carbon neutrality by 2050, 2022.
[3] M. P. BOYCE, Advanced industrial gas turbines for power generation, The Boyce Consultancy Group, LLC, USA, 2012</para>

Second, when you discuss the advantages of can-annular combustors, you provide [3] as a reference, but it is unclear which specific information you are referencing. To improve the clarity of your paragraph, I would suggest revising this sentence to indicate which advantage you are discussing and adding an appropriate annotation. Finally, you cite [1] as a reference in your concluding sentence, but it may be helpful to provide some additional context about how this reference relates to the rest of the paragraph. Other than that, you did an excellent job with presenting the information in a clear and concise manner.

<essay>The recent advancements in the synthesis of blue-light emitting quantum dots were made with different types of materials. Metal halide perovskites, particularly lead halide perovskites, are the most well-known material used for the synthesis of blue quantum dots.1 But because of the toxicity of lead, perovskites containing other types of metal are being emerged as an alternative to lead halide perovskites.2 Moreover, producing III-V type blue quantum dots using indium phosphide (InP) is also being studied.3 In this review, we will be discussing the properties of quantum dots synthesized with diverse materials, and compare the relative advantages and disadvantages of each type. Through this analysis, we will be able to assess the quantum dots whether they are suitable for use in light-emitting diode (LED) displays. The articles that could be discussed in this review were searched via Google Scholar. To focus on the quantum dot that consists the basis of QLEDs rather than the LED itself, we excluded the papers that contained insufficient information about the properties of quantum dots. Also, we narrowed the range of papers to less than 10 years after publication, since we will be discussing the recent advancements of blue quantum dots. Then, we selected one specific article from each basis material of quantum dots we will be dealing with: lead halide perovskites, lead-free halide perovskites, and InP. For the sake of credibility, we chose papers that were cited by other articles more than 50 times. After the whole process, we selected one paper that conducted studies about copper (II)-doped cesium lead halide perovskite quantum dots, one paper that did research on antimony halide perovskite quantum dots, and one paper that dealt with InP/ZnS/ZnS core/shell quantum dots.</essay>
Here is it. Please check any grammar or spelling mistakes.
chatgpt_after:
It looks like the paragraph is well-written, and I didn't detect any grammar or spelling mistakes. However, there are a few minor revisions that could make the paragraph even clearer:

- In the first sentence, it might be better to say "blue-light emitting" instead of "blue-light emitting" for clarity.
- In the second sentence, it might be clearer to say <sent>"Metal halide perovskites, particularly lead halide perovskites, are the most well-known materials used for synthesizing blue quantum dots"</sent> for clarity.
- In the third sentence, it might be clearer to say <sent>"Moreover, InP is being studied as a means to produce III-V type blue quantum dots"</sent> for clarity.
- In the seventh sentence, it might be clearer to say <sent>"For the sake of credibility, we chose papers that had been cited by other articles at least 50 times"</sent> instead of <sent>"were cited by other articles more than 50 times."</sent> 

Overall, though, good job! The paragraph is well-written and provides a clear overview of what you learned in the class.

user:
<essay>The synthesis of blue quantum dots (QDs) has been studied with a variety of materials used. Blue quantum dots commonly have sizes of 2-6 nm and a peak wavelength of 400-500 nm. In order to have short wavelengths, these QDs are extremely small, so there exists difficulty in synthesizing them due to several factors such as Ostwald ripening, surface ligand effect, and quantum confinement effect. Depending on the precursors used, the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of these quantum dots may also vary. PLQY is the ratio of the number of photons emitted through photoluminescence to the number of photons absorbed by the material, and is an important criterion for determining the efficiency of QDs. In this section, three recent studies regarding the synthesis of blue quantum dots will be presented. Along with the efficiency of the quantum dots, the struggle for minimizing the use of harmful elements is also being emphasized, so studies about CdSe quantum dots which contain hazardous cadmium will be excluded for this section.
One major example of blue quantum dot research is the use of indium and phosphorus precursors, resulting in indium phosphide (InP) QDs which are a type of III-V QDs. In 2020, Zhang et al.[1] reported the synthesis of blue InP quantum dots which have a structure of an InP core and a ZnS shell. For the core, (DMA)3P, ZnI2, and InI3 were used, while for the shell, zinc stearate and 1-dodecanethiol were used. The use of (DMA)3P is highly advantageous because it has high stability when exposed in the air and does not generate toxic PH3¬¨ gas. Since InP core by itself has low photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY), ZnS which has a large bandgap as a shell can enhance the PLQY up to 45%. The resulting quantum dots had an emission wavelength of 468 nm, which grants the QD to have a blue emission. What is striking in this study was that this wavelength of 468 nm was the shortest wavelength among the reported InP quantum dots at the time. Moreover, full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) was 47 nm, which is considered narrow among blue InP quantum dots.
Meanwhile, other groups of researchers focused on the use of metal halide perovskites for the synthesis of blue QDs, owing to their high stability and excellent photophysical. In 2019, Bi et al.[2] reported that CsPb1-xCuxX3 (X = Br, Br/Cl) perovskite QDs have a potential for being used as blue QDs that possess great optical properties. CsPb1-xCuxX3 perovskite QDs are synthesized by doping Cu2+ ions to the CsPbX3 quantum dots. The larger Pb2+ ions are substituted with smaller Cu2+ ions, leading to a contraction of the octahedral structure and eventually a much more stable lattice. These blue quantum dots show an emission peak in the range of 450-460 nm, accompanied by a narrow PL linewidth. The PLQY was as high as 95% when the x value was 0.07. In particular, these doped quantum dots had high thermal stability due to the stability of the modified lattice structure. The CsPb0.93Cu0.07Br3 QDs retained their PLQY value to 35% under annealing temperatures of 250oC, while the undoped QDs showed a sharp decrease in their PLQY value to 1% at same temperatures. The superb optical properties and high thermal stabilities with the use of metal halide perovskites may pave the way for developing blue-emitting optoelectronic devices with improved stability.
Metal halide perovskites surely account for a crucial part in the blue quantum dot synthesis study. However, the problem with these quantum dots is the fact that metal halide perovskites mostly consist of lead ions, which are notorious for toxicity to human bodies. To cope with this issue, a number of researchers aimed to reduce or even eliminate the lead part of these perovskites by substituting lead with other components. For instance, in 2017, Zhang et al.[3] reported the synthesis of blue quantum dots using lead-free Cs3Sb2Br9. These inorganic antimony halide perovskite quantum dots are synthesized via modifying the structure of traditional CsSbBr3 perovskites, by moving every third Sb layer along <111> direction. The QDs resulted in an emission peak of 410 nm, and the PLQY of 46% could be obtained. This value of PLQY was notable in that it was much higher than that of the counterparts with similar emission peaks. The high value of PLQY can be attributed to the higher proportion of Br that reduces the surface trapper effect, and a large exciton binding energy. In addition, the FWHM value was 41 nm, which is also a much improved value compared to previous studies.</essay>
chatgpt_after:
I did not identify any major grammar mistakes or awkward expressions in your draft. However, I noticed a few minor points that I would like to clarify or suggest.

- In the first sentence, you might rephrase <sent>"Blue quantum dots commonly have sizes of 2-6 nm and a peak wavelength of 400-500 nm"</sent> as <sent>"The peak wavelength of blue quantum dots ranges from 400-500 nm, with sizes typically around 2-6 nm."</sent>
- In the second sentence, you could simplify <sent>"so there exists difficulty in synthesizing them due to several factors such as Ostwald ripening, surface ligand effect, and quantum confinement effect"</sent> to <sent>"Synthesizing blue quantum dots is challenging due to factors like ripening, ligands, and confinement."</sent>
- In the fourth sentence, you could clarify the definition of "photoluminescence quantum yield" by adding "per absorbed photon" after "number of photons emitted through photoluminescence."
- In the paragraph about indium phosphide quantum dots, you could change "which grants the QD to have a blue emission" to "resulting in blue emission."
- In the paragraph about metal halide perovskite quantum dots, you could add "are" after "CsPb1-xCuxX3" in the third sentence.
- In the third paragraph, you could rephrase <sent>"Metal halide perovskites surely account for a crucial part in the blue quantum dot synthesis study"</sent> as <sent>"Metal halide perovskites play a critical role in the synthesis of blue quantum dots."</sent>
- Finally, in the last sentence, you might rephrase the comparison to previous studies by saying "The FWHM value of 41 nm is an improvement over earlier studies."

In order to have short wavelengths, these QDs are extremely small, so there exists difficulty in synthesizing them due to several factors such as Ostwald ripening, surface ligand effect, and quantum confinement effect. Depending on the precursors used, the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of these quantum dots may also vary. PLQY is the ratio of the number of photons emitted through photoluminescence to the number of photons absorbed by the material, and is an important criterion for determining the efficiency of QDs. In this section, three recent studies regarding the synthesis of blue quantum dots will be presented. Along with the efficiency of the quantum dots, the struggle for minimizing the use of harmful elements is also being emphasized, so studies about CdSe quantum dots which contain hazardous cadmium will be excluded for this section.
One major example of blue quantum dot research is the use of indium and phosphorus precursors, resulting in indium phosphide (InP) QDs which are a type of III-V QDs. In 2020, Zhang et al.[1] reported the synthesis of blue InP quantum dots which have a structure of an InP core and a ZnS shell. For the core, (DMA)3P, ZnI2, and InI3 were used, while for the shell, zinc stearate and 1-dodecanethiol were used. The use of (DMA)3P is highly advantageous because it has high stability when exposed in the air and does not generate toxic PH3¬¨ gas. Since InP core by itself has low photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY), ZnS which has a large bandgap as a shell can enhance the PLQY up to 45%. The resulting quantum dots had an emission wavelength of 468 nm, which grants the QD to have a blue emission. What is striking in this study was that this wavelength of 468 nm was the shortest wavelength among the reported InP quantum dots at the time. Moreover, full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) was 47 nm, which is considered narrow among blue InP quantum dots.
Meanwhile, other groups of researchers focused on the use of metal halide perovskites for the synthesis of blue QDs, owing to their high stability and excellent photophysical. In 2019, Bi et al.[2] reported that CsPb1-xCuxX3 (X = Br, Br/Cl) perovskite QDs have a potential for being used as blue QDs that possess great optical properties. CsPb1-xCuxX3 perovskite QDs are synthesized by doping Cu2+ ions to the CsPbX3 quantum dots. The larger Pb2+ ions are substituted with smaller Cu2+ ions, leading to a contraction of the octahedral structure and eventually a much more stable lattice. These blue quantum dots show an emission peak in the range of 450-460 nm, accompanied by a narrow PL linewidth. The PLQY was as high as 95% when the x value was 0.07. In particular, these doped quantum dots had high thermal stability due to the stability of the modified lattice structure. The CsPb0.93Cu0.07Br3 QDs retained their PLQY value to 35% under annealing temperatures of 250oC, while the undoped QDs showed a sharp decrease in their PLQY value to 1% at same temperatures. The superb optical properties and high thermal stabilities with the use of metal halide perovskites may pave the way for developing blue-emitting optoelectronic devices with improved stability.
Metal halide perovskites surely account for a crucial part in the blue quantum dot synthesis study. However, the problem with these quantum dots is the fact that metal halide perovskites mostly consist of lead ions, which are notorious for toxicity to human bodies. To cope with this issue, a number of researchers aimed to reduce or even eliminate the lead part of these perovskites by substituting lead with other components. For instance, in 2017, Zhang et al.[3] reported the synthesis of blue quantum dots using lead-free Cs3Sb2Br9. These inorganic antimony halide perovskite quantum dots are synthesized via modifying the structure of traditional CsSbBr3 perovskites, by moving every third Sb layer along <111> direction. The QDs resulted in an emission peak of 410 nm, and the PLQY of 46% could be obtained. This value of PLQY was notable in that it was much higher than that of the counterparts with similar emission peaks. The high value of PLQY can be attributed to the higher proportion of Br that reduces the surface trapper effect, and a large exciton binding energy. In addition, the FWHM value was 41 nm, which is also a much improved value compared to previous studies.

user: <essay>In this work, we have delved into some of the most prominent advancements in the development of quantum dots that emits blue light, with diverse materials being used as precursors. In each type of quantum dots, we have discussed the synthesis methods, the emission peak, the PLQY values, and the relative advantages of using the particular materials. InP, CsPb1-xCuxX3, and Cs3Sb2Br9 all showed an emission peak at 400-500 nm, and resulted in PLQY values over 40%. It can be estimated that blue quantum dot studies of each type had their own advantages. In the case of InP quantum dots, the research group was able to obtain blue quantum dots that are highly stable and do not generate toxic PH3¬¨ gas. For the researchers who synthesized CsPb1-xCuxX3 (X = Br, Br/Cl) perovskite QDs, a particularly high PLQY value of 95% can be obtained, which is more than twofold of their rival candidates. Lastly, Cs3Sb2Br9 perovskite QDs dealt with the issue of the inclusion of toxic lead in lead halide perovskite quantum dots. Therefore, it is promising that the ultimate goal of synthesizing blue quantum dots which possess high efficiency and do not contain any hazardous components can be achieved in various routes. These blue-emitting quantum dots may be further applied to the development of blue-light emitting devices such as QLEDs, and are promising for granting these devices of high EQE (external quantum efficiency) and long lifetimes. Still, the current development in blue quantum dots lag behind in the properties of the red and green counterparts. Hence, future studies may focus on the synthesis of blue quantum dots with a specific target peak wavelength, having much more improved values of PLQY and FWHM. In addition, the endeavor for minimizing the use of harmful chemicals should also be accompanied for the sake of protecting the environment and reducing health risks.</essay>

user: <essay>There was a Midterm semester feedback survey for CC500: Scientific Writing for Computer Sciences. The survey responses were collected from 19 anonymous students. The survey is composed of four sections each section described in Tabe 1 to 4 respectively. Table 1 shows the time spent on doing four different tasks to prepare for the CC500 class. Completing writing tasks took the longest time, with a majority of the students taking longer than 2 hours to finish the homework. Then it is followed by reading the text most students take at least an hour to complete it. Table 2 shows students‚Äô thoughts on the video content. Regarding understandability, helpfulness, video length, and overall satisfaction, all students were positive about the video content. There are 0 responses of strongly disagreeing, disagreeing, and neither agreeing nor disagreeing on every four attributes. Furthermore, more percentage of students strongly agreed with the video content appropriateness than agree. This indicates that students are very satisfied with the current video content. The responses on the appropriateness of textbook content in four attributes (understandability, helpfulness, content amount, and overall satisfaction) are depicted in Table 3. Unlike video content, with all affirmative feedback, 18% of students disagreed that the amount of reading is appropriate. This can be related to the data 57.8% of students spent more than 1 hour reading the text, even 1 student taking more than 4 hours in Table 1. Table 4 presents responses on classroom content in five attributes (understandability, time spent on checking homework, interaction between students, interaction between teacher and students, and overall satisfaction). All students at least agreed that the class is understandable and were overall satisfied. However, 10.5% of students neither agreed nor disagreed with the time spent on checking homework. This relates to the additional feedback from a student claiming that ‚Äútoo much things‚Äù are to be discussed and that sometimes we ‚Äúskip half of the activities‚Äù. In conclusion, all students were generally satisfied with the class. However, around 20% of the students thought the time spent reading the text took too long. A way is to shorten the homework.</essay>

This is still a significant percentage, but it's not a majority.

user:
Summary: Generating natural Chitchat dialogues requires high-level decisions that neural language models (NLM) struggle to learn. Therefore, control; the ability to specify desired attributes of the text at test time, is important to fix errors. This paper investigated how controlling four low-level attributes (repetition, specificity, response-relatedness, question-asking) of generated text, changes human judgment on eight conversational quality aspects (avoiding repetition, interestingness, making sense, fluency, listening, inquisitiveness, humanness, engagingness). The paper used two methods Conditional Training (CT) and Weighted Decoding (WD) to control the four low-level attributes and found that while controlling question-asking, repetition had positive effects on human judgment aspects, increasing specificity decreased making sense and fluency while increasing response-relatedness decreased making sense, fluency, humanness, and engagingness. Therefore, though controlling can increase human engagement, we must have a careful balance between the four low-level attributes.

Evaluation: The authors did a great job of exploring how low-level attributes affect human judgment factors. Their finding that humanness and engagingness can be very different was very interesting. Also, supplementary materials were very helpful in understanding the specific experimental procedures. However, how they came up with the four low-level attributes and why they evaluated the 8 human judgments is unclear which is a critical part of this study. For example, groundedness or trustworthiness is an important factor. Also, there is a limit that human evaluation is very subjective. Factors like interestingness are hard to measure and inherently dependent on each person.

2. Instead of saying "Therefore, control," I would suggest changing it to something like "Therefore, having control" or "Therefore, possessing the ability to control," as it would make the sentence flow better.

Overall, though, your writing is well-organized and easy to understand. Great job!

The paper used two methods Conditional Training (CT) and Weighted Decoding (WD) to control the four low-level attributes and found that while controlling question-asking, repetition had positive effects on human judgment aspects, increasing specificity decreased making sense and fluency while increasing response-relatedness decreased making sense, fluency, humanness, and engagingness. Therefore, though controlling can increase human engagement, we must have a careful balance between the four low-level attributes.


Evaluation:
The authors did a great job of exploring how low-level attributes affect human judgment factors. Their finding that humanness and engagingness can be very different was very interesting. Also, supplementary materials were very helpful in understanding the specific experimental procedures. However, how they came up with the four low-level attributes and why they evaluated the 8 human judgments is unclear which is a critical part of this study. For example, groundedness or trustworthiness is an important factor. Also, there is a limit that human evaluation is very subjective. Factors like interestingness are hard to measure and inherently dependent on each person.

essay:
This paper introduces a parametrically parsimonious model for yield curves that has the ability to represent the shapes generally associated with yield curves: monotonic, humped, and S shaped. We find that the model explains 96% of the variation in bill yields across maturities during the period 1981-83. The movement of the parameters through time reflects and confirms a change in Federal Reserve monetary policy in late 1982. The ability of the fitted curves to predict the price of the long-term Treasury bond with a correlation of .96 suggests that the model captures important at- tributes of the yield/ maturity relation.

The need for a parsimonious model of the yield curve was recognized by Milton Friedman (1977, p. 22) when he stated, "Students of statistical demand functions might find it more productive to examine how the whole term structure of yields can be described more compactly by a few parameters." The purpose of this paper is to introduce a simple, parsimonious model that is flexible enough to represent the range of shapes generally associated with yield curves: mono- tonic, humped, and S shaped. The ability of the model to fit U.S. Treasury bill yields and to predict the price of a long-term Treasury bond suggests to us that the model succeeds in the objective set by Friedman. Potential applications of parsimonious yield curve models include demand functions (Friedman had in mind money demand), testing of theories of the term structure of interest rates, and graphic display for informative purposes. The fitting of yield curves to yield/maturity data goes back at least to the pioneering efforts of David Durand (1942), whose method of fitting was to draw a monotonic envelope under the scatter of points in a way that seemed to him subjectively reasonable. Yield may be transformed to present value, and J. Huston McCulloch (1971, 1975) has proposed approximating the present value function by a piecewise polynomial spline fitted to price data. Gary Shea (1982, 1985) has shown that the resulting yield function tends to bend sharply toward the end of the maturity range observed in the sample. This would seem to be a most unlikely property of a true yield curve relation and also suggests that these models would not be useful for prediction outside the sample maturity range. Other researchers have fitted a variety of parametric models to yield curves, including Cohen, Kramer, and Waugh (1966), Fisher (1966), Echols and Elliott (1976), Dobson (1978), Heller and Khan (1979), and Chambers, Carleton, and Waldman (1984). Some of these are based on polynomial regression, and all include at least a linear term that would force extrapolated very long term rates to be unboundedly large (either positive or negative) despite their abilities to fit closely within the range of the data. Vasicek and Fong (1982) have recommended exponential splines as an alternative to polynomial splines. In a comparison of the two spline methodologies, Shea (1984) finds that exponential splines are subject to the same shortcomings that polynomial splines are, essentially because polynomial splines are used after a change of variables. Students of the term to maturity structure of interest rates have invariably described yield curves that are essentially monotonic, humped, or, occasionally, S shaped. This consistency is strikingly evident in the long historical record of subjectively drawn curves presented by Wood (1983). A similar consistency is shown by the yield curves plotted in Malkiel (1966, pp. 13, 14) and in the Treasury Bulletin. This is true even of yield curves based on polynomial methods. For example, those plotted by Chambers et al. (1984) reveal the explosive tendencies of polynomials only toward the end of the fitted maturity range. A class of functions that readily generates the typical yield curve shapes is that associated with solutions to differential or difference equations. The expectations theory of the term structure of interest rates provides heuristic motivation for investigating this class since, if spot rates are generated by a differential equation, then forward rates, being forecasts, will be the solution to the equations

prev_essay: In order to investigate the synchronized state in the neural network, we measure R and rho by changing gE and gI. We find three types of synchronized states. In the first state where gE is larger than gI, both R and rho are high. This means that in this state, both spike time and membrane voltage fluctuation of neurons are fully synchronized. In the second state, both R and rho are low. Thus, they show asynchronized behavior. Finally, in the third state where gI is larger than gE, R is low but rho is high. prev_essay:
Neural oscillation is known as being emerged from synchronized activity. To understand the neural oscillation, we first analyzed synchronization in neural network depending on I-E ratio. To classify the synchronization state, we measured two variables, R and \rho by changing gI/gE for different gE (Fig. 1). With small gI/gE (gI/gE < 4), we found both R and \rho are high. In this range, spike timing and membrane potential fluctuation of all neurons are synchronized. In the intermediate gI/gE (4 < gI/gE < 6), R and \rho are low, which corresponds to asynchronized state. With high gI/gE (gI/gE > 6), we found \rho is high and R is low. In this range, spike timing are not synchronized, but the membrane potential fluctuation is synchronized. Thus, we found two different synchronized states when gI/gE is low and gI/gE is high, between these two types of synchronized states, we found asynchronized states.

In state I, we found the timing of firing for excitatory neurons are synchronized (Figs. 2(a)).  tIn addition, when we see the microscopic dynamics of an excitatory neuron (viE), we found that the excitatory neurons fire on all peaks of oscillation. The inhibitory neuron fires more than excitatory neuron, but they showed the increased firing for each peak of oscillation. These results indicate that both excitatory and inhibitory neurons fire regularly. In state II, where asynchronized state, the timing of firing of neuron is not synchronized (Figs. 2(b)). However, we found that in some cases, they are synchronized weakly (from 10.1 to 10.3 s). In that case, we found both slow and fast oscillation are shown. In state III, we found that the timing of spikes is aligned rather than synchronized (Figs. 2(c)). We found that not all neurons fire for each peak of oscillations and the neurons are fire irregularly (vEi, vIi). In addition, we found that two different synchronized states have different oscillation frequency (Figs. 2(a), 2(b)).

Cordoba-Chacon et al. generated adult-onset, hepatocyte-specific, GH receptor (GHR) knockdown mouse (aLivGHRkd) to investigate the effect of GH on liver metabolism. aLivGHRkd mouse line was generated by injecting AAV-TBGp-Cre virus to adult GHR-floxed mouse. This mouse line was validated by reduction in Ghr mRNA and GHR protein expression levels compared to littermate controls (Figure 3A). After seven days of aLivGHRkd induction, liver weight increased in aLivGHRkd mice on standard chow diet (Figure 3B). aLivGHRkd mice also showed hepatic GH resistance. By the hepatic GH resistance, the rate of de novo lipogenesis more than doubled (Figure 4).
essay: Secondly, GH inhibits hepatic de novo lipogenesis, and it leads to treatment of fatty liver condition. Lipogenesis is the process of fatty acids and glycerol converting to fats. J.
